debateinfo.title: TRANSPORT AND REGIONAL SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (APPLICATION OF CRIMINAL CODE) BILL 2001

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Anthony, for Mr Anderson, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: The Transport and Regional Services Legislation Amendment (Application of Criminal Code) Bill 2001 amends certain offence provisions, in legislation within the Transport and Regional Services portfolio, to reflect the application of chapter 2 of the Criminal Code Act 1995 (the Criminal Code) to all Commonwealth offences from 15 December 2001.

For reasons of convenience, the bill also includes proposed amendments to the Australian Antarctic Territory Act 1954 and the Heard Island and McDonald Islands Act 1953 administered by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage.

Subject to several exceptions, where the penalty attached to existing offences of strict liability is reduced in order to comply with Criminal Code policy, the bill does not affect the current operation of existing criminal offences. Rather, it seeks to ensure that the existing criminal offences are not altered following the application of the Criminal Code.

The bill provides for amendments that specify whether an offence is one of strict liability. In the absence of such an amendment, offences that were previously interpreted as strict liability would be interpreted as not being of strict liability. In addition, the bill provides for amendments that restate any defences to an offence separately from the physical elements of the offence. This amendment is necessary to ensure that the defence is not mistakenly interpreted to be an element of the offence that must be proved by the prosecution. The bill also provides for amendments to:
(1) recognise that the Criminal Code does not apply to applied state and territory offence provisions;
(2) recognise the application (in whole or in part) of the Criminal Code;
(3) clarify the physical elements of an offence and the corresponding fault elements;
(4) identify the evidential or legal burden in relation to a defence;
(5) repeal offence provisions that are general offences in the Criminal Code;
(6) ensure that the meaning of the phrase `engage in conduct' includes omissions; and
(7) replace references to provisions in the Crimes Act 1914 with references to corresponding provisions in the Criminal Code.

The bill also exempts the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Act 1995, the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Act 1997, and the Road Transport Reform (Vehicles and Traffic) Act 1993 from the application of the Criminal Code. These acts have been exempted because they were passed under a cooperative scheme relating to road transport existing between the Commonwealth and the states and territories. As a consequence of the terms of the scheme, these acts can only be amended on the basis of a recommendation from the National Road Transport Commission (NRTC) and subsequent approval from the Australian Transport Council (ATC). The exemption is not to be permanent. The Commonwealth will refer the question of amending the legislation so that it is Criminal Code compliant to the NRTC immediately to be pursued through the workings of the ATC.

The bill does not change the existing criminal law. Rather, it ensures that the current law is maintained following application of the Criminal Code to Commonwealth legislation. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Horne) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 18 September, on motion by Mr Downer:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased to be participating in the debate on the Intelligence Services Bill 2001 following my involvement in the deliberations of the Joint Select Committee on the Intelligence Services in its preparation of the advisory report on the Intelligence Services Bill. I commend those speakers who have participated in this debate so far. I acknowledge the cooperation of the member for Kingsford-Smith in his detailed response to the bill and the cooperation of the opposition in ensuring that the final outcome will be that this bill will pass both houses. The member for Kingsford-Smith made the observation, amongst his detailed comments— and I agree with him—about the responsibility of the parliament in relation to the secrecy of operations. I will speak a bit further on these matters later.

speech.para: The member for Fadden, the chairman of the ASIO committee, made the very interesting observation that during the deliberations of the select committee there was very little interest by the press. That is an unusual situation, given that the press have over the years taken a remarkable amount of interest in matters related to ASIO, ASIS and other covert operations. I particularly commend the member for Banks for his bipartisan spirit. He was particularly active on the committee looking at the bill. I note that he suggests that both sides of the parliament have ownership of the bill dealing with this very sensitive matter. I well recall the member for Banks's particular concern about clause 14. I will allude to that in a minute.

The background to this bill before the parliament is the fundamental dilemma facing Western democracies—and it has been drawn very much to our attention in recent days—of the ability of elected parliaments to control the secret service operations of major Western powers. I think the Howard government and the Minister for Foreign Affairs have now come to a situation of providing a legislative backing for ASIO and ASIS. After a very cooperative approach by all members involved, the parliament now has a reasonable oversight of a secret service operation, a surveillance operation, on behalf of Australians, of those people, be they internal or external agents, who may cause us damage.

I made the comment in the parliament when we were discussing the joint select committee's report, and I will put it on the record again, that the focus of the Intelligence Services Bill is that ASIS was established by executive direction on 13 May 1952. It was not until 1977 that the government publicly acknowledged the existence of ASIS as Australia's foreign intelligence agency. It demonstrates the move that has taken place under the Howard government that ASIS is now under the control and direction of the parliament in terms of some of its policies but not its operations. I make that very clear.

The Samuels and Codd report, which other members have referred to, dealt with the fundamental problem of the ability of the government and the parliament of the day to oversee the operations of ASIS and ASIO. Our report states:

quote.para: The IS Bill reflects this recommendation by seeking to provide a legislative basis for ASIS which details levels of accountability and oversight, and sets out the functions of ASIS and of the Defence Signals Directorate (DSD).

speech.para: I will not go into the further detail of that. It raises the fundamental issue that the Australian parliament—unlike some of the other parliaments around the Western world— have compromised, with the help of the opposition and the select committee, to have genuine parliamentary oversight of these operations so that no longer are the press grabbing hold of headline material which really does not constitute the major operations of either ASIS or ASIO.

I particularly note that parliamentary scrutiny of these two organisations is based on parliamentary observation of general policy positions but not of operational day-to-day activities. It is very important that we understand that. The bill limits the immunities that are provided for ASIS and Defence Signals Directorate personnel. Those persons, be they on Australian soil or on foreign territory, have some limited immunities. I draw the attention of the House to the debate that is going on in the USA at the moment after the catastrophe in New York. Last week, I noted in the Australian the headline `CIA incompetence is criminal'. I make no particular judgment about the ability of the CIA in America, but the article points out that the CIA spends $US30 billion each year on the 13 intelligence agencies in the US. The article suggested that they failed `to protect Americans from a handful of lunatics' and `was just the latest in a line of disasters'. The article went on to state:

quote.para: Yet Mohammed Atta, who piloted one of the planes that crashed into the World Trade Centre, was a prime suspect in the 1986 terrorist bombing of a bus in Israel. How does someone like that— none of the hijackers used aliases—get into the US?

speech.para: That indicates the difficulty that Australian or American agencies have in finding and identifying persons who eventually turn up as terrorists and cause remarkable damage by using small numbers of people. Everyone in this House is aware of the catastrophic outcome of the events in New York. Recent headlines suggest that the CIA should have been more vigilant. I suggest that that is a fairly difficult assignment. Hopefully, here in Australia, ASIS and ASIO, in executing their task under parliamentary direction, will do their best to identify such persons or activities. In the short term at least that will be very difficult for Western nations, because with modern technology individuals can cause havoc, as has been demonstrated in the USA.

The committee, in looking at the relationship between the parliament and the agencies, was particularly concerned with clause 14 and it certainly took a lot of care and consideration to identify people who acted for the agencies in a way that conformed to Australian laws, yet it was able to ensure that those people could execute a successful outcome on behalf of ASIO or ASIS. In my judgment, after the committee discussion and the discussion of the definitions among members opposite, members of the government and professions involved in ASIS and ASIO, a sensible outcome has been reached in identifying persons who would be involved in such activities.

We now have a bill before the parliament and a clearer understanding of the role of ASIS and ASIO. Both organisations will be supervised by a parliamentary committee. That will depend very largely upon trust on the part of the executives of those two organisations in dealing with the parliamentary committee. In the UK and the USA there has been concern about who supervises the operatives, whether members of parliament have that capacity and whether they would receive sufficient trust from intelligence organisations. One witness before our committee suggested that even members of parliament should undertake an ASIO check. That was rejected on the basis that members of this parliament who form the parliamentary committee and who are trusted by ASIO and ASIS executives can play a sensible role.

In my judgment, the role of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security, as he has been operating in providing written supervision of the operations of ASIO, has demonstrated a very successful modus operandi. The minister must provide written instructions to operations by ASIO. The inspector-general, on behalf of the committee and the parliament, can provide his observations on whether those instructions are lawful and whether they execute the wishes of the parliament. In my observation, that has been a successful way to solve a very difficult problem. I emphasise the fundamental problem that we face in the parliament: we are asking the parliament, which is an open and democratic institution, to supervise covert organisations, because that is the nature of their activities. After struggling for many years, the Howard government have come up with a solution to provide the necessary balance.

I note that members opposite and members on this side have agreed that there is ownership of this legislation by both sides of the parliament. It augurs well for the attitudes of future governments and for the future operations of ASIO and ASIS that persons involved in those two organisations can have confidence that both sides of the House of Representatives and the Senate have agreed to a set of guidelines and directions in the statute book that will assist the operations of those two organisations into the future without fear of undue interference by the parliament, yet retain accountability to parliament by way of annual reports and informal discussions with the committee from time to time.

It has been in the national interest that, after this interesting and fairly long process following the royal commission, the Codd and Samuels inquiry, and long deliberations in drafting the legislation, we have come to this final position. In a world of terrorism which has been drawn very much to our attention in recent days, when the President of the USA is now suggesting that they will step up efforts to attack terrorists wherever they might be, in any part of the world, this shows a new dimension of terrorist activity and warfare between nations. It is appropriate that, in this particular week, this parliament has agreed to this legislation in a bipartisan manner, that the matters have been debated in full by a joint select committee and that those people with an interest and an understanding of these matters have agreed on the fine print. The legislators have agreed to the details of the bill.

It would be my earnest hope that the element of trust between the parliament and the two operations—ASIS and ASIO—would continue to be the order of the day and that these organisations will continue to execute their tasks. I put on the record the very good outcome of ASIO's activities during the Olympic Games in Sydney where I know and understand that they did their job professionally. The Sydney Olympics went ahead without any incident, and it is a credit to both those organisations that that outcome was achieved without any public fanfare or undue concern by members of this parliament.

I commend the legislation and the spirit in which it has been put to parliament. I hope that it can be a model for other parliaments and other such organisations around the world. At a time when some political leaders around the world are calling for yet more secret service activity and more of an attack on terrorists—which is quite right—the execution of those political statements is somewhat more difficult. I hope that members of ASIS and ASIO feel confident that the supervision by this parliament will be professional and that they will not be hindered in their activities to find the people who will be challenging the security of Australia, both of Australians personally and of Australian institutions. This is landmark legislation and I am delighted to participate in it and support it.

talk.start.para: —Like the previous speaker, I was a member of the Joint Select Committee on Intelligence Services that looked at the Intelligence Services Bill 2001. The committee did its job quite well. The government and opposition members on the committee cooperated with each other to come up with a report which we debated in this House a few weeks ago. The government has accepted most of the recommendations in that report and that shows that there is some movement here. It is particularly gratifying to me, as a member of the committee, that the government has done that.

speech.para: As we know, this bill will place Australia's foreign intelligence collection agencies, ASIS and the Defence Signals Directorate, on a statutory basis. As members are probably aware, ASIS was originally established in 1952 by an executive minute and for 20 years very little was known about the organisation by anyone outside of the government. An article in the Daily Telegraph in 1972 exposed its existence and since that time there have been numerous incidents and sundry inquiries into the aspects of various intelligence agencies, and of ASIS in particular. This legislation is, at long last, an attempt to regularise ASIS and its activities and to put it on a firm legislative basis.

It is very appropriate that we are debating this legislation now after we have seen the outcome of last week's attack in America and the talk of the failure of the intelligence services in the US. That seemed to be a particular failure of human intelligence, and there is now talk in the US that they are going to go back to what some people might think were the rather irregular good old days of the CIA. There has been talk that the intelligence services will have to cooperate with criminals and that they might have to enrol criminals and unsavoury people. In the words of one of the leading American officials, `It's a bad world out there and we've got to get down in it.'

This legislation makes sure that ASIS and DSD do not get down to doing illegal things in that bad world. It is very important for Australians to understand that there is now a legislative footing for this organisation, that this legislation will spell out the things that ASIS can and cannot do and that it will spell out the role of ministers and the parliamentary committee in overseeing the body. That is probably a very good thing for the organisation because too often with intelligence services people outside have an idea that they are up to everything—and all sorts of things—and that is often as much an impediment to the way these organisations work as it is a help. Putting ASIS on a legislative basis is a good thing for the body.

During the committee inquiry I learnt of the very high level of dedication of the people who run the security services in Australia. As long as we attract such people to run them, I do not think we will see any of the excesses that we sometimes see of intelligence agencies overseas. To have a parliamentary committee having oversight of ASIS and DSD will be a good thing. I have noticed as a member of the ASIO committee that the more open the intelligence services are with members of parliament, the more confident we feel with them. The model of the ASIO committee has been a very good way for parliament and for the government to regulate the security services.

I remember that in the seventies and the eighties all sorts of conspiracies abounded about what ASIO were doing here, what ASIO were doing there, that they were keeping files on everybody and that they were doing this, that and something else. But since the legislation was changed and ASIO was put on a more formal basis, there has not been that sort of paranoia and there has not been that hysteria among some sections of the community in Australia. I think the model for regulating ASIO, the internal security service, will be a successful model for regulating the work of ASIS and DSD. The role of the joint parliamentary committee that will be set up will also help to dispel some of the ideas that people have about what these organisations do.

The amendments the government has accepted to the bill that were put forward by the committee will also strengthen the bill and strengthen the rights of individuals. Explicit provisions have been put in the bill to prohibit political activities by ASIS. The immunity provisions have been tightened up because the committee was concerned that the immunity provisions in the original bill were extremely wide. The work of the committee was very useful in that when that was brought to the attention of the agency they said that was not their intention. They then worked with the committee with a proposal which would overcome what I am now willing to believe was an unintended consequence of the legislation. If the legislation had not gone to a parliamentary committee for discussion, the bill would have gone through in its original form, which would have had that very wide classification of an immunity of a person who was nearly any person who was helping ASIS to do anything in Australia.

The provisions of this bill make it also very clear that ASIS cannot get themselves involved in a lot of the things that we have seen more proactive people talk about in the US in recent days. I think to have that laid out in legislation for ASIS is a good protection for them, because there will always be people who think that in these James Bond sorts of areas everybody is out there trying to be James Bond. Members of the committee found to their relief that ASIS do not see themselves as James Bond or M or Q or whoever is sitting in the officials' box and that they do not have those views of the way that the organisation ought to work. But it is important that it is legislated to show that, because it is as much a safeguard for them as it is for the rest of us.

We have provisions for the Leader of the Opposition to be briefed by ASIS. We have provisions in the bill to ensure that the rights of Australians who might come to the attention of the organisation are protected, and we also have a much stronger definition of what the immunities are for ASIS officers. It is important that people do not get too carried away with wondering what those immunities are. They are designed basically to protect people from the conspiracy laws here in Australia. There is no doubt that some of the work that ASIS do will by definition be illegal in the country in which they do it, but there are laws now in Australia that provide that, if Australians conspire to break the law in another country, that can also be a crime here. While one would not want to see planning committees in the foreign affairs building being carted off to jail for considering something that may have been illegal in some other country, one also does not want to see planning committees in the foreign affairs building deciding to go out and burglarise people here in Australia. It is fairly clear from the way the legislation is now drafted that the vast majority of that work will be about planning things overseas and very little to do with people actually breaking anything other than the conspiracy laws here in Australia. But the original draft of the bill would have allowed people to do a lot more than that.

All in all, the legislation is very timely because it makes the point that the external security services and the internal security services here in this country are not in a position, and will not be in a position, to do the things that some of the more cowboy elements in America are suggesting that their security services ought to do. The framework in which they should operate is very explicitly laid out now, and I have no doubt that that is probably as much a relief to them as it is to us.

It was also an interesting experience to see the heads of at least four of the major spy organisations in the country sitting at the table, if the fellow from the Defence Department does not mind being referred to as a spy. The Director of DSD, the Director-General of ASIO and the Director-General of ASIS appeared before a parliamentary committee and gave frank evidence in public. I congratulate my fellow committee members for taking the decision at the beginning that all evidence would be taken in public. If we had not done that—if we had had in camera hearings—it would have led people to believe that some secret deal was being negotiated and that it was not all above board. The evidence the witnesses gave to the committee was frank, and it helped us to come to those unanimous decisions. There are not too many committee reports of this nature that go through this parliament. My recollection is that there has never been a unanimous decision out of an area that has as much contention as this area sometimes does. The committee members worked well together, and our job was helped by the fact that the officials were frank and honest with the committee. There were some rather humorous asides, particularly on the issue of who has the safe that disappeared from the Parliamentary Counsel's office. In all, it was a very useful exercise.

I look forward to the work that the joint committee will do. I hope that the members who get elected to that committee will take their roles very seriously. The people who have been on the ASIO committee over the years have done that and have achieved a good working relationship with the security services and have provided critical support without being captured. If this new committee develops that type of relationship with the agencies, it will be useful both to the agencies and to the parliament. I will be interested to see how the legislation works. I think there should be a review of the legislation in a few years time to see how it is working. You can never be sure of these things. If people know there will be another time line to look at it, it will focus people on it. It would be useful for the parliament and whoever is in government in a couple of years time to look at how this legislation is working. The closer we can make this legislation mirror the ASIO legislation, the better template we will have for the other organisations coming under our purview now. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —This Intelligence Services Bill 2001 will place the foreign intelligence collection agencies, ASIS and DSD, on a statutory basis. The bill establishes a joint parliamentary oversight committee, which the member for Watson described. The current ASIO committee will be disbanded and replaced by a new select committee that will have expanded jurisdiction and will supervise all of them.

speech.para: The opposition has cooperated fully with the government on this legislation. As was explained to me as a new member, the role of a number of senior people from both sides was to refine and finetune this legislation. The legislation was examined by a select committee and very senior people from the opposition and government sides have improved this legislation, which shows the Australian people that people in the Australian parliament from all sides take these issues and the defence of Australia very seriously. From what I have heard from both sides of the House, the officials of these agencies are to be commended for their cooperation and for the more refined state that we have now got to.

I cannot imagine that the Australian people would ever have seen a time where they understood the need for these kinds of agencies and organisations more than in the last week or two. I do not think it has ever been more apparent. I remember reading a speech by Senator Ray some months ago in the wake of the Olympics. He made the point that the effectiveness of these agencies' work could be judged by the fact that there was nothing on the public record about the Sydney Olympics in this regard. I think his point was a very good one. The Australian people should be very grateful that apparently everything ran smoothly at that major international event and there were no problems of terrorism or anything else.

What do we need these organisations for? I am not going to speak on the detail of this legislation. I want to examine the need for these organisations, particularly in the current circumstances. We need these organisations to preserve our freedom, our societies and—as the events in New York, Washington and Pennsylvania show—our lives. Unfortunately, there have been some people who have argued against the ethos of our cooperation on these matters with the United States. They take a view that British author William Shawcross has described as fundamentalist anti-Americanism. I will read something he said in yesterday's Age, because I believe it is very germane to these bills. Shawcross argued:

quote.para: The US is the most important democracy on Earth. It is the anchor of what we call (properly) the free world. That is an imperfect world, but it is far better than anything else on offer—as millions of migrants attempting to join it from other parts of the world will testify.

speech.para: I think that applies not just to the United States; it applies equally to Australia. He went on:

quote.para: American treasure and American blood were essential to Britain's victory of 1945.

speech.para: And, as the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition have said about Australia's defeat of the aggression that threatened Australia's very existence in 1941-42, the article goes on:

quote.para: America is the vital centre that held through the Cold War and enabled the world to defeat communism, the greatest terror of the 20th century. To be sure, Washington made mistakes, but American international engagement was essential to progress in the past century.
This new century's enemies are incredibly dangerous, as last week's attacks show. The assault on the World Trade Centre and the Pentagon reveal also how vulnerable the US now is.

speech.para: I would say that that vulnerability applies equally to Australia and that, therefore, the need for these agencies is as important here as it is in the United States. Mr Shawcross continues:

quote.para: But those who claim the US `had it coming' should realise that the attack on America is an assault on us all—and that we are all equally vulnerable.

speech.para: That is the point I want to focus on: this new threat of terrorism is an existential threat. I believe it is our very societies that those extremists would like to see destroyed. This is why I rise to support this legislation. I believe that, under proper parliamentary supervision, and with the cooperation of the opposition and the government working together with the responsible heads of these important organisations, Australia can prepare itself for these kinds of challenges. Indeed, these organisations may be at the frontline of preserving our liberties. As Mr Shawcross explains, the usual suspects are arguing in the Australian media that US foreign policy, and maybe Australian foreign policy, is to blame for these terrible events in the United States. Nothing could be further from the truth. The people who are perpetrating these deeds are not suffering from some angst about Western colonialism. They believe fundamentally that our societies are evil and should be attacked.

It is very interesting to note, as the member for Corangamite did, that all of these threats are interlinked. This is why we need these agencies overseas performing the tasks that they do; it is vital that they understand all of the international interlinks. The member for Corangamite pointed to the fact that the chief perpetrator of crashing those planes into the World Trade Centre, Mohammed Atta, had been the prime suspect in a 1986 terrorist bombing of a bus in Israel. If ever we needed proof that all of these events were interlinked and that we need serious organisations to analyse these links and to prevent them, surely that is the proof. It is also very interesting that one of Mr bin Laden's first and most serious interviews took place in Australia, in the magazine Nida'ul Islam in 1996, when he predicted his attacks on the United States. Those of us who live in Melbourne will remember the Herald Sun picturing one of Mr bin Laden's associates wandering around the streets of Melbourne a couple of years ago before he was expelled to Denmark.

Prior to the events of the past week, I wrote to the Attorney-General in his capacity as the minister who supervises ASIO, regarding an incident that took place in Canberra that I want to put on the public record. It was at the Canberra synagogue some three or four weekends ago where, with 100 people present, the lights on and 80 people in the car park, five men wearing balaclavas got out of a car, threw stones through the windows and then molotov cocktails and accelerant after the stones through the broken windows. This is an incident that I believe is terrorism. These people were not participating in desecration or vandalism. They knew there were people in the buildings, and this was a serious threat to the lives of those people. I commend the agencies that will be subject to the joint parliamentary oversight of this new select committee. I understand that they are taking these particular kinds of threats very seriously. I do, I know members of this parliament do, and I am sure the agencies will be informed by the extreme public concern with these kinds of events.

I have taken a very strong personal view that we ought to be as compassionate and humane as possible with the asylum seekers on the ships that have tried to approach Australia. I believe that we should not conflate our concerns with extremists who defame the great name of one of our world's monotheistic religions by using it for their own ends. We should not conflate the poor victims of the Taliban who are on the Tampa with those extremists. But we need to walk that fine line: the balance between the preservation of our liberties and a tough-minded defence of our societies from this existential threat from extremists. This legislation means that, with the parliamentary oversight of the joint select parliamentary committee, we will now strike that balance. It is a balance between parliamentarians having any undue influence on this committee and the intelligence agencies, as the member for Watson said, and supporting the agencies on a bipartisan basis in their ability to continue work that is needed for the preservation of the kinds of free societies that we have in Australia.

I mentioned during the condolence motion our support for the US, with the invocation of the ANZUS Treaty for the first time in 50 years and the cooperation of our Australian intelligence services which will flow. This cooperation ought to be informed not by the spirit of revenge or retribution that those who would have us do nothing say is our driving force; it ought to be informed by an intelligent, measured, calm and cool ethos of self-defence. What we want to do is to prevent these extremists from perpetrating these kinds of deeds again, and certainly in this country.

I believe that, after the events of this last week, these bills could not be more timely. The opposition supports this legislation. I think the process of cooperation between senior parliamentarians is very interesting, and I am sure the agencies are reassured—as the Australian people should be. Both political parties seem to self-select in choosing some of the most senior and responsible people from both sides to sit on these committees. We have thought about these matters very seriously and are approaching the defence of Australia, in the sense that these agencies are involved with them, very seriously.
At the conclusion of his article in the Age yesterday, Mr William Shawcross, in writing about the events in New York, Washington and Pennsylvania said:

quote.para: The core of democratic values was attacked last week. We are in this together. We are all Americans now.

speech.para: Those are certainly my views, and I believe they are the views that should inform us in handling this threat to our society. I believe that this legislation and these agencies are necessary in the current circumstances and that the way we have now set ourselves up with this legislation means that we are in a position to defend Australia.

talk.start.para: —I rise in this cognate debate and support this important legislation, the Intelligence Services Bill 2001 and the Intelligence Services (Consequential Provisions) Bill 2001. The agencies which are the subject of this legislation are important and integral parts of this nation's defence of its national security. This has been the truth for some decades. It is doubly the truth today, given the events of the last week.

speech.para: If recent events demonstrate anything, it is that the challenge of our national security is not just the concern of a narrow elite of the strategic or security policy establishment; it is now the concern of us all. Similarly, the events of the last week demonstrate that questions of foreign policy are not just the concern of a narrow diplomatic elite; they are now the concern of us all. These events demonstrate the total indivisibility of what we have always categorised—falsely, I believe—as the domestic and the international, strategic policy and economic policy, defence policy and social policy. These are not clinically separable concepts any longer, and they have not been for a long time. They are now part of an integrated whole.

Why do I say this? Because in the age of the new security policy, all of us are affected—not just a nation's standing army, not just the naval units of a particular nation state, not just the aircraft of our respective air forces. All of us are now affected. The clinical divide between the military and the civilian no longer exists. What was once the concern of a nation's main army is now the concern of a nation's main street.

The second factor alive in all this is that the threats to our security are now in multiple forms. There are still the so-called classical threats to security, defined in the classical defence policy literature, but there are also so-called soft threats to security: narcotics, illegal people movements and cyberterrorism and its threat to security. Then, of course, there is terrorism itself—physical terrorism of the type we saw graphically and grotesquely at work in New York, Washington and Pennsylvania last week.

The professional defence policy, strategic policy, and security policy literature have debated concepts of total security for almost a quarter of a century. In our policy debates we often conflate these terms as if they are identical. They are not identical. Defence policy and defence studies properly concern the discrete examination of the force structure of the armed forces of a nation and the military doctrine which will be used in the deployment of those armed forces in given strategic scenarios. This is a necessary science and it is one in which this country has a long and proud tradition, with our various academies and professional defence studies institutes.

Security policy is a much more all-encompassing concept. Defence policy is one of its subsets, but it has many other component parts. There is the whole field of economic security with its subfield technological security, the continued viability of a nation's financial infrastructure, of the world's international financial infrastructure and of a nation's physical infrastructure: power generation, transmission, distribution, water reticulation and transportation systems. All of these are component parts of a nation's security policy environment. Added to that we have the field of illegal people movements—23 million internationally displaced persons at present—and the merchants of death who currently prey upon them; we have the field of health and quarantine and a concern about the impact of communicable diseases; and we have the field of international narcotics traffic and its physical assault on our people. Then we have the violence of terrorism itself, global, regional and subregional. Terrorism is a field which is changing in its qualitative state; changing because of the impact of globalisation, with instantaneous communications, rapid transport and near-invisible financial transactions. All of these underpinnings of what we see as the magnificent advances of the global economy are at the same time equipping agents of terrorism worldwide with a new armory which in past decades has not been available to them. Overshadowing all these dimensions of what I have described as a nation's total security, we have the continuing effect of weapons of mass destruction—nuclear, chemical and biological.

The changing nature of the threat to a nation's national security, including this nation's national security, requires, I believe, a fundamental re-evaluation of how we best manage security policy in this country. I say that not as some invitation to a rancorous or partisan debate; instead, I believe it is time for a dispassionate discussion amongst us all about how we now integrate the range of security policy capabilities we have and how we enhance those capabilities against the changing nature of the total security policy environment in which this nation now finds itself.

It was in this context that the Leader of the Opposition on 13 September released a statement outlining a series of proposals about how we might begin to do this in the future. One of those proposals, immediately relevant to the propositions I was advancing just now on total security, is the last in this statement, which says that there is a need to:

quote.para: Establish an integrated national security policy approach by broadening the focus of our Cabinet National Security Committee so that it not only covers traditional issues (defence and foreign policy, security and intelligence, international trade strategy), but also strategic law enforcement policy (drugs, terrorism, border protection, information infrastructure protection, protective security). Government agencies covering these issues must also be more closely integrated.

speech.para: The practical challenge we face is how we can better integrate the intelligence product of the Office of National Assessments, the Defence Intelligence Organisation, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, the Defence Signals Directorate, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Customs, the Australian Federal Police and the various agencies of state governments currently engaged in the analysis of our security policy environment, and how we can better paint an integrated picture of the changing nature of our security policy environment in any given week, month and year because it now changes quite rapidly.

Our traditional approach in these areas, that of a semi-quinquennial strategic basis document produced by the defence policy establishment about the changing nature of our strategic environment, is, I believe, no longer adequate to this task. Our security policy environment is changing with extraordinary speed and complexity. Providing a mechanism which delivers an integrated analysis of our security policy environment is one thing; providing an integrated set of policy advices to government on what to do about changes in our security policy environment is another; and a third is to provide integrated mechanisms to give effect to policy decisions of government across its various agencies in pursuit of the maintenance of this nation's national security. How all this is to be done is a matter for fair and reasoned debate among us all. One proposal is for an enhanced National Security Committee of the cabinet and perhaps for that to occur with an enhanced secretariat, with personnel drawn from the multiple agencies of the existing security policy establishment. Another proposal which is often advanced is for a fully fledged national security council. I believe these are the parameters of the debate which we as a nation must now have with speed, urgency and without any partisan rancour for, very simply, our national interest now demands it.

However, fundamental to an effective defence policy in the narrow and an effective security policy in the broad is an effective intelligence capability, and this goes to the specific objects of the legislation before the House. Why is intelligence important? For some I think this is self-evident; for others it is less so. I suppose its key component is that, to the extent that it is humanly and technologically possible, we need to see beyond our own immediate horizons in time and space in order to meet any emerging threats to our total security before those threats fully materialise and then assault, weaken or even destroy our security. A second dimension is simply this: intelligence represents relatively inexpensive security. If you get intelligence right, if you can stop or reduce a problem before it requires a massive response involving multiple agencies of state, it is far less expensive for the Australian taxpayer. That is why I have always believed that our intelligence agencies in this nation should be properly resourced without any debate.

As for the immediate provisions of the legislation, the Intelligence Services Bill 2001 places ASIS, DSD and ASIO on a statutory basis. This is to be welcomed by all sides of the parliament. Secondly, it creates oversight of these agencies through a joint parliamentary committee. This is also welcomed by all sides of the parliament. This new mutual engagement between those who work within the agencies and those who occupy benches in this parliament will be an interesting and creative exercise as it unfolds. It will be a challenge to our professionalism and a challenge to our goodwill. I am advised by those who participated in the Joint Select Committee on Intelligence Services in the preparation of this legislation that what has characterised its deliberations and its discussions with the agencies concerned has, in fact, been that spirit of professionalism and goodwill. I believe that this balance that we will seek to achieve between accountability to the parliament and, through the parliament, to the people on the one hand, and the effectiveness of our agencies in the field on the other, is eminently doable.

I conclude by simply saying this: when we talk about the various intelligence agencies of this nation in our public debate, often those who work within them are derided in the media; often they are regarded as incompetent in what they do. Plainly, each of these agencies—as have all agencies of state— have had their ups and downs in their bureaucratic evolution. That is the nature of things. No department of state in this country or in any other Western democracy ever evolves without getting it wrong from time to time. That is just reality. We as a parliament and as a nation need to place on record the fact that we commend the professionalism of these agencies, because they discharge an important function for the nation. When they are attacked, in the main they cannot respond. We need to be mindful of that in this place and across the nation at large. The work which they do is not only important, it requires a high degree of professional ability; and in some cases the work is arduous and dangerous. The staff of these agencies should be commended for their professionalism. I am happy to join those on this side of the House in our support for the legislation.

talk.start.para: —in reply—At the end of this debate on the Intelligence Services Bill 2001 and the Intelligence Services (Consequential Provisions) Bill 2001, I thank all those who have spoken and, in every single case, thank them for the valuable contributions they have made to the broader issue of discussing the intelligence agencies and for their support for the intelligence agencies of Australia. I regard this as very important legislation. All of us agree that ASIS needs to be put on a statutory basis. There needs to be a degree of transparency and accountability, but at the same time we do not want to do that in a way that undermines the efficacy of the organisation.

speech.para: Secret intelligence is, ipso facto, secret and must be kept that way. So too must the people who work for intelligence organisations be protected—perhaps above all they must be protected. So if we want to have effective intelligence agencies, there have to be some quite substantial constraints on the degree to which their work can be made public. In other words, there are limitations to the transparency of those organisations. This legislation represents a very good compromise between, on the one hand, transparency and, on the other hand, maintaining the integrity and the efficacy of the organisations.

I took the view that it was important to get the parliament itself fully engaged in this process. Given the sensitivity of intelligence agencies, it is not going to be helpful to the country, let alone to the work of those intelligence agencies, if there is a great and divisive debate about their work. That has meant a degree of cooperation with the opposition, and I appreciate the good will with which the member for Kingsford-Smith, as their principal spokesman on this issue, and others have approached this whole task. We established the select committee, which I thought was going to be the most constructive way to handle this. There was a number of different alternatives that could have been pursued— House of Representatives committees, Senate committees and so on.

The idea of a select committee was built out of not only trying to engage the parliament very fully in this process but also ensuring that the members of the select committee had access to the sort of information they needed to be able to make balanced and educated judgments about the legislation. They therefore had to know a fair bit about ASIS and DSD, what they do and how they work. The briefings that were given by ASIS were—I know, as their minister—very full and very frank. As I have often said about intelligence, the more people know about it—as this committee would have found— the more they would have realised that it was not actually a conspiracy and, to some extent, the more they would have begun to understand that there is a certain element of it which is almost prosaic. In other words, it helped the legislation and it helped the passage of the bill to have the select committee know more about ASIS. I suppose that is a statement of the obvious.

The member for Fadden did an outstanding job as the chairman of that select committee, and I pay very warm tribute to him. He worked well with the other members of the committee—Labor and coalition: Liberal and National. He has shown a great interest in the task; he has put a lot of work and a lot of time into it. He has really made an outstanding contribution to public policy through his role as the chair of the select committee. A number of amendments, which we are going to get to in a moment, have been proposed by the committee. I sat down with ASIS and other agencies and we have gone through the proposed amendments very closely. I have to concede that in some cases it is my view that the amendments have improved the legislation—they have taken the legislation forward. It also in my view has been important to address some of the concerns that have been raised by some members.

The opposition, I notice, in a characteristic way claim, `These are all our amendments. If it hadn't been for the Labor Party none of this would have happened.' I think we can perhaps get off the grass a bit there. In the community there are understandably a couple of issues of concern which, as the minister, I am very happy to address. One of them was the question of immunities. At the level of talkback radio, the kind of proposition is that these immunities would mean that I, as the foreign minister, could speed through my electorate at 150 kilometres an hour and not be charged for speeding because I have immunities under the intelligence services act. This of course is a complete nonsense. But it has been important to clarify and define more clearly the immunities. There were recommendations made by the committee, and they have been taken up.

Also, the committee was rightly concerned about protecting the privacy and the integrity of Australian persons and Australian organisations. Again, I think the amendments there have been very helpful in addressing that concern. Finally, there were views within the bureaucracy about whether DSD should or should not be brought into the purview of this parliamentary committee to be established by this bill. My personal view was that it seemed like a good idea. I am glad that the committee made the recommendation that it did. I am obviously personally happy to endorse it and I am glad that others have now endorsed it as well.

It has been a very interesting process in terms of the work of the parliament. And that leads me to my two concluding comments. Firstly, I really do appreciate not only the remarks that many members in this debate have made about the importance of intelligence in general but also the way members of parliament in this debate have steered away from the hysteria that you sometimes find in the media about Aussie spies, networks of spies and how we are out there running conspiracies against the Labor Party or some other domestic political organisation through ASIS. That is just nonsense. But you often find yourself having to try to prove your innocence, which is very hard to do. I really do appreciate the support which has been given, and which has been demonstrated in this debate, by the parliament for the work of our intelligence agencies. They are made up of extraordinarily dedicated, professional and, in some cases, rather brave people. I have enormous admiration for the people who work for the Australian Secret Intelligence Service.

I noticed the other day that the Leader of the Opposition produced something that he called a `10-point plan' for addressing terrorism. I am glad that he showed some interest in these issues because obviously all of us need to focus very much on them. One of the 10 points, from recollection, was that there should be an increase in expenditure on intelligence. I make the point that, fair enough, there should be an increase in expenditure on intelligence, but we did actually increase the ASIS budget this year by around 23 per cent. The Director-General of ASIS, Allan Taylor, would say that there is no limit to the amount of money that you could spend on ASIS—he probably thinks that—but there is a limit to the amount of money that you can spend on anything. It is not a concept that the Labor Party has ever been very familiar with, but there is a limit. I have put a lot of extra resources into ASIS since I became the minister in March 1996. It is a much bigger and more extensive organisation now than it was then. Why? Because I think that the work of intelligence, the value adding—some people would say the force multiplier—we get from intelligence agencies is simply immense.

The last point that I wanted to make is in relation to the media. The media in this country never cease to amaze me. One of the things that has amazed me is how they have shown absolutely no interest in this legislation at all. If you want to know why the public is so cynical about politics and politicians, one of the reasons is that the media concentrate on trivia so much and on differences. They promote conflict because they think that it sells their papers or the TV shows better.

This is an enormously important piece of legislation; this is historic legislation. The government has taken the initiative to bring the legislation forward. It has worked very intimately with the opposition and through a parliamentary committee to improve the legislation and, other than on the day that we announced the introduction of this legislation, I do not think that there has been much of a squeak from anywhere in the media about it. This debate began yesterday and there was nothing in my clips this morning about the debate either. It is a pathetic indictment of our media. Nevertheless this has been a very important exercise. In a way, it sets up a great model for how the parliament can work with the government to ensure that legislation is truly effective and can yield broad national support. I very much appreciate the comments that have been made by members on both sides of the House. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

speech.para: These amendments form the government's response to the report of the Joint Select Committee on the Intelligence Services on the Intelligence Services Bill 2001 which was presented to parliament on 27 August. The committee, which I have already referred to in my remarks, was ably chaired by the member for Fadden and assisted by the member for Kingsford-Smith as the deputy chair. It did produce a constructive and helpful report after considering the bill in detail.

The committee held public hearings over three days and took submissions from interested parties and members of the public. Those hearings included the taking of detailed evidence in public from the heads of ASIS, ASIO and DSD and the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security. This was a significant step in terms of opening aspects of the agencies to scrutiny. The committee quite properly reviewed the bill as setting a framework for the operation of these important agencies well into future. I commend the committee's report and record my appreciation to the committee and the secretariat for their work and to all those who participated in the hearings and giving of evidence.

The resumption of consideration of this historic bill comes at a most critical time given the horrific events of the past week. The bill is of particular importance to the parliament. The Joint Select Committee on the Intelligence Services made 18 recommendations in its report. The government is pleased to accept the majority of the committee's recommendations without change whatsoever. The government will accept recommendations Nos 3, 4, 6, 8, 9, 11,12, 13, 15, 16 and 18 as proposed. It will accept recommendation No. 1 but strengthen it, and accept recommendations Nos 2, 5, 7, 14 and 17 in principle but with some slight differences in approach which have been discussed with the opposition.

The government does not support recommendation 10 made by the committee, and I think the member for Kingsford-Smith referred to this yesterday in his remarks. Recommendation 10 would have provided access to operationally sensitive information in the form of past operations, and amendments in relation to this recommendation will not be introduced—and I understand the opposition is happy with that.

These amendments address three critical issues in particular. The first is limited immunities for ASIS and DSD detailed in clause 14 of the bill. The committee focused on this provision in great detail. In its consideration it discovered that, as originally drafted, the provision went further than intended. Recommendations 6 and 8 of the committee report, which the government fully accepts, represent amendment items 14 and 15. These amendments result in provisions that are sufficient for the agencies in the conduct of their functions but also provide strong protection for the rights of Australians at home in Australia.

The second critical issue was activities focused on Australians overseas. The occasions when the intelligence agencies may need to focus on the activities of Australians overseas are rare. Nevertheless, to ensure that these occasions are properly limited, a strict authorisation process is proposed. This response is to committee recommendations 2 and 7 and is represented as amendment items 7, 8, 9, 10 and 11. The committee recommended that the test for whether a minister may authorise a particular activity in relation to an Australian person or organisation be centred on prejudice to national security. The amendments proposed by the government list, and therefore limit, those occasions when a minister may authorise an activity specifically focused on an Australian person. While not defining `national security'—this term has not been defined in Australian legislation, despite its use in numerous acts and regulations—the government amendments have gone further by limiting the circumstances in which an Australian may be a specific focus and by identifying these in the legislation. These amendments, which accept the thrust of the committee's recommendations, provide both assurance about the limits on the agencies' powers and confidence that issues relevant to national security will be properly dealt with. (Extension of time granted)

The third critical matter addressed by the committee was the inclusion of DSD within the oversight responsibilities of the parliamentary joint committee which was originally proposed to oversee the administration and the expenditure of ASIO and ASIS. The government has considered recommendation 11 carefully. On balance, it agrees that there is merit in DSD being included under the responsibilities of the committee. The inclusion of DSD under the parliamentary committee accounts for a large number of amendments being proposed—items 1, 20 to 25, 28 to 34, 36, 40, 42 to 44, 46 to 51, 53, 54, 56, 57, 59 to 62 and 64 to 70.

I will now comment briefly on the other recommendations accepted by the government. Recommendation 1 proposed that note 2 under clause 6 be amended so that the minister is obliged to advise the parliamentary joint committee of the nature of any other activities to be carried out under subclause 6(1)(e). The government agrees with the thrust of the recommendation but considers that this should be strengthened and given legislative effect. Amendment item 6 represents the government's response. Recommendation 3 proposed that the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security report in his annual report on the operation of subclause 7(d) of the Intelligence Services Bill. The government agrees with the recommendation.

Recommendation 4 proposed that the Attorney-General be consulted by the responsible minister when making rules relating to the communication and retention of information concerning Australian persons. The government accepts this recommendation and has proposed amendment items 16 and 17. Recommendation 5 proposed that protocols be developed for the operation of immunities—clause 14 of the Intelligence Services Bill and division 476.5 of the Cybercrime Bill. The committee said that these should be put in writing and approved by responsible ministers and the Attorney-General, and should be provided as soon as possible to the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security. The parliamentary joint committee should be briefed by the Inspector-General on the protocols and any subsequent changes to the protocols.

The committee also recommended that the immunity provisions in the bills should not come into effect until the Inspector-General had received the protocols and had briefed the parliamentary joint committee. While agreeing to the other elements of this recommendation, the government considers the agencies, particularly at this time, should be able to fulfil all their functions as soon as possible once the legislation is in place—and I am sure members agree with that. The responsible ministers will provide the protocols to the parliamentary joint committee as soon as possible, but the operation of the limited immunities should not be delayed until this can occur.

Recommendation 9 proposed that a new subclause be added to require the parliamentary joint committee to be briefed by the Inspector-General on the privacy rules and any changes to them. The government accepts this recommendation, which is amendment item 18. I also note that the proposed parliamentary joint committee will have access to these rules and will be able to provide comment. Recommendation 12 dealt with the parliamentary committee's ability to request the responsible minister to refer a matter in relation to the activities of ASIO and ASIS to the committee for review. The government accepts the recommendation, which is shown as amendment items 26 and 27.

Recommendation 13 proposed that schedule 1, subclauses 6 and 9, be amended to ensure that the requirement on the parliamentary committee to receive written authority to publish evidence should only be in relation to evidence taken in private. The government accepts this recommendation and has proposed amendment item 55 in response.

Recommendation 14 concerned the committee's ability to publish evidence under schedule 1, subclause 6(3). The committee considered that this provision provided for more restrictive procedures in relation to the operation of the parliamentary joint committee than is the case for the current ASIO committee. Rather than use the words proposed by the committee, the government has adopted the thrust of the provisions in the current ASIO Act to meet these concerns— and this is represented in amendment item 55.

Recommendation 15 proposed that schedule 1, subclauses 2(2) and 3(2), be amended to ensure that a notice to appear before the committee must not be for a date less than five days after the day on which the notice is given to the person. The government accepts this recommendation, and amendment items 39 and 45 refer.

Recommendation 16 proposed the deletion of two provisions dealing with notices to appear or produce documents to the parliamentary committee being provided to the responsible minister. (Extension of time granted) The government accepts this recommendation and has proposed amendment items 41 and 52. Recommendation 17 proposed that a number of terms used in the bill be defined. The government has agreed to define the terms `paramilitary', `police functions' and `serious crime'. The government has decided not to define the terms `intelligence', `national security' and `Australian organisations'. In relation to the term `intelligence', I note that `intelligence information' is defined in the bill. As I have already mentioned, the government does not see benefit in defining `national security'. The term `Australian organisations' is not defined, but honourable members should note that the definition of `permanent resident' is the same as that in the ASIO Act 1979 and includes the definition of a `body corporate'. The terms `foreign power' and `security' are also defined as part of other amendments made in the bill. Recommendation 18 proposed that arrangements for the briefing of the Leader of the Opposition about ASIS be the same as those relating to ASIO. The government accepts this recommendation and has proposed amendment item 19.

Beyond addressing the recommendations contained in the report of the committee, the government has proposed two additional amendments: items 12 and 13. These require that the agencies' functions do not include undertaking any activity for the purpose of furthering the interests of an Australian political party or other Australian political organisation, and they impose special responsibilities on the Director-General of ASIS and the Director of DSD to ensure that their agencies are kept free from any influences or consideration not relevant to their functions. These amendments provide further reassurance to the parliament and the public in regard to the activities of our intelligence agencies.

In moving these amendments to the bill, the government has largely embraced the approach recommended by the committee in its report. This historic bill, incorporating the amendments proposed, represents a major enhancement in the accountability of the intelligence and security agencies. It also further strengthens the role of the agencies by detailing their functions and responsibilities in legislation. I commend the amendments to the House.

talk.start.para: —The opposition commends the government for introducing these amendments and commends them to the House.

speech.para: Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

cognateinfo.title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT (EXCISION FROM MIGRATION ZONE) (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 2001
BORDER PROTECTION (VALIDATION AND ENFORCEMENT POWERS) BILL 2001
MIGRATION AMENDMENT (EXCISION FROM MIGRATION ZONE) (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 2001

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 18 September, on motion by Mr Ruddock:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: — The opposition will support these migration legislation measures contained in the Migration Amendment (Excision from Migration Zone) Bill 2001 and related bills. We have no problems with the way the original bill has been reintroduced. The measures are in accordance with our bipartisan approach to matters of this nature. I will not go into the details of the bill because I think they will be self-explanatory. Some of my colleagues listed to speak in this debate further down the track will no doubt talk about some of the specific provisions, particularly in relation to the Border Protection (Validation and Enforcement Powers) Bill 2001.

speech.para: I want to talk generally about some of the issues involved in people-smuggling and some of the issues involved in the way this government has approached this undeniable problem. I want to talk generally about immigration issues related to the protection of our borders. It is very important when we talk about these matters, when we talk about the integrity of our borders, when we talk about people who come here on an unauthorised basis, that we do so in a way that both governments, of whatever political persuasion, and oppositions do their best to think about the nation and the security of the nation and ensure that, wherever possible, these matters are looked at in a bipartisan way. The sovereignty of the country is very important. We naturally need to be vigilant in hard times such as this. We know, of course, about what happened in the United States only last week. People become far more aware of the matters involved in illegal immigration and the integrity of border issues when they see the sorts of unspeakable horrors which occurred in the United States.

As the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs full well knows, when it comes to supporting the government in an attempt to combat people-smuggling there have been a number of bills introduced over the last couple of years which in the main have received bipartisan support. I was going through a list of them before, but there are too many to mention today. I noticed one relating to strip search powers for immigration detainees. One bill introduced a raft of measures for immigration detainees such as new offences for inciting riots, increased offences for escapes from centres and new offences for the manufacture of weapons. All these were passed on a bipartisan basis. The Migration Legislation Amendment (Electronic Transactions and Methods of Notification) Bill 2001 was passed on this basis. Strength of character provisions have also been passed. On and on it goes, even to the point where one of the bills, known as the HREOC bill, was designed to stop lawyers from passing information on to newly arrived asylum seekers. All of that was passed.

The only piece of legislation relating to border protection issues that was not passed was legislation introduced into this House some 2½ weeks ago and which one of these bills now seeks to replace. At the time the opposition took what was, I believe, a very principled view, a view which any self-respecting political party not only in this country but anywhere in the Western world should have taken. It was a bill that was hurriedly introduced. It was probably, although I have no evidence, cobbled together in the Prime Minister's office and thrown into the hands of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs with not too much consultation with the excellent people in the immigration department. I think you can see the difference in the bill that the minister presented to the parliament yesterday. It has obviously been drafted properly. Obviously a lot of matters have been taken into consideration. It is a bill that can easily be supported.

Although the opposition has suffered a great deal of, if you like, political hurt out there in the electorate from not supporting that bill, we do feel that we stand here today completely vindicated for what we did at that time. I talked about this on radio this morning—I mention it to the minister because he will get the transcript of it shortly anyway. I will tell you it was on the Howard Sattler program; that makes it easier and probably will cost the public a little less for you to get the transcript. I said that the bill that was introduced a couple of weeks ago would have made the likes of Slobodan Milosevic happy. Some of the powers given in that were such bad law that it could not possibly have been supported.

We say that our position on the original border protection bill has been completely vindicated. We said that the original bill was flawed, draconian and unacceptable. A fortnight later, thankfully, the government appears to agree. The new package of legislation proposed by the government yesterday resembles the original bill in name only. The concerns that were expressed by the Labor Party caucus in our resolution of Thursday, 30 August have been met by the new package. This is, I believe, a credit to the Labor caucus. Knowing full well that there were political ramifications, we still said that we had to wake up in the morning and look at ourselves in the mirror. The fact is that, by taking that stance, we have ensured that, without compromising what the government was trying to do, we now have a bill which is acceptable and takes into consideration what we said were problems.

The Labor Party took a lot of heat and pain over the decision to knock back the original bill, but we have forced the government to come up with a more workable and acceptable package. The original bill sought to operate in spite of any other law. That is no longer there. The original bill bestowed open-ended immunities from the civil and criminal law. That is no longer there. The original bill posed no impediment to somebody wanting to tow an unsafe vessel out to sea. That is no longer there. What we do not have yet is a long-term solution to the problem of people-smuggling illegal immigration. I want to talk about that later. There is a difference between the opposition and the government. The difference is that we in the Labor Party, in the opposition, want to find a solution for the long term when it comes to people-smuggling issues. John Howard and this government want to find a solution for the third term—namely, their third term.

The regime about to be put in place by this new package of immigration bills will not deal with the problem at the source. As I will develop shortly, we will continue to focus on the need for further diplomatic efforts in Indonesia so that there is a proper and decent deterrent to those dangerous sea voyages, in the form of Indonesian agreement to accept the return of boat people for proper processing. We want also to continue pushing our idea for a national coastguard. As I have stated previously, Labor has always supported the government in an attempt to combat people-smuggling, and I have mentioned some of the bills that we have supported in the past. But we have not just provided passive support; we have suggested clear, strong policies in this area. In particular I want to talk about the opposition's coastguard policy, which the government continually tries to degrade by saying that it will not work. An Australian coastguard will be charged with the enforcement of Commonwealth law in Australian waters. That will include people-smuggling, quarantine, illegal fishing, customs and drug-smuggling. Coastwatch functions and resources will include all surveillance and response operations to enforce Commonwealth law in Australian waters, the collection and coordination of intelligence, search and rescue functions, and antipollution and environmental protection functions.

Australia needs a coordinated approach to address the difficulties that we face with unlawful boat landings, drugs, fisheries, pearling and quarantine related issues. An Australian coastguard will draw together the coastal surveillance resources, programs and activities that are currently undertaken by Coastwatch, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, the Australian Fisheries Management Authority, the Australian Federal Police and the Royal Australian Navy patrol boats. It will have primary responsibility for the maintenance and enforcement of Commonwealth laws in Australian waters. The coastguard will have a full range of law enforcement powers so that it can act as a maritime police force—as some people call it, a cop on the beat. The role will extend beyond monitoring the coastline; it will be in charge of detection surveillance and law enforcement with regard to people-smuggling and other illegal activities.

We need a national coastguard. We simply cannot afford to send a significant part of our navy to Ashmore Reef and the Christmas Island section to stop boats coming in from overseas. Apart from the fact that it will bankrupt the country if our only real solution to the problem is deploying a significant section of our Navy, the boats are still getting through. To my knowledge, at least two boats have already `run the blockade'. One has turned up at Ashmore Reef, with some 216 people who were transferred to the Tampa, and one has ended up at Cocos (Keeling) Islands. There might be more. It is impossible to detect all such boats. I am not saying that coastguards can do that, but at least they are equipped for that sort of work. They are not vessels that have hundreds of recruits or Navy personnel, at enormous cost. Some cost estimates are in excess of $100 million. When will the Navy be called back? I suspect that it will be after the election, because it will be kept there for political purposes. There is not much doubt about that. There has to be a way to stop people-smuggling. To its credit, at least the government is trying to do something, but a lot of its measures such as passing domestic laws have not seemed to work.

In 1999 the government introduced temporary protection visas. I remember the minister making a big deal at the time, saying, `This is the measure that is going to stop people coming from overseas.' The opposition supported that legislation, but we commented at the time that we did not think that it would solve the problem. Over the past 10 years, about half, if not more, of the unauthorised boat arrivals in this country have been since we brought in the temporary protection visa legislation. In other words, it has not proven to be the deterrent that the minister would have liked us all to think it would be. In fact, it has caused a lot of other problems. There are now people on temporary protection visas around this country who are being supported in many respects by charities and by the states. As a result, there is resentment of refugees, which unfortunately has led to some circles of unrest within the community. That is the consequence of turning immigration issues into political footballs. In the next five to 10 years, when people consider this period in our history they will look back at what has happened in the last couple of months and they will find that for purely political purposes the government was prepared to risk the cohesion of our multicultural society simply because what they were saying might be popular in the electorate for short periods.

Success in stemming the flow of unauthorised arrivals has been far greater when a regional and international approach has been taken. Over a period, the government, supported by the opposition, has arranged memorandums of understanding with foreign governments. The minister has visited China and other places, there has been increased cooperation between authorities and there have been fewer arrivals from targeted countries. I mention, for instance, the Fujian province in China. To his credit, the minister—I have told him this before and I have said it publicly—because he was able to go to the source, stopped the snakeheads sending people over here. Hardly anybody has come from that area in the year since that happened. We commend the minister on that. We believe that it is the only way that the government can do it.
