The proof of what has happened is Australia's appalling relations with our closest neighbour, Indonesia. Indonesia is the staging post for many people smugglers. Cooperation with Indonesia is crucial. Unfortunately, the Howard government is unable to build upon the relationship.

I want to quote from a speech given by the Leader of the Opposition which did not get a lot of coverage in the newspapers. For some reason, good policy and good speeches normally do not get a good run in the newspapers. They always seem to look for the more dramatic episodes and statements. This was a speech made by Mr Beazley to the Asia-Australia Institute, University of New South Wales, on 6 September 2001—almost a couple of weeks ago and not long after the Tampa incident. He said:

quote.para: The events of last week, and the whole question of illegal people movement, illustrates one eternal truth about Australia's future: we can have no security or certainty as a nation without building sound international relationships, and this cannot be done unless we have a national government focused on this task ... Above all, we need these strategies to be directed by a national government focused constantly on the task, not just whenever a media opportunity arises ... We are not shut off from the world. We are engaged whether we like it or not. Stopping the boats will not be achieved by hitting the domestic airwaves, playing the political angles for domestic applause.

A return to an orderly immigration regime can only be achieved by building cooperative international networks. This means working with other nations in a consistent and long-term fashion to secure Australia's place in the world.
Tonight I want to outline how a Labor Government would do that, and in particular how we would work to engage with our region.

speech.para: He then went on to enumerate some of the things a Labor Party in government would do in terms of this problem. He said:

quote.para: Most importantly, there needs to be a relationship built on mutual trust and respect that will develop over time between our leaders.
Today, this is best exemplified by the vexed issue of illegal people movement.
In the light of our experience with the MV Tampa—

speech.para: and this was just after the Tampa had arrived—

quote.para: we need—as a nation—to do some serious thinking and planning about how we deal with this question in a way that actually tries to solve the problem.
Australia is a good-hearted country, but we cannot afford to be an easy target for the people-smugglers—who are the real villains in this issue, not the illegal immigrants.
We must not allow our immigration policy to be subverted by unchecked illegal arrivals. We must protect our borders.
Labor believes we cannot be a soft touch, but that means having a smart touch in gaining international cooperation.

It means having a cop on the beat 52 weeks a year in the form of a Coast Guard, not just for 3 weeks when you decide it's a problem all of a sudden. It means recognising you can't protect your borders without working with your neighbours.

speech.para: This was said two weeks ago and it is quite prophetic. He said:

quote.para: Australia won't fix this problem without fixing the relationship with Indonesia. We won't fix this problem without a year-round dedicated Coast Guard. Only one political party is promising to do these things.

Let me set out my position in detail. Labor supported the Government's original position that the passengers on the MV Tampa should go to Indonesia, having been rescued in an Indonesian search and rescue zone. We offered the government bipartisanship because Australia's response conformed with the law and with our international obligations.

We parted company with the Government over the border protection legislation it hurriedly tried to introduce last week. This is because it was bad law, may well have been unconstitutional, and sought to override every other piece of Australian law. In any case, the Prime Minister said later he didn't really need the bill.
Labor offered Mr Howard our cooperation in finding a solution, including support for any specific legislation that might be required in relation to the MV Tampa—but our offer was refused.

Mr Howard mocked an ALP Caucus resolution stating that a safe haven would need to be found for the passengers if they were to be turned away from Australia. Then he spent last weekend trying to comply with it.
If it turns out that the Commonwealth's actions are found to be legally wanting in the next few days—

speech.para: and this is before the decision from the Federal Court—

quote.para: Australia will rue the day the PM refused Labor's offer to work with him on legislation specific to the MV Tampa situation.
What last week showed is that Australia cannot solve the general problem of illegal people movement on its own, and any attempt to solve it on our own is doomed to failure.

We cannot deal with every illegal arrival in the way we have dealt with the MV Tampa—for one thing, we simply couldn't afford it. In the end MV Tampa wasn't simply turned around and its passengers sent back to sea. An international solution had to be pulled together.
The issue of uncontrolled migration has not arisen over the past week—it has been a growing global problem for at least five years.

Around the world there are up to 23 million displaced persons. In Australia, 13,600 have arrived illegally by boat in ten years—11,000 since 1996. We have seen a 244 per cent increase in illegal entrants into Australia in just three years—driven entirely by a surge in illegal entries by boat.

speech.para: The Leader of the Opposition went on to say:

quote.para: Effective measures to combat people-smuggling require cooperation with neighbouring countries that are serving as transit routes for illegal people movement to Australia. People-smuggling poses a significant national security problem.

speech.para: The Prime Minister cannot even get President Megawati to answer his phone calls. In his speech, Mr Beazley said:

quote.para: A Labor Government will pursue the issue of people-smuggling with the highest levels of the Indonesian Government. We will do so in the context of a wholehearted commitment to build a mutually beneficial relationship with the new Indonesia.

Labor will seek a comprehensive agreement with Indonesia to extend bilateral cooperation against people-smuggling. This will be accompanied by increased technical support for Indonesian law enforcement authorities to disrupt people-smuggling operations and additional assistance to Indonesia for maritime surveillance.

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: Efforts to combat people-smuggling must be pursued on a regional basis. A Labor Government will appoint a Special Australian Representative to promote regional action on people-smuggling issues. The appointment of a senior Australian diplomat to this full-time role will provide a powerful focus for Australia's effort to improve regional cooperation.

A Labor Government will put the issue of people-smuggling firmly on the agenda in Australia's regional security dialogues—bilaterally and at the ASEAN Regional Forum. The ARF has in recent years expanded the scope of its dialogue to cover transnational crime issues including drug trafficking, arms smuggling and piracy. Greater attention must be given to people-smuggling and refugee issues across the region.
As a major initiative, the Special Representative will explore the potential for convening an Asia-Pacific Summit focused on the question of combating people smuggling.

A regional Summit involving Heads of Government, Foreign Ministers, and Ministers responsible for Immigration and Law Enforcement, together with UNHCR, other UN agencies and relevant experts would provide a valuable forum to develop a comprehensive framework for cooperation. Australia should be prepared to fund such a conference and related meetings of technical experts in 2002-2003.

speech.para: I want to say something shortly to my friend the honourable member for Fisher, who is sitting at the table—and he is my friend, although sometimes he can be pretty silly— about putting this issue into such a context that all it does is create fear and anxiety amongst the Australian public. I want to talk about that in a moment. I have quoted extensively from Mr Beazley's speech because it shows that, rather than trying to make political capital out of this, Mr Beazley is saying, `We want to find a solution.' We do not want to have the situation where the Australian Navy, or a significant section of it, are up there just at the time that we start to beat the drum before an election. The reality is that most of these people have arrived during this government's time in office. In other words, it has been their watch. They have tried all of these things and they have failed. I accept it is a difficult proposition; I understand that. But they are the government, it is their watch and they have failed. When this government fail, which they do quite often on a lot of issues, they tend to find scapegoats, and of course at the moment the scapegoats are everybody but themselves.

Whilst we understand that there is no easy solution to the problem, we know that the rhetoric that is used should not be alarmist. It should not be used for political purposes to incite possible unrest, particularly in a society like ours which is made up of over 200 different nationalities. Apart from indigenous Australians, all of us if we go back three, four or perhaps five generations are from people that came from overseas; all of us are. The last thing that this country needs is government leaders, or anybody, going around the place trying to incite some sort of racial unrest. Unfortunately, whether it is unintended or not, the fact is that that is happening.

talk.start.para: —Through you, Madam Deputy Speaker, I will fix up the member for Fisher in a moment. I was particularly disappointed when I saw in an AAP report the Minister for Defence, Mr Reith, the member for Flinders—who of course will be leaving this parliament in the next couple of weeks and will not be coming back—trying to make a connection between some of the so-called boat arrivals and terrorists. The AAP report, dated 18 September, was headed `Govt continues linking refugees to terrorists'. It said:

quote.para: Defence Minister Peter Reith first made the relationship between boat people coming to Australia and terrorists last week in the wake of the attack on the United States.

speech.para: He is quoted as saying:

quote.para: There is an undeniable linkage between illegals and terrorists and it is absolutely vital in my view to ensure that we don't have illegals entering Australia inappropriately because given the fact that some of those people come from country that is centre of terror, I would be particularly concerned if those people were allowed to enter Australia.

speech.para: Of course there is a possibility that that could be the case, but I ask the House to consider what happened in the United States last week. The terrorists came in either legally or using false passports, and they were actually taught how to fly in America. They were not people who turned up in leaky boats and who paid $15,000 to people smugglers. Terrorists usually come in good suits, and they sit in seat 2A in the front of the plane. They are well financed; bin Laden or somebody gives them money. They are not even checked for security. How ridiculous is it to suggest that these people come in on boats? People who come in on boats end up in detention, and we give them security checks as thoroughly as we can. We check who they are. Terrorists are not going to come over here and spend time in detention. It is a nonsense. That suggestion was made to incite unrest in the community and to make linkages that possibly do not exist.

I said this before, but thank God nobody takes any notice of the honourable member for Fisher, who is sitting at the table and whom I count as a personal friend. Thank God that this is a person who, when he makes speeches from time to time and talks absolute rubbish, nobody takes any notice of, because, if they did take notice of him, the man ought to be ashamed of himself. I know the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Ruddock, does not do that. He does a lot of stupid things, but he is quite smart about how he does them. He does not go out and do what the member for Fisher is doing. I say to the member for Fisher: I know that deep down you do understand what you are doing. I say to you: desist. There might not be a lot of people from ethnic backgrounds in your electorate, and there are not in mine either, apart from the fact that most of them are from Anglo-Saxon backgrounds—

talk.start.para: —There are in mine.

—Yes; there are in yours, and there are in a lot of people's electorates. The last thing we need is to have this awful situation of people throwing petrol bombs at mosques. The people who suffer are Australians. Maybe the honourable member for Fisher does not do it intentionally; I will give him the benefit of a very strong doubt. But I say to you: do not do it again. You are a better man than that—at least I think you are a better man than that. There might be some venal political gain for you in doing that, but all it does is incite unrest. Apart from the member for Flinders, you seem to be the only one who is continually saying things like this. I ask you to desist.

speech.para: I want to say on behalf of the opposition that we support these bills in the spirit of bipartisanship, because we are concerned about the effects of people-smuggling and about the integrity of our borders. We have certainly proven in the past five years since we have been in opposition that we are as concerned and as hard on these illegal immigration problems as is the government. Apart from that one bill which was just unbelievably bad law, we have supported the government in almost every instance. We will continue to do so. We support the bills, but we ask the government to be a little bit more sensitive to the fact that this is a multicultural country and not to use these issues simply for venal political point scoring.

talk.start.para: —I rise today somewhat disappointed by the member for Bowman's contribution to the debate on the Migration Amendment (Excision from Migration Zone) Bill 2001. It is interesting that, when these debates are held, it is only the Labor Party saying that politics surround this very difficult and vexed issue of illegal migration. It is almost a substitute for engaging in a debate on the substance of the subject, almost an alternative to being tested and challenged on ideas about a problem that is of concern to governments right around the globe. The pathetic and demeaning way in which the member for Bowman, the shadow immigration spokesperson, and those in the Labor Party try to present the government's agenda here as somehow being one borne out of political expediency is offensive. It is a revolting misrepresentation of the sincere and genuine efforts of a government trying to tackle an enormously complicated problem that governments around the world have been trying to grapple with. It is a problem that is not going to go away, and it requires thoughtful, insightful coordinated action to try to stem the flow of illegal migration.

speech.para: While Minister Ruddock—the minister at the table; he is probably the most honourable individual I have met in public life—toils away at this extraordinarily complicated issue, we get a poor excuse for a policy alternative. The member for Bowman has added absolutely zero to the debate and, ridiculously, he talks about the Labor Party's principled position. Principles are about moral rules and about fundamental truths that guide your actions. That is what principles are about.

In the Financial Review today, there is a story about Labor's backdown. Labor have agreed not to oppose the government. They have no alternative plan; they have decided to just get out of the road of the government's genuine efforts to do something about this problem. One senior frontbencher from the ALP is apparently concerned about a dramatic slump in support for the Labor Party in the wake of their opposition to the government on this issue. The political motive rests with the ALP, as reflected in the Financial Review today. A senior frontbencher said:

quote.para: People had to get to the point where we were cheesed off being wedged—and we'll fix it when we are in government.

speech.para: That is the clearest statement that Labor is cooperating for the sake of political expediency, and it is published in today's media. When one is running around thinking about political motivations for these issues, look at the conduct and the rhetoric of the ALP and its inability to come up with any alternative plan other than to have Kim Beazley paddle out in an inflatable rubber duckie to stick a Coastguard sticker on the side of a vessel that has an Australian Navy sticker on it. That is all Labor can come up with. Alternatively, the opposition will spend $2 billion replicating the Coastwatch, coastal surveillance and Navy protection arrangements that are in our border protection systems. All the Labor Party can come up with is a new sticker on the side of our boats to say that it is now a coastguard, without confronting the issue of the tools the coastal protection authorities will need to tackle and to manage this extremely complicated issue. That is all the Labor Party have offered.

It is a bit like the Roadrunner cartoons: every time Wiley Coyote tries to come up with a plan a big boulder lands on him. His legs are going, his back is arching and he is just about to get going when—whoomph!— the boulder lands on him. That is the Beazley way of handling this issue—he gets wound up and excited and is on the verge of doing something, and then—whoomph!—realisation. Labor is so out of touch and so disconnected from the policy debates of today.

If you listen to Labor, they are going to do some serious thinking and planning. That is novel; they have been in opposition for five years. Why not do some of that now? They are talking about being pally with the Indonesians so that we can send illegal arrivals such as those on the MV Tampa back to Indonesia. The Indonesians did not want them, and the people on the Tampa did not want to go there. It is a little problem, isn't it? It is one of those Wiley Coyote problems. The Beazley plan falls over.

Labor are going to appoint a public servant to jawbone countries to take back illegal migrants. Senior government ministers who command the respect of foreign governments are working with those foreign governments to achieve better outcomes in an extremely complicated issue. What is the other Labor Party solution? To put illegal immigration on the agenda. Where have they been? My brother lives in the Netherlands. He rang me and said, `There's a general mood in Europe that, thank goodness, someone is trying to do something about illegal migration.' It is an issue that concerns countries right around the globe. Jack Straw, the Home Secretary in the United Kingdom, started talking about it last year. Countries are grappling with extremely complicated issues. Australia is being seen as a guiding light of action, of proactivity and of positive intervention at a national government level.

The Beazley plan is, `Let's get everyone together for a chat.' Where have the Labor Party been? Minister Ruddock has already funded the United Nations High Commission for Refugees to organise an international conference in October. It is happening. This is action. The government is doing constructive work. Contrast that with the `Acme' solutions of the Labor Party: they look good, they are bandied around and Labor sound like they are interested, but they take us nowhere.

talk.start.para: —They don't even look good.

—That is probably right; they don't even look good. Most people can see right through what is going on here. While the factions within the Labor Party haemorrhage over this issue, it is only the Howard government that has a clear plan. The contrast is the Labor alternative of new stickers on the sides of our boats and calling them coastguards. It is a pathetic response to an international issue on which Minister Ruddock and the Howard government are leading the way.

speech.para: So what are we talking about today? This is a package of bills designed to strengthen measures available to our nation to preserve our own sovereignty. It is about safeguarding the integrity of our borders. It is about providing the border protection authorities with the tools they need to do their jobs effectively. It is about putting beyond any legal doubt the lawfulness of the reasonable and measured actions the government took to handle the MV Tampa and subsequent events. It is also about removing the incentive for people to choose illegal migration, people-smuggling, as a preferred pathway to gain entry to this country.

Let me put it another way, and I sure the minister will not mind it if I recount some of the conversations he and I have had: there is a vibrant, highly regarded and very constructive Afghan community in my electorate on the Frankston-Mornington Peninsula area. Many of them have relatives in northern towns in Pakistan, in Peshawar and Islamabad. They come to see me and say, `Bruce, why is it that we can't get our relatives to gain a refugee visa?' They go to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and they visit the Red Cross in northern Pakistan. My local community is frustrated that their relatives cannot gain entry. That frustration is often borne out of the simple fact that there are 23 million displaced refugee seeking individuals under the supervision of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. There is a handful of countries around the world that offer a haven for those people—for 23 million people seeking somewhere to resettle, seeking a refuge. To qualify for one of those positions, your circumstances need to be more devastating and more compelling and the infringements on your personal dignity and the persecution you suffer have to somehow lift your circumstances above those of 23 million other people who are seeking a refugee visa. That is a great frustration.

I said to Minister Ruddock during one of our backbench committee meetings on immigration, `Philip, do you know what worries me? It is that the best advice I can give my local constituents is to save up their money and have their relatives arrive illegally. I don't want to give my constituents that advice.' I do not want to say that, somehow, they are infinitely advantaged, infinitely better off than people in refugee camps if they can cobble together the cash, pay a people smuggler $16,000 to $19,000 each and arrive on our shores illegally and that their prospects of being granted a refugee visa through the court system will be infinitely better than if the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, the dude who looks after this complicated problem, looks at their case and says, `I'm sorry, there are others whose circumstances are more compelling.'

What we are about today is decency in our humanity. People ask, `How can you restrain those people seeking to arrive here illegally?' My answer to that is that we do that with some heaviness in our heart, but our heart, our national spirit, makes 12,000 opportunities available for people in the most desperate circumstances to start a new life in this country. Shouldn't those 12,000 places go to the people who deserve them the most? Shouldn't the level of persecution that those people are subjected to be the greatest, because we want to do the most good with the opportunities we make available in a country that, on a per capita basis, is only outperformed by Canada in creating a refuge for those people? Shouldn't those places be given to those who need it most? Shouldn't they, as there are examples in my local community, go to the Afghan woman living in Afghanistan under the fundamentalist Taliban regime, where women are not allowed to work and their daughters are not allowed to go to school and where they have children whom they cannot feed—they pick up scraps of bread and the like? We saw it on a television program the other night: the women cobble together food to feed their kids, because in that part of the world women are not allowed to work. Surely we should be opening our hearts to those people. Surely if we have places available they should go to those people.

Those places should go to the people in Sierra Leone who have stood up for democracy and now need to stay in those UNHCR camps for their own protection, because they get killed if they leave. Surely a place should go to those people, in advance of someone who can cobble together $100,000 and get their family here through illegal people smugglers. Surely your right to get access to those 12,000 places should not depend on the size of your bank balance. People say, `How can you be so inhumane?' Give me a break! What about the southern Sudan? You have people living in camps in northern Kenya who have been driven out by the Islamic fundamentalist regime in southern Sudan. They flee and they get locked up in Kakuma for their own survival, because if they hop out of that camp they get taken out.

What about in other parts of the world such as the Balkans where you have a Bosnian Muslim married to a Serbian and, because of the ethnic cleansing that has gone on over there, they cannot live anywhere because the ethnic divide in their communities gives them nowhere to call home? Surely they have to be preferred refugees to our country over someone who decides that they were displaced years ago through horrendous events in the Middle East or in Afghanistan, has settled and created their own business, accumulated wealth and has decided it is time to leave and pursue a better life in Australia. They have tried to get recognised as a refugee but, basically, it is about their economic circumstances. Their right to live a dignified and peaceful life is there, but they would perhaps rather be living in Australia. I can understand that: this is the greatest country on earth; of course they would want to come here. But we have 12,000 places; let us make sure they go to the 12,000 most deserving people who are suffering horrendous levels of persecution; not the people who can cash up their assets and pay a people smuggler.

If they are coming out of Afghanistan, Iran or Iraq they can arrive in Malaysia without a visa, because no-one checks in Malaysia. As the Indonesians flee Indonesia to go to Kuala Lumpur, the boats are backfilled with people who have come over from Afghanistan, Iraq and Iran into Malaysia. They then end up in Indonesia and get on a boat and come down here. These are people who have cashed up their assets; they have chosen to sell. They have freely accumulated that wealth. How persecuted can you be when you accumulate that level of wealth? There are people fleeing Afghanistan now who are paying $10 to cross the border into Pakistan. That is everything they own. Compare that with people paying $16,000 to $19,000 a head to get into this illegal people-smuggling racket.

talk.start.para: —Queue jumpers.

—Yes, queue jumpers. Give me a break: there are 23 million individuals looking for sanctuary and we have 12,000 places. We invest several hundred million dollars a year into making sure that these people settle well and also to process the paperwork, the claims, the appeals, the further appeals, and the legal processes— while immigration lawyers get fat pockets as they extend the period within which people who are assessed not to be refugees try their luck through our legal system. That situation contrasts with the individuals who have the wealth to pay for passage. They are free enough to leave at a time of their own choosing, free enough to realise their assets and sell everything they own, to notify family that they are leaving, to get on an aircraft of their choice—whether it is business or economy class I do not know, but they can choose an airline of their choice—and fly to Malaysia or somewhere else in our region. They are so persecuted that they can do that any time they choose. They are so persecuted that they are able to accumulate wealth. They are so persecuted that they are able to organise their affairs, get their family together, and pursue illegal immigration channels. They are so persecuted that they arrive in a transit country and meet up with people smugglers. They are so persecuted that they then travel to a destination where they meet up with somebody else. They are free to move, free to make those choices, free to exercise the pursuit of what they think is a better life. They are so persecuted that they are able to do all of that. They are so persecuted that they can get on a boat and try to land here illegally. That is how persecuted they are. They can do all those things of their own free will, unimpeded, and pay for it.

speech.para: Contrast that with people living in northern Kenya, people in the Balkans, people in the great lakes area of Africa, or people who are trying to eke out a basic living in parts of Afghanistan, where being a woman is a passport to being denied the opportunity to raise their kids. Their husbands may have died in the freedom-fighting efforts against the Soviet occupation. There are a million reasons. There are people in my community who are like that, and I have been able to assist them into Australia because they have no way of maintaining their basic dignity.

This legislation is about making sure that those 12,000 places go to the people who deserve them most. It is about making sure that our humanity goes to the most deserving. It is about making sure that our borders will not be challenged by organised crime syndicates which trade in people and on the opportunities our nation presents, and make a profit out of it—bypassing our lawful migration systems and challenging our border protection arrangements. Individuals are coached on what to do and say when they arrive. They dispose of their identification so that it becomes our task as a nation to find out who they are, whether they are of good character, and whether they are able to involve themselves in our health system without creating risks to our public health. Then we have to determine whether they are genuine refugees.

There is little doubt why some of the people on the second vessel which was intercepted by the Manoora were unhappy. Some of those people had tried their chances in Indonesia and were told they were not refugees. They got on a boat, and then our people said, `We know you. You have tried this before. You are still not a refugee.' They were understandably unhappy, because they felt they had paid for passage to a new life in this country and that they were being denied what they had paid for. The pity is that they paid people smugglers; the pity is that new life was the liberty, freedom, peace and prosperity in our country. The bigger pity, though, is that they were seeking to take the place of people who were more deserving, people who were more desperate, and people whose persecution is so horrendous that they cannot even leave the protection of the United Nations High Commission for Refugees. This is a day when Australia is saying, `This matters to us. We want to make sure our programs are humane and fair and that the generosity of this great country goes to those most deserving.' When the sun comes up over the lands of Australia, we know that our big hearts are going to those who need it most. I commend the bills to the House.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in this cognate debate on the Migration Amendment (Excision from Migration Zone) Bill 2001 and the Migration Amendment (Excision from Migration Zone) (Consequential Provisions) Bill 2001. We in this place are all politicians, of course, but first and foremost we must be legislators. On Wednesday, 29 August this year, the government introduced into the House the Border Protection Bill 2001, after giving the opposition 40 minutes notice. That bill was ill conceived, absurd in its operation, and we could not support it. In particular, the legislation backfired because it would have applied to Australian citizens on board Australian pleasure vessels as much as it would have applied to illegal immigrants on board foreign fishing vessels. It would have given officers of the Commonwealth absolute discretion to use coercive force and to exercise powers, without accountability—powers that exceeded those of a soldier in the heat of battle, a soldier called out in a civil emergency or a terrorist attack, or even a police officer pursuing a murder suspect. It gave extraordinarily wide powers to extraordinarily junior officers. I will go through those provisions shortly and point out how absurd the legislation was and why it needed to be changed. Fortunately, the government has come to its senses with the package of bills that it has proposed today, but I think it is necessary, as a result of the debate that has taken place, to spell out just why the Border Protection Bill 2001 was so absurd.

speech.para: Before going through the bill, I would like to draw people's attention to an article written in the Bulletin of 11 September 2001 by Laurie Oakes, a respected political commentator. He described the background to the legislation in these terms:

quote.para: The legislation had been thrown together in an afternoon, and the government wanted it rushed through both Houses that evening. In a remarkable display of blind (some would say irresponsible) obedience to the executive, Coalition MPs gave it the thumbs up without seeing either the bill itself or an explanatory memorandum.

speech.para: And what did they approve? They approved legislation that did not have a stated purpose. It contained powers to expel a ship from Australian territorial waters and, in so expelling a ship, to expel those persons on the ship from Australian territorial waters, but it did not give the purpose for that expulsion. For instance, it did not talk in terms of a potential or actual breach or anticipated breach of the Customs Act or the Migration Act; it simply gave extremely broad powers to expel ships with people on them. How was `ship' defined in the legislation? It was defined as:

quote.para: ... any vessel used in navigation, other than air navigation, and includes a barge, lighter or any other floating vessel.

speech.para: What is `any other floating vessel'? That could of course be an Australian pleasure craft. A yacht, a ski boat, a windsurfer or, indeed, a sea kayak could be included in that concept of floating vessel. Who were the people contemplated by this legislation? Clause 6 gave power for a Commonwealth officer, or a person assisting an officer, to return to a ship `a person' who was on board the ship. Of course, `person' could mean an Australian citizen, a citizen of the United States, Canada, Great Britain or from anywhere in the world—`a person'; a human being. So that legislation backfired big time. It hit Australian citizens as much as it hit illegal immigrants on board foreign vessels. That is a tremendous backfire in your own territory. For that reason alone, no responsible opposition could have passed that legislation.

Let us look at the powers that were given to the government. I know the government will say, `We never intended to use these powers against Australians.' But, coming back to my first point, we as legislators must pass legislation that has regard to not only the government of the day—and the opposition of the day, for that matter—but also the fact that there will be governments of different persuasions in time yet this legislation would have remained on the statute books. In other words, you have to get your legislation right. It is interpreted by the courts on its face, and it would exist into the future. It had to be rejected, and any sensible and rational analysis such as Laurie Oakes undertook would prove that to be the case.

Clause 4 of the bill says an officer may, `in his or her absolute discretion', give directions for a ship and people on it to be removed. Moreover, clause 4(2) provided that that direction `must not be called into question, or challenged, in any proceedings in any court in Australia.' Bearing in mind that this legislation, as I have said, applied as much to Australians and Australian vessels, that officer, who was defined in section 3 as being any employee of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs—not someone who had appropriate training, but any employee of the department—had the power to exercise these extraordinarily broad discretions with complete legal immunity. Indeed, clause 7 of the bill protected such an officer, who had the power to use coercive force, from all forms of civil or criminal accountability. Clause 10 specifically said that the bill—which I again emphasise impacted as much on Australian citizens on board Australian vessels as anyone else—`has effect in spite of any other law.'

It was completely absurd for any responsible parliament in this tradition of the Westminster system to even contemplate passing that legislation. I know that it evoked tremendous debate in the community. All I can say is that those who were spearheading the debate did not take the time to read the bill or even the explanatory memorandum before participating in that debate, because if they had looked at those provisions they would have seen that the bill was quite irresponsible and absurd in its operation and potential operation. Indeed, it was quite reckless of the government to introduce such a bill, which I again emphasise would have applied as much to Australian citizens as to any illegal immigrants. They are the reasons that the opposition rejected that bill, but we rejected the bill in the context where, in all other respects, the opposition has offered bipartisan support to the government to address this issue of illegal immigration.

There is no doubt that this is a big issue, but this government has had 5½ years to commence addressing this issue. As I understand the figures, over the past 10 years about 13,000 people have illegally entered Australia by way of boats. I understand that in the last five years of the Labor government there were about 2,000 people. They were unquestionably a problem to be dealt with, but under this government there have been about 11,000 people. So, if you like, this government has had 11,000 warnings that the illegal people-smuggling trade is on the increase, but it has waited until three months before an election to respond. And how did it respond? It responded with absurd and ridiculous legislation on 29 August. Fortunately, the government has taken on board criticisms that we have made and criticisms that informed commentators have made. So I am pleased to be in a position to indicate that we can support the current package of legislation, the Border Protection (Validation and Enforcement Powers) Bill 2001 and also the legislation relating to the excision from the migration zone of certain islands and territories of Australia.

The reason we can accept the amendments, particularly those contained in the new border protection bill, is that it is an entirely different piece of legislation. It does not operate on the basis of enforcement powers being triggered by a direction from the Prime Minister or a minister, and it is in the context of specific legal regimes that already exist in, firstly, the Customs Act and, secondly, the Migration Act. It actually proposes amendments to those two acts. Clearly, the enforcement powers—that is, to remove vessels or people—are in the context of preventing a customs offence, on the one hand, or a migration offence, on the other hand. This is not simply a power for the sake of power, but the exercise of power for a purpose.

There is also a third stream—indeed, it is the first stream in the new bill—which is to validate action which has already been taken in respect of the Tampa. We have consistently offered to support the government with legislation to address the situation of the people on the Tampa, and it is reasonable for the government to include in that validation section events that have occurred in respect of other vessels that have arrived since 27 August, most noticeably the Aceng. Importantly, the first part of this bill refers specifically to those vessels or any other vessel reasonably suspected of carrying people seeking to breach the Migration Act. Again, we have a vessel identified—so it is not legislation directed at Australian citizens, which the former bill most certainly was. The identification of that specific purpose in that context means that officers who will exercise these powers will be trained officers either in the customs or migration field or, if necessary, police officers or defence officers. They will be trained, they will know what they are doing and they will be operating in the context of an existing framework.

In summary, our first reason for supporting the current legislation is that it has those specific purposes within existing legal frameworks; it is not a power for power's sake at large. The second point is that it clearly will not apply to Australian citizens, as the earlier bill did. Importantly, as I read out before, the earlier bill attempted to completely override the rule of law in Australia; it would have applied notwithstanding any other legislation. This bill as proposed by the government now is acceptable, one of the reasons being that it specifically acknowledges the role of the High Court, under section 75 of our Constitution, to review administrative action. There is a specific clause noting that fact in each of the divisions, in the three parts that I have mentioned—the validation provision and the enforcement provisions in the customs section and the migration section.

The third reason we can support the bill is that the government has taken on board our concerns regarding the exercise of force. We must recognise that when parliament authorises the use of coercive force it must do so in a responsible and prescribed way, not at large, not with absolute discretion. The use of force in the bill we are considering today is consistent with similar pieces of legislation where the use of force is authorised subject to the requirements that trained officers must undertake their duties in good faith and that any force used must be determined to be both necessary and reasonable to undertake their duties. That is a safeguard again in the context that it is specifically acknowledged that their actions are subject to review.

The final reason that we are in a position to support the bill is that it specifically requires an officer, before returning someone to a vessel and expelling that vessel, to have regard for the safety of that person. That was not the case under the former proposed legislation. There was no requirement to have regard to the safety of the person before they were expelled. Effectively, under the former legislation a vessel, no matter how unseaworthy it was, could have been dragged out to sea and allowed to sink, with the loss of all life, and those officers would have had complete immunity. These new provisions prevent that and are sensible; the government have taken on board our concerns.

The other point I want to make in this debate is to dispel any suggestion that, had we agreed to pass that fundamentally flawed and absurd piece of legislation on 29 August this year, it would have had effect in any way, shape or form on the legal proceedings considered in the Federal Court regarding the status of those people now known as the Tampa boat people. The reason it would not have had effect is that, even if a ministerial direction had been given under the Border Protection Bill of 29 August, clearly the Federal Court's decision at first instance related to the boarding by the SAS troops in the period before any such direction could have been issued. Also, specifically, the Federal Court at first instance determined that there was detention upon the Manoora after it left Australian waters, a situation completely unaddressed by the previous bill. Of course the whole methodology adopted by the government in respect of the Tampa issue was to remove persons from the Tampa and put them on the Australian naval vessel the Manoora before transporting them to Nauru.

The Border Protection Bill 2001 of 29 August did not provide for that possibility at all. It provided for the removal of a vessel, namely the Tampa—not the people off the vessel onto another vessel. In summary, in no way, shape or form would that bill have prevented the Federal Court proceedings. Indeed, I think the government by implication specifically acknowledges that issue in that the amendments to the Customs Act and the Migration Act that are being proposed in this legislation will specifically enable officers of the Commonwealth to remove either vessels or persons not on those vessels, that is, separately from those vessels, so it would facilitate what occurred with respect to moving people off the Tampa onto another vessel. I think by so enacting there has been an acknowledgment that the former bill was deficient in that respect. It was quite mischievous, indeed misleading and counterproductive to a rational debate, for the government, members of the government, or anyone else for that matter, to suggest that the Labor Party's defence of the rule of law on 29 August in any way, shape or form contributed to or enabled that litigation to take place.

The final issue which I should address but will substantially leave to my colleagues is the excision bill—that is, the bill excising from the migration zone Cocos Island, Christmas Island, Ashmore Reef and some other territories prescribed by regulation. We are prepared to support and indeed we acknowledge that, if persons who are in distress can be taken out of the sea and brought to dry land for processing, it may actually facilitate more humane treatment of those persons, rather than putting them on board a naval craft such as the Manoora and transporting them to other locations. Even if they are to be transported via Cocos Island, Christmas Island or another location as designated, clearly it is easier to give them health checks and the like if they are on dry land before so transporting them. We are prepared to acknowledge that that argument exists. We are also prepared to acknowledge the legitimacy of giving a different class of visa status so that these people who arrive via people smugglers do not have the opportunity of jumping the queue. In summary, we have offered bipartisan support all the way through in dealing with illegal immigration. It is a shame the government has not taken up our offer earlier. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Migration Amendment (Excision from Migration Zone) Bill 2001 and related bills that are before the House. While Australians may argue about the federal government's prime role, the most important role that the government undertakes, there can be no doubt that the maintenance of Australia's sovereignty would be one of those at the top of the list. It is certainly a major concern to the Australians that I speak with in my electorate. The maintenance of Australia's sovereignty includes our right to determine who will come here and when. For those who say that Australia lacks compassion, allow me to put the figures before the House. Australia has a proud record on immigration.
—One of the most humanitarian countries in the world.

—Indeed. The member for Fisher is quite right, and I will get to that in a moment. Since 1945, almost 5.7 million people have come to Australia from other countries, with almost 600,000 of those under refugee and other humanitarian programs. In fact, Australia on a per capita basis is second only to Canada in its generosity to refugees. Today nearly one in four of Australia's nearly 20 million people was born overseas. The provisions contained in this legislation are overwhelmingly in Australia's national interests. It is one of the great and enduring responsibilities of any government to protect the integrity of its national borders—and our borders are under threat. In 1998-99 there were 921 unauthorised arrivals, and in 2000-01 there were 4,141 unauthorised arrivals. In the last full calendar month of this year there were 1,212 unauthorised arrivals.
—How many?

—There were 1,212 in one month: more than in the whole year of 1998-99. The reality is that Australia's borders are under great stress and pressure. According to media reports, there are 5,000 potentially unauthorised arrivals waiting to come to Australia from Indonesia. So this is historic legislation which will be welcomed by the vast majority of Australians, particularly those in my electorate who have consistently voiced their anger to me over the defeat of similar legislation in the Senate by the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats. Later in my address I will get to the concerns of citizens in my electorate.

speech.para: First I would like to deal with the Border Protection (Validation and Enforcement Powers) Bill 2001, which is particularly relevant, validating as it does the recent actions of the government and officers of the Commonwealth, including members of the Australian Defence Force, in relation to vessels carrying illegal immigrants and those on board those vessels. It validates all of the actions taken by the government since 27 August 2001, which is the date on which Australia first took action in relation to the MV Tampa. It also provides additional statutory authority for future actions in relation to incursions into Australian waters by unauthorised vessels and any persons aboard any such vessels. This means that apprehended vessels, and those aboard, must not necessarily be brought to Australia, and it covers operations similar to that currently being carried out by the HMAS Manoora. This is necessary to prevent rulings similar to that of Justice Tony North being brought down in the future. This will provide certainty to my constituents in Dawson who, since the Justice North ruling, have constantly asked a quite reasonable question.

That night I had a meeting with constituents on an unrelated matter. My phone started ringing at eight o'clock and it rang and rang. Some of the calls were from people 300 kilometres away from Mackay. The message was the same: who is governing Australia—the elected government or an unelected judge? People were furious that decisions that rightly belong to an elected government that is totally accountable to the Australian people were overridden by one judge. That question from my citizens in Dawson has now clearly been given an answer. Although the Labor Party undoubtedly portrays the original legislation as flawed— and I will deal with that shortly—and sees this as some sort of backdown, nothing could be further from the truth. The scope of the bill has been broadened. Changes to the original bill were necessary because of changed circumstances, not because of the indecision of the Labor Party. The fact is that this bill covers everything that the original bill sought to do, plus a range of other measures. The bill is still necessary, just as the previous bill was necessary, to protect Australia's borders and Australia's sovereignty. I want to refer to Mr Beazley's original response in the second reading debate on the original border protection bill. One of the points that he made struck me greatly. He said, referring to Australia and the government:

quote.para: ... and we believe this to be the case—[it] already has sufficient law to cover the position associated with it.

speech.para: Subsequent events have shown that in fact that was a totally erroneous conclusion, as were so many others. The shadow Attorney-General has said that the original bill was deficient. The only deficiency is in the lack of leadership shown by the Labor Party and the Democrats in this debate that is absolutely riveting for all Australians. The fact is that the government has spent the past two weeks in the Federal Court, arguing about the destination of those who were aboard the MV Tampa, and this highlights the precise reasons why it is necessary that the government introduce the border protection bill. This new bill will cover the Tampa and any other vessels, together with those on board who seek to make unlawful entry into Australia. It also covers those on the Aceng, plus those who have arrived at the Ashmore and Cartier Islands and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands.

I note that one of the Labor Party's arguments was that Australians on Australian vessels could be subject to the original bill. While technically that may be correct—and I notice that the shadow Attorney-General said that it would depend on the political colours of the government—the fact of the matter is that no government is suddenly going to decide that some charter vessel with Australian citizens having a happy sail should be towed out of Australian waters. The suggestion that any officer of the Commonwealth or any member of the defence forces would undertake such an action is an insult to our defence forces and to the very high standards of Australian Commonwealth officers. To suggest that a vessel that is perhaps sinking or damaged might be towed out of Australian waters is a further insult to those who work either in our defence forces or as officers of other departments. It was a convenient excuse that the Labor Party used but, of course, it did not fool the Australian people. They are most astute and shrewd and they saw the reason: it was simply lack of leadership.

Returning to the bill, we need to confirm the authority for the actions taken by our defence forces in moving people from the waters surrounding Christmas Island and the Cocos Islands to Nauru. The government is confident that any actions taken under the authority of this bill will fulfil our international obligations. I will speak briefly about the bill dealing with the excision of some Australian territories from the Australian migration zone. The bill is to ensure that any intending illegal immigrant who arrives in an excised area after 2 p.m. on 8 September 2001 will not be able to make an application for an Australian visa if detained by Australian authorities. It would also enable an authorised officer, including a member of the Australian Defence Force, to take an offshore entry person, a would-be illegal immigrant, from Australia to another country. This would, for example, enable a person to be moved from Christmas Island to Nauru for the purpose of refugee assessment. The bill also, importantly, prevents any legal proceeding against the Commonwealth or any person acting on behalf of the Commonwealth. This bar on legal proceedings would have effect notwithstanding anything else in the Migration Act or any other law.

The new and stricter visa regime contained in the bill will deter further movement from, or the bypassing of, other safe countries. Most importantly, the bill will crack down on people smugglers and make their predatory profession far less attractive. The truth is that people smugglers do not care what happens to the people who get on their boats, they do not care what happens to the boats themselves; they only care about the money. For those who say that we should be compassionate and aware of our international obligations, it is quite right to assert that Australia should do that. But those who watched the Four Corners documentary a week or so ago—and it was an excellent production—would have seen the situation in Taliban Afghanistan, with mothers who cannot work and provide food for their children and women who are not allowed an education. It is a desperate situation for many. Those, such as those women and children, who leave Afghanistan and go into refugee camps in Pakistan and elsewhere and who are genuine refugees who fear for their lives and are persecuted have no money to pay people smugglers and have no other options. Their only option is to wait and wait and wait, while others who do have the money— and the amounts being bandied about are anywhere from $A12,000 to $A30,000 or $A50,000—can pay people smugglers. People who have access to such funds are not those who are destitute and without resources. They jump ahead of genuine refugees who wait patiently for their opportunity to come.

The people smugglers, as I have said, care about none of that and are determined to continue their exploitative business. While we are working, quite properly, with other governments to stop this trade, we need to send the strongest message possible to these people that they will pay the price if they are caught. The legislation provides for mandatory sentencing arrangements for people convicted of people-smuggling offences. Where five or more people are smuggled into Australia, the perpetrators can receive a sentence of up to 20 years. First offenders will be sentenced to at least five years; repeat offenders could get at least eight years imprisonment. The message is quite clear: if you engage in people-smuggling and you get caught and convicted, you will go to jail for a very long time—not as with some of the penalties that we have seen imposed by courts recently. This, of course, does not apply to minors.

In summary, this is an important legislative package for both the government and the Australian people, who will welcome its passage through the parliament. It would be remiss of me not to congratulate the Prime Minister on his leadership in this matter— leadership that is, regrettably, totally absent in the ranks of the opposition.

In the time left to me, I would like to move to others who perhaps have been less than helpful in this national debate. I refer to an article that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald entitled `Stumbling on a path of inhumanity'. It is by Malcolm Fraser, a previous Prime Minister of Australia. I have great regard for previous prime ministers, regardless of which party they have come from. They have served our nation and they are deserving of our respect and regard— particularly Mr Fraser, who heads Care Australia. He is obviously spending his time in retirement in the very worthy activity of community service. However, I have to say that those who have been Prime Minister of Australia have an obligation to give a more insightful, thoughtful overview of national issues. I will pick up perhaps some of the references that Mr Fraser made in his article. He said:

quote.para: When policy falls heavily on the poor, the destitute, those seeking to flee hunger, brutality and tyranny, then that policy is wrong. It is inhumane.

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: The destitute have been made pawns in a harsh political contest.

speech.para: The truth is that those who are poor, destitute and seeking to flee from persecution are in fact those who languish in refugee camps around the world; they are those who have no money for people smugglers and have no option but to wait. The truth is that Mr Fraser, in opposing many of the government's sensible and fair-minded measures, is in fact ignoring those he seeks to assist. He went on to say:

quote.para: Turning 430 destitute people away from our shores cannot be regarded as an act of Christian charity—

speech.para: referring to those on the MV Tampa. The truth is that those people are not destitute. They have been able to pay people smugglers. What would be an act of Christian charity would be to ensure that refugee places in Australia are there for those who most desperately need them—not for those who can most cleverly exploit the lack of laws in Australia, as has been the case to date—and to ensure that only those who are deserving are able to access such places. In what is a very long article, Mr Fraser went on to say:

quote.para: We should ensure sufficient places are made available in recipient countries so that genuine refugees are not kept in camps for many years without hope.

speech.para: That is certainly a very laudable sentiment, and he is absolutely right. But, if there are 23 million refugees worldwide, the possibility of the recipient countries—and there are only a limited number of countries that have so far agreed to take refugees—being able to take all 23 million refugees is, frankly, impossible, much as we would wish it otherwise.

I am very disappointed with that article written by Mr Fraser. It ignores much of the information that the current government has made available to the Australian people and it does not add to a balanced debate in Australia; it is not in our long-term interests nor in the interests of genuine refugees. I hope that ex-Prime Minister Fraser, compassionate as he is, will perhaps give more thought to the conflicting arguments in this debate and argue in our national interest and that of genuine refugees.

In the time left to me, I will turn to the media. They actually were stumped during this debate that the Australian people did not share their views. In fact, never have I seen the gulf between the self-proclaimed pseudo-intellectuals in the media and the fair dinkum Aussie so stark. Christopher Pearson put it very well in the Australian Financial Review when he said, referring to an article by the Australian's Paul Kelly:

quote.para: Instead of being “an inept saga of crisis management” and scrambling by John Howard—

speech.para: as asserted by Paul Kelly—

quote.para: ... this was a deft exercise of influence and a defining moment in domestic politics.

speech.para: He probably did not realise how prophetic his words would be as time went by. Just in the last two days I have distributed a petition calling on the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats to allow the passage of this bill through both houses of parliament, and the number of people who have signed it is extraordinary. I have signatures from Kirwan, Brandon, Ayr, Longreach, Home Hill, Mackay, Slade Point, Bowen, and Winton— which is far west of where I am and, I think, in the electorate of Capricornia. The signatures are flooding in. There is no doubt that this issue has sparked great concern across Australia and great regard for the government and particularly for the Prime Minister's leadership on this issue. I will quote from one letter that is symptomatic of those received by newspapers in my electorate. It is headed `Labor takes weak stance' and has been written by Mr P. Gibbins of Mackay. It states:

quote.para: So Kim Beazley and his Labor comrades didn't have the 'ticker' to vote for the federal government's legislation permitting the forced removal of ships from Australian waters. Why am I not surprised?

The ALP have showed they are prepared to put the interests of people smugglers and illegal immigrants ahead of the interests of Australian taxpayers. Labor has again demonstrated that they are hopelessly out of touch with ordinary Australians and only interested in listening to noisy minorities.

speech.para: (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Australia requires a sense of national unity and a respect for its fellow citizens if we are going to come through the very difficult periods without greater division than we have had hitherto. I think we ought to step back and reflect on the origins of this border protection legislation. The shadow Attorney-General has clearly set out the reasons the opposition believes the legislation introduced by the government a fortnight ago was made in haste and contained provisions which would have shamed this parliament forever had it been passed. He made the point that our first duty was as legislators rather than as politicians. I go further. I say that our first duty is as Australians. In that task we have defined those elements which bind us together in common as Australians.

speech.para: I was particularly disappointed by the comments of the member for Dawson, which were quite on the edge of this debate, regarding former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser. She chided him for his comments about the way this parliament is dealing with these issues and asked him to spend more time arguing in the national interest and in favour of genuine refugees. The implication was that the former Prime Minister and those who have concerns or qualms about the way in which this government has addressed this issue are not genuine Australians, are not real Australians, are un-Australian. I regard that as profoundly disturbing.

I find it profoundly disturbing because we are already seeing seeds of the kind of internal breakdown that we so eloquently spoke against just the other day in the wake of the tragedy in the United States. We as parliamentarians came together to say that we need not only to condemn those acts and to bind ourselves to common action with those who have been injured in their quest for a just but moderated solution but also to reinforce those elements which bind us together as Australians. I recounted in that debate the instance when I was in a taxi with a man who was wearing a turban. He happened to be a Sikh, not a Muslim. Because of his appearance, a group of youths in a car swerved towards him and abused him, simply because they perceived him to be Islamic. From those small wounds that are to date quite minor because our society is stronger than those who would wrench it apart would wish, great tears can emerge.

I contrast the way this legislation was introduced into this parliament and how it was dealt with by this Prime Minister with the way President Bush has dealt with a far greater crisis afflicting his nation. When we were faced with an instance that the Prime Minister regarded as a serious incident that required the common approach of this parliament, he gave the opposition 40 minutes notice of a piece of legislation that was so unsatisfactorily drafted that it has now been revised and entirely changed by the government itself. He sought our support to have that legislation introduced and dealt with in both houses on a single day of sitting of this parliament. He then set about a process of demonising as being outside the mainstream of Australian opinion those who drew proper criticism of it.

Contrast that to President Bush. President Bush recognised that at a time of national crisis Americans required bringing together. He had a significant task, a far greater crisis than anything facing Australia. But he reached out to those forces in political opposition to him and explained to them the common task that he sought their cooperation in pursuing. There were no briefings from the Australian Prime Minister to that effect in relation to the instance that I am speaking of today. When President Bush was confronted by these instances, he recognised that it required an international solution and he started to build an international coalition in order to prosecute that moderate but effective defence of freedom that he has committed himself to. There was no such process from the Australian Prime Minister. Indeed, we had the Prime Minister on talkback radio, playing to the galleries within the Australian domestic community, promoting the kinds of tensions that as yet are small tears in our social fabric. But he did not pick up the phone to speak to President Megawati Sukarnoputri and did not do anything that could have effectively searched for a say of resolving this without the kind of intemperate debate that has characterised this to date. He then brought into this parliament legislation that in similar circumstances he, had he been Leader of the Opposition, would have castigated in the same terms.

Let me not be insensible to the political realities that the member for Dawson and the member for Dunkley have adverted to. When nations feel under threat, they do act sometimes in circumstances that they later regret. I believe that in the long-term history of the Australian Liberal Party the actions of the Prime Minister in introducing that legislation will be seen as a matter of their regret. When we were faced with that legislation and the circumstances in which it was presented, we knew that to oppose it in this parliament would be to our short-term and possibly long-term political cost. We knew that. We believed it was put forward with that intention, because of the manner and circumstances in which it was presented. Had the government sought our cooperation as it did with the legislation that is now before the House, and had the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs seen fit to provide an extensive briefing to the leadership of the opposition, to take us through it and explain the manner in which it dealt with the issues, and how in practice it addressed the concerns of the opposition which we had raised previously, had there been a genuine attempt at bipartisanship, we could have resolved this a fortnight ago. We could have had this legislation a fortnight ago.

We made that plain to the Prime Minister on the day. Caucus affirmed that common purpose the next morning and set out the terms on which we would support legislation. Those terms indicated that we were committed to finding a humane and legal solution for the situation of the people aboard the Tampa but that we would not support the coalition bill because it purported to override all other laws without qualification, including international maritime laws and Australian criminal and civil laws; created an unnecessary and unreviewable absolute discretion for Australian officials in removing vessels from Australian territorial waters, irrespective of the seaworthiness of those vessels or the health and safety of those on board; gave no guidance as to when, how and why such a decision was to be made; provided no rational basis for the assessment of what `reasonable means' and `reasonable force' are in the removal of a vessel; and was so broad it would potentially allow the exclusion of Australian citizens on Australian vessels without any avenue of parliamentary, administrative or judicial challenge or review. But we also indicated that Labor would support legislation that would accommodate a proper response and that dealt with these circumstances.

We remained open to that and we now concede to the legislation that comes before us, not because we have changed our position but because the government has. The government now has put forward a set of proposals which we could have supported a fortnight ago had our support been sought in a genuine and bipartisan way. That is not to say that we think that this package of legislation is the best way of dealing with this. It is still a matter of some haste. In the ordinary course, legislation making such profound changes to the migration laws or the laws affecting significant areas of public debate in Australia are given to parliamentary committees for examination. There is opportunity for public comment. There is a serious assessment of the national interest. None of those things are available to us in these circumstances. We might say of this legislation, drawing the distinction we made in relation to the law relating to the previous legislation, that it now comes within the reasonable range of proposals which an Australian government might make. But there are other measures that could have been adopted, other ways through it, and some commentators make that point very validly.

I not only want to speak in this debate of the reasons that we now support this legislation; I also want to reflect on those many millions of Australians—certainly they are a minority, but they include the former Prime Minister of Australia—who are deeply concerned about the way in which this debate has been conducted. I want to reach out to those people who feel that there has been a want of compassion and concern not only by the government but also by the opposition in its support for this legislation. I say to those people that there are some issues in public life where I suppose what you might call the Socratic solution has to be taken: you have to swallow the hemlock in order to make a moral point for the future, and your society is improved because of that ultimate sacrifice. That was the circumstance in which the Australian Labor Party found itself a fortnight ago. We could not pass this legislation, notwithstanding the political consequences which we knowingly faced. But, of course, the problem with a Socratic solution is that you are dead, and we should not wilfully take a Socratic solution if the possibility of life and better outcomes is available to us. We are practising politicians, not suicide bombers. Our responsibility is to the Australians of the future.

We believe that there can be a better way of seeing our way through some of these issues, and we have put constructive proposals to the government in relation to many of these issues. We have, for example, drawn attention to the circumstances in detention centres and called for judicial review. We note the concerns of the UNHCR in relation to the facilities in Nauru and their concern that that may create a precedent for UNHCR direct involvement in the use and processing of offshore refugees in the case of developed nations. We note we have a significantly improved proposal for coastal security—the Australian Coastguard. We note that the Australian government claims that 99 per cent of illegal arrivals seeking entry to Australia are detected by boat, but we are sceptical of that. Of course, it is incapable of proof one way or the other. How can one prove or disprove the assertion that 99 per cent of persons are detected? That is quite incapable of proof or disproof. How could you prove what you cannot know because of the nature of the circumstance?

What we do know is that most people who currently come to Australia actually have in the past sought to be detected. They have sought to find an Australian vessel, because they would then be taken to a point where they would be processed within the Australian domestic regime. Now the rules will change. Now they will seek to evade our coastal patrols and to reach the Australian mainland, because they have a far better processing option. And, in that course, we do need to have more effective and best practice coastal surveillance.

We also have better solutions than the entire removal of all judicial supervision of administrative action. We believe in a simple, one-tier straightforward practical application of judicial review which avoids the complications, costs and the very doubtful constitutionality of the government's proposals. We have solutions in the international field, which we believe we can far better implement, with Indonesia and other countries, and we recognise that this is a question not only of source countries but also the need to find cooperative arrangements to deal with those people who are assessed as not having refugee status. About a third of people currently in Australian detention facilities are people who have been screened out as not having legitimate claims, but we cannot find cooperative solutions to return them to their homelands. These require the same kind of international and cooperative actions.

So for those people who are concerned that there is no voice speaking for those who are dispossessed and needy in our community, do not be afraid; the Australian Labor Party has not let that torch burn low. But we do face a situation where the government no longer holds to a piece of legislation which was so intolerable that no political party could approve it. We now go forward committed to a process which is backed broadly on a bipartisan track with the Labor Party making constructive suggestions and commitments to the Australian community about how some of these issues should be better dealt with.

Let me conclude with this: there have been some unfortunate things said in the wake of this debate. I will comment on only two of the most unfortunate things. Firstly, the parliamentary secretary, Mr Slipper, made a remark suggesting that—and I think the defence minister made remarks in a similar vein—amongst the people who are coming on these boats are probably Afghani terrorists. As I understand it, the briefings provided to the opposition leader give no succour to that claim and I think it simply inflames community division at a time when we need healing.

Secondly, I refer to the comment by the member for Dunkley. Whilst I accept his point that there are issues of priority, he put, I think, a hypothetical question suggesting there was no plausible answer other than to say that he was correct. He said how persecuted can you be if you have accumulated that amount of wealth; in other words, the amount of wealth to pay for your travel to Australia? Any member of the Australian Jewish community would provide an answer to him. There were many people of great wealth in the Nazi state who fled that persecution, some who sought refuge on boats and paid their fares. Anybody who has seen the film the Voyage of the Damned and read the book knows the circumstances of those people who went, under the Nazi terror, from country to country—where no country would admit them—and knows their fate through those circumstances. To suggest that you cannot be persecuted if you have the wealth to pay for your flight is wrong. There is an element of truth in the point that there may be priorities and shades of deserving between those who are waiting. But the simple argument about a queue is one which is entirely self-made.

When Labor was in government and we saw the Tiananmen Square example and we admitted many thousands of Chinese who might have faced torture and repression had they been returned to China, we did not sum that against some notional queue and say that we would provide no succour for the rest waiting in camps. We said that we still had that obligation. We adjusted our program so that we could continue our compassion to those people who were in greatest need. However, we also addressed the need of those who might have faced persecution in their homelands—the students, were they returned.

Much of this is according to our will and how we address these issues—how we plan them and address them. This is not an easy situation. These are not easy debates. As I started out saying, the Australian community does not share a single view as to how these issues ought best be resolved. There is a majority opinion, just as in Athens at the time of its great testing when Socrates took the hemlock, when the Athenians were at the walls, there was little tolerance for those who took an alternative view to the majority view within that city.

But in those times of great testing great resolve is required. For societies that are able to hold themselves together and work together, that resolve pays off in terms of their long-term survival, their unity and their strength, and from that grows real security. Real security also requires security not just against external threats but against the insecurity of unemployment, against the insecurity of those who would seek to obtain health care but cannot, against the insecurity of those who seek education in the public system and find it wanting. Those are all great challenges for us as Australians.
