debateinfo.title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT (EXCISION FROM MIGRATION ZONE) BILL 2001

cognateinfo.title: MIGRATION AMENDMENT (EXCISION FROM MIGRATION ZONE) (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 2001
BORDER PROTECTION (VALIDATION AND ENFORCEMENT POWERS) BILL 2001
MIGRATION AMENDMENT (EXCISION FROM MIGRATION ZONE) (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 2001

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: — There are three bills in this package that we are debating this afternoon: the Migration Amendment (Excision from Migration Zone) Bill 2001, the Migration Amendment (Excision from Migration Zone) (Consequential Provisions) Bill 2001 and the Border Protection (Validation and Enforcement Powers) Bill 2001. The first bill excises some Australian territories from the migration zone. In particular we are referring to the Ashmore and Cartier Islands, Christmas Island and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. The second bill puts forward consequential measures associated with the first bill, and the third bill in this package is a validation of the government's actions in relation to vessels carrying unauthorised arrivals, in particular those unauthorised entrants on the Tampa, and enhanced border protection measures.

speech.para: I think it is important that we actually get a bit of realism into the debate and that some facts be put forward, not just simply some of the myths that have been peddled so far. Firstly, I do not think anybody in this parliament believes that illegals should be offered any sanctuary in this country if, in fact, they are queue jumpers. I think that is a view that both sides of parliament have held for some time. I think it is also a myth to suggest that those on the Labor Party side are anything other than tough on this sort of measure. But we also believe that it has to be tempered with compassion and therefore the comments that have been made in this place about the reasons why Labor would not support the original bill with reference to border protection are simply myths that are being peddled not only in this place but also, unfortunately, on talkback radio and in other places—and I will come to that in a moment.

Let us get down to the facts. In the last 10 years, 13,000 illegal boat people have endeavoured to get to this country. In the last five years—that is, under the present Howard government—that number is 11,000. All of a sudden, three months out from an election, we find that the government is moved to do something about it. We find the government moved to put in place border protection legislation, or at least legislation under that broad rhetoric. We find the government moved to send one-third of the Australian Defence Force's naval assets to Christmas Island.

What are those assets that got dispersed up there? It is interesting to have a look at them. We are talking about illegal boat people coming in leaky boats—and what do we send? We send one FFG7 class guided missile frigate with two Seahawk S70B helicopters—that is, the HMAS Newcastle; we send two Anzac class frigates, the HMAS Arunta and the HMAS Warramunga; we send one supply ship fleet oiler, the HMAS Westralia; and we send three P3C Orion maritime surveillance aircraft. I remind you that that was after the event. That was after Tampa.After the people were picked up and put on the Tampa we sent in the Navy. What did we do before that? We put the SAS on board the Tampa to make sure that the people did not jump overboard. We sent all sorts of other defence assets to Christmas Island to make the place safe—safe from what? That is still to be determined.

Whilst on this side of the House the bills that have been presented by the government this time around are acceptable, I think it is a little difficult to swallow in this environment and with this timetable that the government for three weeks has put so many naval assets and other assets of the Australian Defence Force on Christmas Island and in the immediate environment at a cost estimated at $110 million—for three weeks! That is not the cost associated with the initial approach in dealing with the Tampa refugees; that is after the event—$110 million to do that. What happens when the three weeks are up—and I think that that is probably towards the end of this week. What is going to happen then? Are we going to see the defence resource base again whittled down? Are we going to see moneys that have not been allocated within the defence budget going to extending the naval vessels operating off Christmas Island? I dare say that, if the election happened to be called, they might be kept out there for a bit longer. This is the government being tough.

But even with those resources up there, guess what? More boats are still getting through. They were found on Ashmore Reef even after we had all of these naval resources there. There is a better way, and Labor has proposed that better way. We have said that not for just three weeks of the year but for 52 weeks of the year we need to have a cop on the beat. We need a maritime policeman. Labor has proposed—in fact, we put the policy out nearly two years ago—a coastguard; an Australian Coast Guard with a fleet of vessels and with intelligence gathering that can meet the contingency.

We have said that we offer a better plan for being tough on illegals and cracking down on boat people. But we have also said that we have to have a better relationship with our region—particularly with Indonesia. We have suggested that, if, as has been speculated, many of these people are emerging from Indonesia on their way to Australia, we need to have a better relationship with that country so that they do something about it. What did this government do? They sent the three amigos up there—the Minister for Defence, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs—to talk to the Indonesian government. What did we get out of it? Nothing.

We ended up with the Prime Minister coming in here and saying—when Labor had reservations about the original Border Protection Bill—that we did not need to have safe havens for those people to be sent to; rather, they simply should be towed out in their leaky boats to international waters and left there. Then, amazingly, when the Border Protection Bill did not get up—because we pointed out the legal problems that were there and some of the concerns that Labor had about the original bill—suddenly we found the Prime Minister sending the Minister for Defence to Nauru to negotiate safe haven. Then, of course, we got the Border Protection (Validation and Enforcement Powers) Bill 2001, which has come in under the guise of the old Border Protection Bill, but is not the same bill as was here two weeks ago. It does not matter how often those in the government protest and say that Labor should have supported that original bill. The fact is that this is a different bill. If they wanted to test us again, why was the original one not brought back in?

When some cool rational heads in the Labor Party got their minds around that hastily crafted bit of nonsense that was the Border Protection Bill—with 40 minutes warning given and asked, `Will you support this or not?'—even on a cursory examination we recognised that there was no way anyone could support what was in it. And we have now found that the government agreed. Indeed, the government agreed to such an extent that it changed the bill. The original bill sought to override any other law in Australia. Is that in this bill now? No, it is not—it has gone. The original bill bestowed open-ended immunities to the civil and criminal law. Is that there now? No, it has gone. This is a different bill altogether. The original bill posed no impediment to somebody wanting to tow an unsafe vessel out to sea. That has gone too, because cooler heads prevailed— and it is about time.

We have offered bipartisan support right through this. There has been nonsense suggesting that we have not supported the government on immigration bills. Certainly, according to the advice I have—and according to my memory of discussions in the shadow ministry—the original Border Protection Bill was the only one we did not support. Now, here it is in a revamped form that we find we can support. So let us not get carried away with some of these views that are being peddled around this place that the Border Protection (Validation and Enforcement Powers) Bill 2001 is completely the same as the original Border Protection Bill. It is not.

I repeat: we need a coastguard to deal with this, with a cop on the beat for 52 weeks of the year. We need to have an improved relationship with our region, particularly Indonesia, Malaysia and other adjacent countries, so that we can tackle this problem—not just now, not just two months out from an election, not just when another group of boat people happen to have arrived at Christmas Island, Ashmore Reef or wherever it might be. We need a genuine bipartisan approach in dealing with this issue.

No-one wants to see illegals jump the queue. I genuinely think that we in this place, as members of parliament, have many people coming to our offices on a regular basis on immigration issues—the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs knows because we all make representations to him about them—and we know that there are genuine people who want to come to this country. It is true that we take our fair share of people under the refugee category—there is no doubt about that. Equally, there is no doubt that there is a sentiment in the Australian community that suggests we have to take a stand on that, and that is what this legislation is about. But, at the same time, let us not allow elements of this debate, particularly about racial issues, to meld into what we are talking about. There are genuine concerns. The other day the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition, when we talked about the issues associated with those dreadful events last week in New York, made the point about the Muslim community—that is, the religious community or people from Middle Eastern background—

talk.start.para: —Every time.

—Each time, as the minister says, that view was made. We have to ensure that the community cohesion in this country which we have all worked so hard over a long period of time to develop and preserve is sustained. We cannot allow the argument about the potential for terrorists to be on some of these boats to be confused. I note that the Australian today took exception to the honourable member for Fisher, Mr Slipper, when he said that there was an undeniable linkage between boat people and terrorists. Yet when asked to support his allegations, Mr Slipper said, `Many of these illegals come from Afghanistan.' Yes, they do; that is dead right. They are fleeing the Taliban regime which harbours terrorist leader Osama bin Laden. Undeniable linkage? Only in Mr Slipper's mind, and that is dead right.

speech.para: We have to be careful not to inflame some of the concerns in the Australian community which exist because of what happened last week. We have to be careful not to inflame and incite racial tensions in Australia where we have a cohesive society and over a long period of time have developed the view that we have a multinational society.

In this legislation there is an opportunity to do something about the issues of people-smuggling and border protection, but the only way to sustain this for the future is by having Coastguard protection for 52 weeks of the year. Let the Navy and the other defence assets get on with the job that they are supposed to do—that is, protect Australia in all other ways. We need a better national and international approach to this problem, particularly along with our regional neighbours, so that we can all tackle this issue head on.

talk.start.para: —Originally I did not intend to speak in this debate but there were one or two remarks by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs during question time which provoked me to intervene. Given that it is the government's desire that this legislation pass through the chamber as quickly as possible and that we are prepared to facilitate that, I apologise to others on this side of the House who, if I had not spoken, might have had either a lengthier time in which to speak or a chance to speak.

speech.para: There were one or two remarks by the minister which I thought were particularly graceless. Those remarks went to our motivation in agreeing to support all this legislation and legislation in the other chamber. His remarks were graceless to the extent that he indicated that our motivation to support this legislation was a product of expediency and not of concern for the national interest and that our previous determinations had been based on expediency and not on concern for the national interest. In no case has our position in any way, shape or form been based on that at any point in time.

The bill I particularly want to speak to in this cognate debate is the Border Protection (Validation and Enforcement Powers) Bill 2001. We have had now two opportunities to debate in this chamber a border protection bill: during the latter stages of the last period of sitting and today. The circumstances in which we debated these two bills are as similar as chalk and cheese. The bills themselves bear no resemblance beyond the title. The Border Protection (Validation and Enforcement Powers) Bill 2001 that we are debating today is a bill that would have been passed by this chamber during that last sitting had it been the bill that was offered to us at that point in time. We would have passed this bill because it is in the national interest. It is in the national interest of all Australians to have a decent migration program properly defended by its legality. It is in the national interest of all Australians to have our borders effectively protected. It is in the national interest of all Australians that our generous attitude towards refugees is not undermined by people who seek to flout that generosity by placing themselves ahead of others in the queue who are determined by an orderly process to be more deserving. These are all positions which ought to be commonly agreed in this nation and commonly agreed in this parliament.

There is one side in this chamber that struggles for bipartisanship; there is another side that struggles for advantage. That process was never more clearly indicated than in the handling of this. The original border protection legislation was, I do believe, cobbled together for political advantage in the Prime Minister's department, not in the department from which this particular bill emanates. The suggestion was made during question time today—while he did not name me directly, I believe that he was aiming his remarks at me—that we were implying that this bill was weaker, that therefore we would support it and that this was sending a signal to those concerned to organise this illegal trafficking in human beings that they were advantaged by some process going on in this House. They are not advantaged. This bill is being supported because it is legal, because it is workable and because it will be effective. The reason it is legal, workable and effective is that the objectionable features of the previous bill which made it ineffective have been removed.

One of the ironies of this legislation is that it contains an enormously extensive array of amendments related to the Tampa—and other ships which have been intercepted since—to protect those officers from any acts that may have been performed in the course of those persons on the Tampa being removed by the Royal Australian Navy to Nauru. As I indicated in the chamber several weeks ago, if the government had wished such legislation to be put in place at that point in time to protect their interests, they would have had it that night. I indicated it to the Prime Minister. I indicated it in this chamber. If they had wanted that coverage they could have had it that night. It was obvious to all of us in this chamber that the way in which that situation would resolve itself would involve, at some point in time, folk being removed from the Tampa and taken elsewhere. We asked one thing only: safe haven. When we asked for safe haven, we were mocked. The Prime Minister mocked us in question time. But he was making it up as he went along, and the next day he did it: he negotiated safe haven with a couple of countries and ultimately required protection for those engaged in the process—the transfer of those from the Tampa there.

The Prime Minister knew he would never order the Tampa out of Australian waters. The captain was not a semi-piratical captain operating a bumboat; he happened to be an entirely respectable captain from one of the greatest lines operating at the moment in the seas. He had just performed a task in which we had vectored him into a rescue operation. He was sitting offshore with a reasonable grievance, and that grievance was not going to be assuaged by his being ordered out of our territory with nowhere to go. That sort of behaviour would have, had it occurred and been marked internationally, seen us in discredit for years. The government was not going to risk that—and rightly so; the government should not have risked that. But they required a conclusion, and that conclusion we were prepared to give them. We made amply clear to the government that whatever they needed they would get in a bipartisan way.

The government achieved their objectives by putting in place an illegal, unworkable bill. They successfully wedged us and massively damaged us. They spurned the bipartisanship they were offered and they got their useful political effect. What they did not get was an enhancement of the reputation of this nation or a solution to the problem. It is extraordinary when you actually read that bill and work out what it could have meant. These things are unlikely to have happened, but they could conceivably have happened legally. If somebody in officialdom had taken it into their head to sink the Sydney to Hobart yacht race fleet, they could have done it. That was something that was open to them to do. It was also open to them to take from our waters a boat and sink it. That bill gave authority to Commonwealth officials beyond the authority that is given to a front-line soldier in attack mode in wartime. It gave them that coverage. It gave them more coverage than that for a policeman in hot pursuit of a gunman who has just shot someone and is scarpering to evade the consequences of the law. It gave them more authority in civil law than is given a policeman in that set of circumstances anywhere in Australia. It had a clause which overrode all legislation and it sought to exclude the operation of the legislation from the jurisdiction of the High Court. It was an extraordinary piece of legislation and could not be supported. The problem for us was that we could never make that understood in the Australian community. That was the hope of the Prime Minister, and his hopes have been realised as far as that is concerned.

But we have to ignore all those consequences and stand on this side of the House for good law, and what we have got back is good law—good law that ensures that we are not a soft touch, good law that does not breach any of the reasonable constraints that ought to be on Commonwealth officials when they are exercising Commonwealth authority, good law that protects the position of those officials who have been engaged in the transport of people to Nauru in recent times, good law that recognises that ultimately the High Court has authority over all our legal system and that it has a role in making those determinations. We have in place before us in the border protection legislation good law.

Previously, we had legislation that was cobbled together in the Prime Minister's department and not discussed in the Liberal Party caucus. When I went to see the Prime Minister, the legislation was slung contentiously across the table to me with a demand that the opposition support it. Unfortunately for the Prime Minister, when the legislation hit the table, it fell open at that clause that has now disappeared from this law—it is not to be found in this bill—which said, `This law overrides all other laws in operation in the Commonwealth.' The legislation fell open at that particular clause. The Prime Minister picked it up, and I said to him, `We won't be supporting that. But, because you want this voted on quickly and facilitated, of course we'll be in that. We'll be in it for a debate, but we'll not be in it for passage.' That clause has disappeared. This is in fact not really a border protection bill, despite its title; it is an omnibus bill of good reforms to the Migration Act. That is what it basically is—a series of good reforms to the Migration Act that strengthen our borders, and therefore we support it, as we support the other bills because they strengthen the regime and they do so in a reasonably humanitarian way.

I appreciate the fact that, before he chose to introduce this legislation into the parliament and indeed into his party room, the minister concerned actually approached my office and my colleagues and gave us advance knowledge of it so that we could properly discuss this in our caucus processes. I acknowledge that he did that. It was a belated gesture, but we think it is the way in which all of this sort of legislation ought to be handled. It ought to be handled that way because in this place we all have a mutual interest in the respectability of the migration program. We are not a country that can operate without migrants; we are not now and we never will be. When we look at the ageing of our population and the dependency ratios that are developing, we are always going to need a well-calibrated migration program.

The truth is that, these days, the societies that succeed in becoming good knowledge economies are those societies which exploit their hospitality and their ability to offer good opportunities to people of very high skills in new technologies, and the competition internationally for those people is now manifold around the globe. If you go through Silicon Valley and see the enormous success which has driven the United States dominance in new technologies, what you will see is the clever usage made by American society—albeit anarchically—of people of great skill from elsewhere around the globe. That is what has driven the creation of a massive power of the United States in new technologies.

If we want to be the same, we have to be the sort of economy, the sort of society, that openly welcomes people of those skills and encourages them to be here. If we get them, we succeed. If we do not, we fail. That is why it is enormously important that we have an effective migration program. An effective migration program cannot be defended in this society if people are frightened of it, if people feel that they are being economically disadvantaged instead of economically advanced, if people feel that their good offices, their good intentions, are being undermined by what is being done by those who would seek to breach migration laws.

This has been a hard thing to deal with over the years. It was hard for us. The Labor Party put in place mandatory detention for asylum seekers when we were in office because we recognised that we could not afford to be perceived around the globe as a soft touch if we were going to keep the integrity of our migration program in place. But we understood one thing absolutely when we were in office, and it was this: there is no solution to this problem that is not national and there is no solution to this problem that does not have an international component. Unless we are in the business of persuading others that we have a common problem, we are not going to resolve this problem. The key to the resolution of that problem starts—does not end, but starts—in the countries in our immediate neighbourhood, which are the point of embarkation here.

There are many reasons why there has been a surge of people seeking to enter illegally via sea. Not least of the reasons is that our relationship with our nearest neighbour has fallen apart. There was a degree of inevitability, in relation to the affairs which occurred on Timor, of that happening, but there was no inevitability that it should be sustained. It is incumbent upon Australian governments to assign top priority in Australia's international relationships to the region around us and, even when we have a difficulty, not to run away from it. We should take the opportunities that are presented to us for a constant conversation and, when we are handling a problem associated with the immigration laws of this country in which they are engaged, we should conduct the diplomacy on a basis of mutual respect, care and caution and we should not brace them with a megaphone. One of the most shameful things in this whole exercise has been the fact that the original cause of all this border protection legislation lay in the fact that the Prime Minister and the government could not engage in such a good conversation with our nearest neighbour.

We need a simple thing in the neighbourhood. It is the sort of thing that we had when we were threatened some time ago with a surge of people who were refugees from Vietnam and the sort of thing which in a different way we have actually achieved in relation to China—that is, we get an acceptance from those in our region that, if they are the point of embarkation, everybody who comes here goes back. Ultimately that is the deterrent: everybody who comes here goes back. If that occurs, then it is not worth while anyone coming here. But we are never going to get that unless at the other end of the game they have the capacity to be confident that people who are processed through refugee camps in their areas are going to have somewhere to go that is not there. Therefore, the quid pro quo, what we have to do in return, apart from giving them all assistance in regard to their processes, is to agree to take our fair share within the cap that is there for our refugee program. That is what we did with the Vietnamese and that is what we need to do here. There is a very slow processing of UNHCR folk through the camps now in Indonesia.

The consequence of all of this is that we have had the rate of illegal migration to this country of some 1,000 a year when we were in office bump up to over 4,000; there has been an absolute surge. There are many reasons for that, as I have said, but I have been outlining one of the most important ones. There have been 136 boats come in the course of the last three years. The government, five weeks before the calling of an election, chose to take umbrage at the 137th and 138th and 139th. Tough timing vis-a-vis the election; pretty ordinary prior to then. Now we find a situation which I hope most sincerely deters, and I believe it should. I believe anybody now sitting down and looking rationally at the laws and the processes we have in place knows this: they are not going to get here, should they attempt to get here illegally. And that message should go through to them very emphatically.

But there is no doubt at all that, in making this thing up on the run, we have got ourselves into a diabolically expensive situation, not least in the Navy. The way that the Navy is being utilised at the moment is not what a navy is for. The Navy is a peak defence organisation capable of operating in highly lethal environments and delivering death and destruction upon our enemies. That is the purpose of the Navy, the same as it is the purpose of the Army and the Air Force. It requires ships of considerable capacity and crews of great skill in order to be able to do that. They are not patrol officers, they are not policemen; and ships that do those things are not cheap to operate, and never will be.

We need what we have been advocating for the last couple of years. And we do not just advocate it for illegal migrants; we advocate it as a mechanism for dealing with the proper monitoring of our quarantine requirements and our fisheries and for the interception of illicit drugs coming into this country. We need a coastguard. We are a maritime nation: we need a 52 weeks of the year operation. You cannot afford to operate the Navy on this basis for 52 weeks of the year without wrecking the defence budget. We need purpose designed ships, auxiliaries to the Defence Force, commanded by naval officers but being essentially civilian or policing in character; able to be staffed, apart from the command arrangements, by others not necessarily in the Navy, not in peacetime but in wartime. That is what this country needs now. It is the second leg, if you like, of the two additional things that we would propose—I have already talked about the diplomatic relations. I hope the government will see its way clear to change its mind now that it has experienced the consequences of using the Navy for so long on this. I hope also to lay down here that we support good laws, we support good deterrents and we do not seek to wedge on migration matters. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I can only speak for five minutes on the Migration Amendment (Excision from Migration Zone) Bill 2001 because of what has happened: the debate has been cut off, unfortunately. I had very much to say and I had a lot of material prepared that I wanted to put before the parliament. I will be, it appears, the only member opposing this legislation.
—The rest of us were gagged!

—The honourable member mentions that the rest of us were gagged. There were people gagged on both sides of the parliament. It is a disgrace that in these matters people are gagged and are not allowed to express their point of view. I noticed that in the Senate Senator Marise Payne broke down and cried when she was talking about this issue.

speech.para: If ever there was legislation which will not deal with the issues, then the Migration Amendment (Excision from Migration Zone) Bill must take the cake. It is one of the silliest pieces of legislation ever put before this House and it actually makes a mockery of us as a nation. Imagine this: sections of our own country, parts of Australia, are going to the excised, pushed out and told, `The laws on migration do not apply here.' What other country has ever done anything like this? Can you imagine anything crazier and more absurd? Perhaps we should excise Tasmania and make laws that say, `The laws of Australia do not apply to Tasmania in terms of certain agricultural laws, or certain other laws.' What an absurd way to proceed to deal with a problem.

The Prime Minister said, in answer to my question today, that we are going to deal with the issue of making equity between those who are coming by boat and those who are processed overseas, because we do not need a different set of criteria. Minister, if that is what you want, let us legislate for a uniform set of criteria that we all agree on, not this ad hoc and absurd proposal whereby sections of our own country are excised and taken out of the migration law. Just because they have managed to push the Labor Party into agreeing with it, does that mean that what is being done here is right or that it is sensible? It is a nonsense proposition.

The bill does not even explain what is going to happen when these people are processed under the UNHCR. All right, the criteria are going to be tougher, but that does not mean that nobody will get through. What about the ones that get through, the ones that are actually classified, even under the tougher criteria, as refugees? What happens to them? Are we going to say, `Christmas Island is part of Australia but for the purposes of the Migration Act it is not part Australia. We are processing them under the UNHCR criteria but we are not going to let even the ones that pass these tougher criteria stay in Australia, we are going to send them off somewhere'? Is that what we are going to do? And if we are going to accept them under the tougher criteria, why doesn't the minister say so? Why doesn't he tell us what is going to happen to these people? There has never been such absurd legislation before this House.

The other point I mentioned earlier today in my question to the Prime Minister is about the Taliban, that terrible regime that we are all against, the supporter of terrorists and the regime which has made an outrageous interpretation of the Koran and of Islamic faith and which has ended up absolutely against all civilised concepts of human rights and against its own people, the Afghani people. Millions of Afghanis have been forced out of Afghanistan and a few of them—less than one in a thousand—have ended up in Australia. And what do we say? `We are against the Taliban regime; we will support the Americans in whatever they want to do against the Taliban regime, as we supported them against Saddam Hussein.' And I support that. But I say this: what about a bit of consistency? What about saying that people who have escaped these regimes need some of our sympathy and some of our concern? I ask the minister: how many Afghanis are you going to accept from the camps? Why don't you show some goodwill at least in that area? Why don't you show some more goodwill? Why don't you increase the quota of Afghanis? Why don't you increase the quota of refugees from overseas, if you are really genuine about dealing with the refugee problem? But, no, you want to reduce the overseas quota just because some people are arriving in boats.

I put it to you that if you want some consistency and equality in terms of the criteria then, rather than excising Christmas Island and these other islands, why don't we have a debate in this House about what the criteria ought to be and make them uniform criteria? But instead of that we have two sets of criteria, we are going to have part of Australia excised and we are going to say that this is a solution to a problem. I tell you what it is a solution to: it is a solution to political problems. It is simply an ad hoc attempt close to an election to deal with an issue when in fact we should be dealing with this issue in a much better way.

I have run out of time because I have only being given a few minutes. It is unfair that the only person opposing this bill in this chamber should be given such limited time. But other members wanted to speak from both sides who also have some concerns and they have expressed their concerns to me privately. Although there will be one vote against this bill, I can tell you there are many members in this chamber who share the concerns on the issues that I have raised.
Question resolved in the affirmative, Dr Theophanous dissenting.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Motion (by Mr Ruddock) put:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a third time.

subdebate.1.para: Question resolved in the affirmative, Dr Theophanous dissenting.
Bill read a third time.

subdebate.1.para: Consideration resumed from 18 September, on motion by Mr Ruddock:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr RUDDOCK
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I might just make a few brief remarks in closing the debate on this particular bill, and I want to do so in this context: these three migration bills are a package, along with the three other bills before the parliament. One relates to redefining elements of the refugee convention; another deals with access to judicial review; and a third deals with class actions initiated to enable some people to remain in Australia, notwithstanding the fact that they have exhausted all other remedies, when they join together for the purposes of having a matter before the courts on which bridging visas can then be applied for. We have 40,000 people on bridging visas, of which I think 5,000 or 6,000 are participating in class actions, and others using litigation for that purpose.

speech.para: Judicial review has had a very significant impact on the way in which the refugee convention is interpreted in Australia. That interpretation is one which is widened by individual cases. People make the point that we win most cases. That does not obviate decision makers from having to follow the precedents that are established. Once they are established, you have a situation where Australia, in relation to dealing with asylum claims, has a different regime operating from what you see overseas. I will make available to honourable members an article that has been written by a Canadian in relation to exactly the same impact that judicial review has had in Canada and the United States of America.

The fact is that you have two forms of refugee conventions: the jurisprudential model in a place like Australia, which is much wider in its coverage; and a much more rigorously enforced refugee convention administered by decision makers who use the UNHCR handbook for decision making. The fact is that we have seen the courts able to do this largely of their own remit. They have achieved an outcome whereby some groups arriving in Australia have very high levels of acceptance, not because they necessarily have better claims but simply because those claims are made in Australia. When you see 14 per cent of Afghani claimants being accepted in Indonesia and 84 per cent being accepted here, it makes the point very powerfully.

One of the reasons for the overall scheme that we are now implementing is to make it clear that those rules are no longer operating. People will be determined under a system that operates in exactly the same way as it does in Indonesia. The bill that I am addressing makes it very clear that those who are going to be resettled in Australia, if they are found to be refugees, will not get a better outcome than if they had had their claims assessed in Indonesia—it will be a lesser outcome. That is for the purpose of sending that very message—

talk.start.para: —Why?

—Because we are wanting people to avoid those hazardous, life threatening and life taking voyages and to have their claims considered by the UNHCR in Indonesia or Pakistan, rather than having them considered here, where they know they will get different outcomes. That is the reason.
(Mrs Gash)—Order! Messages will be put through the chair.

—It is to send a very clear message that there is a right way and there is a wrong way. We have six bills that need to be dealt with in two weeks. They will all be in the Senate by tomorrow afternoon. The test of genuineness in relation to dealing with these issues, which are part of an integrated package of measures, if you are serious, is whether these matters will be before the Senate and dealt with before it rises. That will be the test. That may require a little courage.
—Are you saying there are no more parliamentary sittings?

—I am saying we want them through in these two weeks. The point I am making is that that may require a little courage in dealing with the Senate. It means that, if the numbers are there to get the legislation through, the legislation ought to carry. If somebody is not prepared to use the numbers to get that legislation through, there are some consequences.
—Do not fret.
—I am not threatening. I am simply saying—
—I said, `Do not fret,' not, `Do not threat.'
—Order! Minister, through the chair.
—I am not fretting, either. I assume the member is indicating that the opposition will work with us to give us that outcome.
—Bipartisan—which is what you do not want.

—No, it is exactly what I want. I have been seeking these outcomes in the national interest. I believe very strongly in what needs to be done. We are dealing with a very different situation to the ones we have seen before. They are different because when we were dealing with the Vietnamese boat people, as they were described, very few came to Australia. They were always detained in countries well away from Australia. Asian countries are saying, `We are no longer prepared to detain people for you.' That is what they are saying. They were prepared to do it for us in relation to the Vietnamese, and they felt they got left holding the baby. They are not prepared to do it now. China was different because nobody was going to get asylum claims up under our system as it was then operating. If they had been able to get asylum claims up, the result would have been very different. The snake heads would not have been deterred if they had found a way through that system.

speech.para: What has happened in relation to these movements is that these people understand how the refugee convention is operating; they understand its liberal interpretation here. They understand the extent to which benefits are more generously paid. As the Indonesians have said to me over and over again, it is the sugar. You get better outcomes if you are able to get in a boat and get to Australia than if you are languishing in the most appalling circumstances in Pakistan, Iran or wherever. I saw a program the other night—and I want to conclude my remarks on this point—on Afghanistan. I looked at the women and children who were starving in the streets, picking up the scraps and trying to get food out of them on which they could survive. If they went over the border into Pakistan, they would not suddenly end up with $16,000 to pay a people smuggler.

Next at risk would be the women at risk program, where we single out specifically women and children for resettlement. What we are seeing is a movement of middle-class people who are able to raise substantial amounts of money. Very often, if they are Afghani, they have been able to earn large amounts of money in situations of safety and security long before they get on the boats. That is the reality.

talk.start.para: —Some of them sell everything.

—They may sell all that they have to bring a whole family. If they are going to pay $100,000 dollars, that may well be. I tell you, the women and children have nothing. Let me just say—and it is a very potent point—that the boat that was apprehended in Cambodia by Cambodian police had 243 people on board who were going to claim to be Afghani when they got to Australia. They were opening up a new route. Smugglers had moved from Indonesia to Cambodia to embark upon sailing vessels across the Gulf of Thailand and through the Indonesian archipelago to Australia directly. Their first effort was thwarted by the Cambodian police. Then we started to test who they were. We were working with the police. Twenty-five per cent of them were on Pakistani passports; they were Pakistani citizens. The balance had in large part Afghani passports with endorsements that enabled them to live in Pakistan. One hundred and seventy-four of the 243 people voluntarily went back—because IOM only removes people voluntarily—to Pakistan rather than staying in Cambodia, where they would have been safe and secure.
—How many Afghans were on the Tampa?

—We will find out about that, but we know that a number of people on the Tampa have already asked if they can be sent back to Pakistan. I do not know how many—I think a fairly small number at this stage. They have already said, `Our preference is to go back rather than wait on Nauru.' We will find out about that in time. A number of other points were made in relation to the border protection legislation. This border protection legislation is wider in its remit, wider in terms of what it achieves and more important than the former bill.
—It is not stupid like the former one was.

—No, the former one dealt with a very specific situation. We wanted to cover a wider range of situations, and the opposition said no. It is dressing it up on a whole lot of other bases, but the fact is that you did say no.

speech.para: Some issues have been raised about costs. Yes, it costs a lot at the moment in relation to the arrangements that have been put in place to monitor our borders, but not as much as it costs if people are allowed into Australia and have to be dealt with under the procedures and the detention arrangements and ultimately have to receive benefits under the arrangements that are in place. Just to give you an idea, a boat of 350 people or so arriving in Australia and processed under those arrangements costs in the order of $50 million. Take two boats of 700 people, and we are looking at over $100 million. Essentially the point is that, yes, it is costing a deal of money in relation to Nauru, and something in relation to the Navy, but they are costs that would have been incurred in other ways if we were not dealing with these issues with the determination that we are.

I simply make the point that this is a package of measures that can have an impact. I am not going to say that there is not a need for more. I will have some more legislation for next week. All of them are essential, and I would hope that, as the shadow minister has indicated, we will have cooperation to get all of these measures through before the parliament rises at the end of next week.

Bill read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Amendment Bill 2001 amends the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Act 2000 to provide extra funding, as announced in the Australians Working Together package released on 2 April. The bill provides $8.6 million over three years for early intervention strategies involving communities, industry and education providers, in order to encourage indigenous students to complete year 12, to complete apprenticeships and to pursue job opportunities. It is estimated that around 1,600 students will be assisted between 2002 and 2004 through expenditure of $6 million to support development and implementation of a partnerships approach and customised service delivery. Another $2.6 million will be used to provide business support for vocational learning for indigenous secondary school students. I am advised that some 40 communities and several hundred students are expected to be involved. It is proposed that there will be a range of options available, such as entry level skills training, VET in schools programs, mentoring and individual case management, and that communities may use more than one of these approaches when deciding what their particular needs are—and we welcome that.

speech.para: The bill also provides $2.86 million over three years to offset the impact on non-profit Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations of changes to the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986. The changes came into force in April this year and restrict the eligibility of charities and other non-profit organisations to tax concessions on no more than $30,000 worth of benefit per employee. The funds from the Commonwealth through this bill are designed to help indigenous non-profit organisations continue to offer competitive salary packaging, which is necessary to attract appropriately qualified staff. I am advised that there are 145 non-profit indigenous organisations currently receiving funding under the Indigenous Education Strategic Initiatives Program. The estimate of the likely cost to these organisations of the changes to FBT legislation was based on a study commissioned by the Department of Health and Aged Care and by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. The study found that the FBT changes, if not offset by additional funding, were likely to bring about staff cuts and/or program restrictions. For that reason we support this particular portion of the legislation.

I cannot speak on a bill dealing with indigenous education without raising once again my concern about the recent decline in tertiary education participation by indigenous students—and I know that this is a concern shared by the honourable member for Banks. Progress in this area has been slow. In 1991 indigenous students made up 0.9 per cent of higher education students. By 1994 this had grown to 1.0 per cent. By 1998 it had reached 1.2 per cent. So growth was slow but steady. It is with alarm, then, that we note that the latest DETYA figures show that in the year 2000 the proportion of indigenous students in higher education fell back to 1.1 per cent. Participation of indigenous Australians in vocational education and training also fell in the year 2000—from 3.1 per cent in 1999 to 3.0 per cent. So we have seen an across-the-board fall in indigenous participation in post-secondary education and training, and that is a tragedy for those indigenous Australians who have missed out.

In response to a series of Senate estimates questions asked in June this year, DETYA advised that in 2000 the number of indigenous students enrolled in higher education was 7,350, or 651 fewer than in 1999. It also advised that the number of commencing students was 3,510, which was 630 fewer than in 1999. DETYA said in its written response, `We are unable to confirm the reason for the decline and are undertaking further research into the issue.' I would ask the minister what that further research has revealed and whether he can deny that his own punitive changes to Abstudy provide the only valid explanation for this significant reversal of a trend of increasing participation that extends back as far as records go.

In 1998 the minister announced changes to Abstudy that, he said, would `open up opportunities for indigenous students to access a wider range of assistance to achieve better education and employment outcomes'. He dismissed claims that the cuts in support to mature age students would lead to declines in the number of indigenous students, and the minister insisted that the changes were budget neutral. Now we have information from his own department that shows that the critics were right and the minister was wrong: the total number of indigenous tertiary students in receipt of Abstudy fell by 1,568 between 1999 and 2000, when the changes were implemented; and expenditure on tertiary Abstudy fell by more than $5 million. So much for budget neutrality! Of the $8.6 million in extra program funds provided by this bill, $5 million has already been taken from Abstudy. As I said before, the opposition will be supporting this bill, but we would appreciate more honesty and integrity from the government—and in particular from the minister—in dealing with the serious problems facing indigenous Australians.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to rise in this House to speak on the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Amendment Bill 2001. It is an issue that is fairly dear to my heart. It goes back many years, I dare say, right back to my own school days—and that now is a long time ago. There is a disadvantage in the Aboriginal community, and the disadvantage stems from lack of education. I have never doubted that for many years. I recall very clearly when I was a high school student in MacLean talking to the headmaster of the public primary school about Aboriginal children. That man was a very dedicated schoolteacher, and he commented that `we have them until 6th grade and then we lose them'. That is a statement that I think has been true for a long time. It was certainly true then and it is still true today. If you look closely at the figures of Aboriginal students who finish tertiary education, who finish high school and get training in DETYA, you will find that the percentages are way below those of the rest of the community. This is an issue I think that successive governments have tried to overcome. If you look at some of the funding that goes towards this education, I dare say that it could be said that governments have positively discriminated in favour of Aboriginal students—and yet we still have not received achieved the desired results.

speech.para: I have a school in my electorate at Baryulgil, which is a large Aboriginal community, and the state government has put every conceivable teaching aid that you might imagine in that school. There are three teachers there for 24 students, and that is way above the average that you would see at any other school. Unfortunately, out of 24 students, some days there are only four students at school. It is an attitudinal problem, and I think that somehow we have to get through to the parents of Aboriginal children the importance of education. I recall—and I suppose many of those my age would recall similar things—what my parents said to me every day before I went to school: `Remember, you must get a good education.' They never had the opportunity. They never went past 6th grade at school because they did not have the opportunity. Yet in my generation my parents drummed it into me, `Make sure that you get a good education.' I am not just saying this of the Aboriginal community; I think in some sectors of the wider community the attitude is that we are not impressing upon young people the importance of education.

When you do not have a good education, you have no chance of getting a job in the community that you might want. That leads, of course, to unemployment, to alcohol abuse, and to assault and all the attendant social problems that frequently occur in the community. Trying to address this by extra funding is one thing, but it is not just a matter of funding, as I have said. We have to try and address it even further than that by way of attitudes—something that is absolutely necessary. Obviously, some people succeed. A very good example of that in this parliament is Senator Aiden Ridgeway. He went to school with my boys at Woodlawn college at Lismore and succeeded. But the trouble is that far too few of those people are managing to succeed. There are very good role models, and maybe we should be using role models to try and encourage young Aboriginal students to do more with the opportunities that exist. There is no country in the world that gives young people in the community the opportunities that Australia gives them. Those opportunities are open to everyone. No matter whether you are Aboriginal or what your ethnic background is, there is free education for all in Australia and every opportunity is given to access it. There are many countries in this world where young people would give anything to have the opportunities that exist in this country.

I support this bill very strongly. But, as I say, money alone will not achieve the results we want to achieve. Somewhere along the line we have to look closely at how we can ensure that students continue in education and then have the opportunities to get some skills and get a job. We have to make sure that they can then join the work force and, as I said, overcome some of the disadvantage that is obvious in those communities.

talk.start.para: —I join with the previous speaker, the honourable member for Page, in indicating the importance of the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Amendment Bill 2001. As someone who has worked on a regular basis with people in indigenous communities, going back to 1975 when I first commenced employment with the Miscellaneous Workers Union, I understand the importance of the lack of opportunity that exists in many indigenous communities around Australia.

speech.para: From growing up in the western suburbs of Sydney, I also understand that one's opportunities in life are very much related to one's educational opportunities. In essence, it comes back to the fundamentals of life. If, in the early years of education, you do not get adequate support in terms of literacy and numeracy, you undermine your fundamental opportunity later in life to proceed with success at school and have the opportunity to complete your schooling and gain access to an apprenticeship or tertiary education. As difficult as that is in some of the outer suburbs of metropolitan Australia, it is even more difficult in the indigenous communities around Australia.

What also concerns me is that, despite our continuing endeavours as a community to support indigenous education and despite the large amounts of money spent both at a Commonwealth and a state level, we have failed to get it right. That effectively means that we have to review what we have done in the past so as to ensure that we learn from our failures and start to guarantee that we get a better return on our investment in indigenous education and guarantee that people start to go beyond year 6, as suggested by the previous speaker, and proceed to the completion of year 10 and, hopefully, the completion of year 12.

In trying to come to terms with indigenous education and targeted assistance, we have to review the method of delivery of education to indigenous communities. One of our weaknesses in the past is that we have failed to appreciate that it is very difficult to take indigenous children out of their communities and expect them to easily adapt to the education system that we and our children are accustomed to. As those who understand indigenous education know, the extended family and family support are of fundamental importance to the indigenous community. If we therefore expect indigenous children to actually grow in their educational opportunities and succeed at school, we have to make sure that the education system is tailored to the needs of those indigenous children.

That means that more and more we not only have to take education into the communities in rural, remote and regional Australia but we also have to make sure that, if we get into a situation where those people are required to leave those indigenous communities to further their education, we guarantee that we provide adequate access to hostels in the major regional and metropolitan areas of Australia and provide a supporting environment which enables those people to easily adjust to their new environment and, more importantly, to go forward on the basis of a wonderful community spirit and sense of support—the key objective being that they settle into those new communities and succeed on the education front. I support the nature of our endeavours as a community to assist our indigenous communities. The key in the first instance is succeeding on the education front. If we succeed on the education front, we will then make progress with respect to jobs and career development, and as a nation we will be better off.

talk.start.para: —The Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Amendment Bill 2001 amends the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Act 2000, firstly, to provide $2.86 million over three years to offset the impact on non-profit Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations of changes to the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986 and, secondly, to provide $8.6 million over three years for early intervention strategies involving communities, industry and education providers to encourage indigenous students to complete year 12, complete apprenticeships and pursue job opportunities.

speech.para: The first purpose of the bill relates to the changes to FBT. The changes came into force in April this year and restrict the eligibility of charities and other non-profit organisations to tax concessions on no more than $30,000 worth of benefit per employee. Benefits above $30,000 per employee will now be liable for FBT at the rate of 48.5 cents in the dollar. The funds from the Commonwealth through this bill are designed to help indigenous non-profit organisations to continue to offer competitive salary packaging which is necessary to attract appropriately qualified staff.

ATSIC and other indigenous organisations preferred a full exemption from FBT for charities and not-for-profit organisations. Instead, a relief package of $43.7 million over four years to Commonwealth agencies including ATSIC was announced on 30 March 2001. The additional $2.86 million in this bill is part of the relief package. The Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs, DETYA, assumes that with access to additional funding organisations will be able to continue to offer competitive salary packaging to professional staff such as teachers and principals.

The estimate of the likely cost to these organisations of the changes to FBT was based on a study commissioned by the Department of Health and Aged Care and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. The study found that FBT changes, if not offset by additional funding, were likely to bring about staff cuts and/or program reductions. During the assessment of the impact of the FBT, 121 education and training organisations receiving Commonwealth funding were surveyed. However, DETYA is not sure how many organisations requested additional funding when applications closed on 31 July 2001. As a result, the opposition, frankly, can have no knowledge whether this was adequate.

I do not think it is widely understood in the general community how much work charitable or not-for-profit organisations do in indigenous communities. As someone who has resided in very remote communities in Australia for the best part of 26 years and having worked for one of these organisations for part of that time, I can say that, without these organisation, services would not be delivered to many parts of Australia and to many Australian citizens, yet they have been chronically underfunded for many years.

The bottom line is that organisations have had to use creative methods to attract staff. As I am sure you are aware, Madam Deputy Speaker Gash, one of the key issues in remote and rural Australia, but particularly in remote Australia, is attracting qualified professional staff. Inevitably, the budgets of those places are so tight that they are unable to provide competitive salary packages. As a result they find it difficult to attract and retain staff. In those circumstances, the people who are being disadvantaged, at great cost to the community in the long run, are Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people; in this case, in Northern Australia. The external costs associated with that are tremendous, yet they have never been quantified and no-one has endeavoured to look at what the cost would be if the organisations that currently carry out that work were not in operation. It is incumbent upon us to recognise that work. Whilst I support this package as proposed by the government today, I am not sure that it is enough. I say to the government that this is something that we want to reconsider in due course, after we have seen the impact of this package on the ability of those organisations to employ and retain staff and to undertake the work for which they have been properly mandated.

The second purpose of the bill is to provide additional funding for indigenous education through an additional $8.6 million for non-Abstudy payments over the period 1 January 2002 to 30 June 2005, with the aim of encouraging 1,600 secondary school students in indigenous communities to complete year 12 and go on to further education. It will also assist 2,300 indigenous secondary education students to undertake vocational education and training. Since 1990, there have been increases in Commonwealth funding for indigenous education, which has continued under the coalition government. However, last year the government included the objective of better literacy and numeracy outcomes and better attendance outcomes for indigenous students as part of the funding arrangements to education providers for the purpose of implementing the government's National Indigenous Literacy and Numeracy Strategy. The launch of the National Indigenous Literacy and Numeracy Strategy in March 2000 was the occasion for the Prime Minister to further reiterate his flawed concept of practical reconciliation.

Practical reconciliation emphasises the government's priority to achieving improved outcomes in education, health and employment and reducing welfare dependency. The Prime Minister has confined the indigenous affairs portfolio to what he labels `practical reconciliation'. By that he means housing, health, employment and education, and dismissing, therefore, what he describes as other irrelevant issues such as rights and social justice. Labor believes that the Howard government's practical reconciliation agenda is a rebadging of what really are basic citizenship rights. In other words, the Howard government believes that people's rights are not important to people's wellbeing in reducing disadvantage or advancing reconciliation. That approach has been criticised by many people nationally and internationally and by indigenous and non-indigenous Australians in all parts of the community, as practical reconciliation really just means providing services that other Australian citizens are entitled to and does not lead to substantive equality.

`Substantive equality' means equality that is real or substantial. It does not mean treating all people in a uniform way, but it acknowledges socioeconomic differences between people and then trying to get equal outcomes. That clearly has not been the objective which has underlined the government's approach. From the proven statistical data concerning indigenous health, housing, education and employment, it is obvious that Australian indigenous people do not have substantive equality. Dr Bill Jonas from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission stated:

quote.para: The current approach of practical reconciliation simply manages the inequality faced by indigenous people. It is insufficient to reduce, let alone overcome, the disadvantage faced.

speech.para: Noel Pearson summed it up by saying:

quote.para: The problems that we are talking about are not simply practical problems that can be solved with good intentions and sufficient funding.

speech.para: But the government has failed even on its own terms of practical reconciliation. We have only to look at education to see that. There has been a fall in indigenous education participation rates over the past few years. In secondary education, school retention and participation for indigenous youth has not improved markedly in recent years. In tertiary education, according to the government's own department, indigenous commencements and enrolments have fallen dramatically in the last year: by 15.2 per cent and 8.1 per cent respectively to either below or just above what they were in 1996.

According to the National Tertiary Education Union, indigenous students now comprise only 1.23 per cent of non-overseas students, the lowest percentage since 1996. That decrease has been linked to the cuts of $38 million made to Abstudy by the Howard government in the 1996 budget for both ATSIC and the ANU. That is the Howard government failing even on its own terms of practical reconciliation. In 1991, indigenous students made up 0.9 per cent of higher education students. By 1994 it had grown to one per cent, and by 1998 it had reached 1.2 per cent. However, DETYA figures show that in 2000 the proportion of indigenous students in higher education fell back to 1.1 per cent. Participation of indigenous Australians in vocational education and training also fell from 3.1 per cent in 1999 to three per cent in 2000.

We have an across-the-board fall in indigenous participation in post-secondary education and training. In response to a series of Senate estimates questions in June this year, DETYA has advised that in 2000 the number of indigenous students enrolled in higher education was 7,350 fewer than in 1999. It also advised that the number of commencing students was 3,510, which was 630 fewer than in 1999. DETYA, in its written response, said:

quote.para: We are unable to confirm the reason for the decline and are undertaking further research into the issue.

speech.para: That is the Howard government failing in one of the key areas of practical reconciliation. Labor programs such as Abstudy have made a significant contribution to improving indigenous education outcomes. Labor is committed to improving indigenous participation in tertiary education across all disciplines and levels of study and it will encourage the recognition and valuing of indigenous knowledge within higher education institutions. Labor believes that indigenous people should be encouraged to enter tertiary education and not be earmarked for vocational education and training, as has occurred under this government and as is borne out by the decreases in tertiary education participation.

Indigenous representation in vocational education and training is primarily in certificate 1 and 2 levels. This means that we run the risk of reverting to the old education paradigm of making indigenous people `good with their hands, but not with their heads'. Of course, nothing could be further from the truth. Indigenous people must be encouraged and assisted in accessing a full range of educational opportunities. The Prime Minister has asked to be judged on the performance of practical reconciliation; by this education measure, he is clearly failing.

It gives me no pleasure to say that, in respect of almost every measure, this government has failed on its own definition of what it believes reconciliation to be about. There are very many examples where I live in the Northern Territory of where the government has failed. Indigenous housing is but another example of that. When I visit communities in my electorate, I see the appalling state of infrastructure, roads, health care and education. Even if you accepted the rhetoric coming out of the Prime Minister's mouth, it has failed. He has not lived up to the promise that he made to the Australian people on the issue of what he referred to as practical reconciliation which, after all, is what every other Australian takes for granted.

We have an obligation to indigenous Australians which has yet to be met. We must recognise that they have a right to equal opportunity and a right to access educational resources. In my electorate of the Northern Territory, not one Aboriginal community has a publicly funded high school. I am talking about some communities of 2,500 people. This government have failed to impose discipline upon themselves and to see that, in terms of providing Aboriginal education, improving Aboriginal education outcomes and employment outcomes, and acknowledging a link between the two, instead of blaming Aboriginal people for poor health, education and employment outcomes, they should assess what the problem really is. The problem lies at the feet of the government and their public policy, and the inability and failure of the government to be prepared to provide appropriate finances to address these shortfalls.

You cannot expect a young Aboriginal person who, like many in the bush may have English as a second, third or even fourth language in some cases, and who might leave school at the age of 13 or 14 with a reading age of year 3 or 4 in the school system, to be able to fit into a TAFE course which may require literacy qualifications for entry to that course. Whose responsibility is this? We know that Aboriginal people cannot then compete in the labour market because they cannot get the training to give them the skills to actually do the work.

I see nothing coming from the government which is designed to address this problem. We hear a lot of platitudes and a lot of statements about its brave intentions, but there is very little to improve the outcomes in this area. As we approach a federal election, there is an obligation on the government to acknowledge that it has failed indigenous Australians in the area of education. The government needs to acknowledge that it needs to do a great deal more in terms of what it proposes to the Australian people to improve educational outcomes for indigenous Australians. However, it is not only indigenous education outcomes that need to be addressed; as I have said, there are many other matters. I have raised in this place before the way in which Aboriginal Australians, certainly in my electorate of the Northern Territory, have been shortchanged by approaches from this government, particularly with regard to roads and other infrastructure. It is all very well funding the Deputy Prime Minister's seat—I expect to no avail in the end—and providing $43 million for roads when my electorate of 1.3 million square kilometres and 110,000 voters gets half that amount of money. It was justified on the basis of need in the Deputy Prime Minister's electorate—I fear not; it was justified on the basis of political expediency. That is the issue here. Indigenous education is not a priority for this government—as much as it might like to say that it is. Indigenous education has never been a real priority for this government.

The new Chief Minister of the Northern Territory was in the gallery this afternoon. Thank God she was elected. I say that for this very simple reason: the previous Northern Territory government, the CLP and the conservative brothers and sisters of the government, had refused to sign an indigenous education program agreement with the Commonwealth government which was a program worth around $43 million for education in the Northern Territory. They refused to sign that strategic initiatives program because they could not agree with the outcomes that the Commonwealth wanted. I think that I am right to say that one of the first acts of the new Martin Labor government in the Northern Territory was to instruct the department to sign off with the Commonwealth on those outcomes and to get the $43 million so it can be spent on Aboriginal education in the Northern Territory. A lot needs to be done. As I have said, we have seen a great failure on behalf of this government. It talks about practical reconciliation, but in reality it has failed.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Amendment Bill 2001. I spoke on the same issue last year when the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Bill 2000 came before this House. I moved some amendments to the bill then. This bill is similar to last year's bill. While there are some changes in funding, in overall terms there are very few changes in policy or approaches.

speech.para: Last year, I raised the issue of what really can be a successful program in indigenous education. What can we do to ensure that we have successful educational outcomes for our Aboriginal people? The answer to that must be that, besides focusing on literacy and numeracy—which the government likes to do—we must also focus on a culturally reasonable and appropriate educational program for Aboriginal children and young adults.

That means that we have to ask ourselves what has happened in relation to Aboriginal culture. This is a very tough question for a society that has essentially acted for over 200 years in a way that was designed to destroy Aboriginal culture. We did succeed in many ways. We succeeded in destroying much of Aboriginal culture. Many Aboriginal languages have virtually disappeared and many cultural traditions have disappeared. Even when some of those cultural traditions remain in some pockets, very often Aboriginal people that came from those traditions have no access to them. So, besides the physical suffering that we imposed upon the Aboriginal people, probably just as cruel was the destruction of their cultural traditions and the removal of people from those traditions so that they were not able to be brought up in those traditions or able to be educated in those traditions.

In the debate on the stolen generation some people said, `Let's not overemphasise what happened. After all, these kids who were taken were brought up in Christian schools and they were taught things. If they had stayed in their original homes, they would probably have been worse off. Let's not overestimate the consequences of the stolen generation.' The single most important point here is this: in removing those children, we did not simply remove them from the family bond and situation as we understand it, we also removed them from their cultural milieu, from their cultural situation. In so doing, we effectively brought them up without much knowledge, or with no knowledge whatsoever, of their cultural traditions. Because so many people suffered this fate, whether they were directly stolen or removed in other ways, we have undermined Aboriginal cultures because we have removed much of the knowledge and much of the spirit of Aboriginal culture from many of the Aboriginal people themselves.

We must come to a recognition of this fact, because the social and cultural alienation of the Aboriginal people is really what has happened. It is this social and cultural alienation which has in a sense broken the spirit of so many Aboriginal people. I do not say all. There are many who have resisted this, but there are also many who have been broken in spirit. When we see Aboriginal people who appear to be, from a Western point of view, at the dead end of society—in poverty, in situations that we would consider deprivation—and many people say, `It is all their responsibility,' we forget about what has happened here. We forget that their spirit has been broken because they have lost their cultural traditions.

That is why at least a part of a reasonable and sensible program of Aboriginal or indigenous education must focus on the teaching of Aboriginal culture and tradition in the first instance to Aboriginal children. The government seems very keen to set targets in terms of numeracy and literacy, but it refuses to put into programs anything to do with actually teaching Aboriginal children about Aboriginal cultural traditions. If anything is taught, it is taught primarily on a voluntary basis in schools. Some schools do it and some schools do not do it, but there is no requirement, even though we have this targeted program. If we are not even teaching Aboriginal children about their cultural traditions, what hope is there of teaching other children about Aboriginal culture so that they can understand it and appreciate it, so that we can have genuine reconciliation?
Last year I raised this issue in the bill that went before the parliament. I raised the question with ATSIC. I received a letter from the chairman of ATSIC. He said:

quote.para: I understand that you are to propose amendments to the government's Bill, the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Bill 2000.
While I look forward to seeing the details of the amendments when they are tabled, I would like to provide some comments on your proposal.

Firstly, I must comment that ATSIC does have a role of advising the government and the Ministers on legislation affecting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and will continue to provide as much positive input in that role to the government, whenever legislation is in formulation.

Secondly, ATSIC already has broad policy and strategic objectives which indicate our strong support for the inclusion of indigenous cultural and heritage education for our people. For example, the ATSIC Corporate Plan states, inter alia:
ATSIC will aim to be well placed to protect our existing land, sea and cultural heritage rights, as well as extend the formal recognition of these rights;
ATSIC will ensure indigenous people are aware of and can exercise their rights, by funding education awareness campaigns on rights for indigenous peoples;
ATSIC will promote the recognition of the right to use and be educated in indigenous languages in Australia.
