Thirdly, I note that the UN Human Rights Committee, in its recent examination of Australia's compliance with the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights asked the Australian representatives how Australian law guarantees the continuation of indigenous culture and livelihood for the future—a question which unfortunately was not, and cannot be, given a positive response.

Given my preceding comments, I would like to add my own view that the proposed Bill will be insufficient if it does not carry provisions for the education of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in our own languages, of our own social Responsibilities and of our distinct indigenous cultural heritage. These are surely the fundamental components of our identity as Indigenous Peoples.

You may take from these comments that I am in support of your intention to strengthen the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Bill 2000 by including quantifiable targets for the education of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people regarding our own cultural heritage.

I look forward to following the progress of your amendments during the parliamentary debate and I will ensure that ATSIC remains available to advise the government, the parliament and members of the parliament on this most important policy issue.
Yours sincerely
Geoff Clark

speech.para: During the debate on the bill, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs indicated that, although they do not agree with specific targets in this matter, they will aim to achieve certain outcomes when educating children, Aboriginal children particularly, about their cultural traditions. I was told that there would an attempt to monitor this situation and report back to the parliament. We have a new bill that deals with this issue but no report. We do not have any idea of whether anything much has been achieved with respect to what Mr Clark described since that commitment last year, which is surely the fundamental component of our identity as indigenous peoples.

With my amendments last year, I tried to ensure that a minimum of 20 per cent of education was dedicated to the teaching of indigenous cultures and heritage. This was to ensure that, when schools received funding under these proposals, they at least tried to have a component of this kind. I do not say that the whole responsibility in this matter rests with the federal government, but I do say that, as the government is funding under this program, it should be monitoring this and it should be trying to achieve these outcomes.

Unless we address this issue, we will not be in a position to restore the heritage of the Aboriginal people to a level that will allow us to say with confidence that that heritage will continue into future generations. What am I talking about when I refer to this heritage? One might ask, `How can you do anything? There are so many Aboriginal cultures and languages.' We can certainly do much to restore the many common elements, even though there are differences. We can certainly do much in particular areas of Australia where there are high concentrations of Aboriginal people to help them to promote their fundamental values about humanity, about spirituality and about respect for one another—a whole different concept of Aboriginal society and philosophy. We need to ensure that that concept is not destroyed in the 21st century.

Since the debate last year, a book was published—I have forgotten now the name of it—that presented the diametrically opposite view to the one I am presenting to you. Basically the book said that we need to tell indigenous people to forget about their cultural traditions—to forget about their backgrounds, become Western and get with it in the 21st century. They should forget entirely about all of that rich cultural heritage— which, by the way, we can learn much from—and simply become part of the globalised village, which will have certain common beliefs and values and will exclude indigenous ideas whether they be indigenous Aboriginal ideas or even indigenous ideas from other cultures. I totally reject the thesis in that book.

We all understand that globalisation is heading in a certain direction, that communications humanity in a sense is moving closer together and that interactions of an economic nature will become increasingly more globalised—there is a certain inevitability about that. Globalisation does not mean that cultural diversity is finished. Globalisation does not mean that valued traditions, including the traditions of our own indigenous people, will be destroyed or should be destroyed and forgotten about. The thesis in that book was observed, but it was dangerous as well. This is why, when we have discussions about globalisation, we also need to have discussions about cultural survival—the survival of a diversity of cultures in a global context. Wouldn't it be a shame if all of the richness of humanity through its many cultures was destroyed through a globalised process and we all had the same beliefs, the same philosophies, the same values, the same metaphysics and the same political philosophy?

talk.start.para: —It would be a boring world.

—It would be a boring world, as the honourable member says. But it would not be just a boring world; it would be a world in which we would not really have the totality of the richness that human beings have created in this world. That is why we have to protect and support Aboriginal cultural traditions. Where they have been destroyed we have to help restore them. We have to teach a lot about Aboriginal cultural traditions to Aboriginal children, and not just to those children living in remote areas but also to Aboriginal children living in the cities. I go back to the point that Mr Clark made in his letter to me: it is the very question of identity. The Aboriginal people themselves lose their identity if they lose their traditions and cultures. We have done so much to destroy their cultures and traditions; let us do something positive. Let us not just talk about having an indigenous education policy that is simply teaching them how to read and write. Let us look at an indigenous education policy that teaches them about these traditions.

speech.para: The proposal that I put forward last year for a modest 20 per cent of the curriculum to be dedicated to that was not a very huge proposal. It was a modest proposal. ATSIC supported this general idea. Other people in this chamber supported this general idea. But we have not heard much from the government about what is to be done with it. What we need from the government, and indeed what we will need from whoever is in government after the election in November, is a statement about the role of education in Aboriginal culture. We need a statement that addresses these fundamental issues of Aboriginal identity, of Aboriginal culture and its relationship to education. The member for the Northern Territory is right: we need to do a lot in housing, employment, health, infrastructure and all those areas, but we may do all of that and still not get the successes that we want until we help restore what was the spirit of the Aboriginal people, which was based on a whole belief system—a philosophy, a metaphysics, various religious practices and a relationship to the land, which is one that we still do not understand because it is different from our views of land. All of those ideas have to come back into an indigenous policy, because only in this way will we be able to have a genuine indigenous education policy and a policy that can assist to ensure the survival of our indigenous cultures throughout the 21st century.

talk.start.para: — The Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Amendment Bill 2001 is not unusual in terms of the bills that come before this parliament. It is one that ultimately everybody will vote for but about which some of us feel disappointment. Its purposes are to provide more funding for indigenous education. Who can complain about that? But it is so sadly inadequate and part of a structure of measures that are failing. You feel like crying out and saying, `Can't you see that more needs to be done.' But, on the eve of the election, all we are really able to do is say, `Here are some resources that are needed; they ought to be provided so let us not stand in the way. Let us simply say that what is being done is not enough and advocate the case for more, subsequent.'

speech.para: The money that is being provided pursuant to this bill arising to offset the impact of the fringe benefits tax is entirely non-controversial in its intention. It is not possible to assess whether it is adequate in its amount. The opposition broadly supported the changes to the fringe benefits tax, because they were about cleaning up the taxation system far beyond the indigenous organisations that were caught up in the crossfire of those amendments. The government was very tardy in its consideration of how the affected indigenous organisations might be compensated but, ultimately, it put in the budget an amount of money that is flowing out to indigenous organisations. I have been speaking to them around the country and there is no doubt that it is assisting them in meeting the crisis in staffing that was caused by the changes, but whether it can be considered as adequate only time will tell.

But that is not the controversial part of the legislation; everybody accepts that there needs to be that compensation. The amount has been objectively estimated and we hope it proves to be adequate. The significance of the bill is in its direct educational expenditure. I want to respond very briefly to the remarks by the member for Calwell, not by way of criticism, because one cannot but admire his passionate commitment. I think the proposition he put forward last year was far too prescriptive. It assumed that the solution that is appropriate for some parts of Australia was nationally appropriate, and it assumed that we can set a targeted amount of money and that that will be broadly applicable. I think that is heroic in its assumptions but not particularly helpful. But the underlying intent of what he was setting out to achieve is valid and worthy of recognition. The concern about indigenous culture and indigenous language, its recognition and support and its enhancement by the educational process rather than by that educational process being in conflict with the process of protection, enhancement, reinforcement and continuity in indigenous culture is a valid concept and is worthy of recognition and respect.

The additional funding provided by this bill is designed to assist secondary school students to go on to year 12 and beyond or to undertake vocational education and training. Over the last decade or so, and in some ways you could say over the last three decades, there has been a substantial increase in Commonwealth funding for indigenous education. That is welcome and necessary. Recently the government has added a more specific outcome objective related to its national literacy and numeracy strategy. It is not possible to argue that literacy and numeracy are other than worthwhile objectives; the risk is that the minister's focus on it might narrow the focus of educational funding as a whole and indigenous education in particular. I think this issue needs some further analysis. There has been a lot of very useful debate about this more broadly in the education community, but I do not want to divert onto it today. I simply say that it is a necessary, but not sufficient, condition for an adequate indigenous education strategy, and I hope we can get a broader focus.

It is that broader focus that I want to talk about. We need to get beyond the issue of so-called practical reconciliation—and that is consistent with the points that the member for Calwell was making. We need to look beyond those things which the government seems to think, for some reason, are special benefits given to indigenous people: housing, health, employment and education—as if those things were not a fundamental government obligation for all Australians. It is not a unique obligation for indigenous people. Along with that, there should be a recognition that there needs to be adequate support in those basic areas of housing, health, employment and education, that these are rights for all citizens, not special entitlements for indigenous people, and that we are not doing them a favour by providing necessary and appropriate support. This goes to the great fallacy that treating everybody the same constitutes equality. There is no way, in health policy, that we would ever say that we should spend as much money on healthy people as we do on sick people. Health funding should be proportionate to need. Rationally, one would have thought that we would do the same in education funding, but we too often hear the fallacy that somehow equality is the same as uniformity and we should treat everybody the same even if their needs are different. That is the first thing we have to dispel. The second thing is that we have to recognise that rights and issues of culture, social questions and questions of justice are worthwhile goals in themselves as well as playing into whether we can achieve our objectives of practical reconciliation.

One would have to say that the practical reconciliation agenda is failing. I spent quite a lot of last week visiting indigenous education institutions, particularly tertiary institutions, and looking at the statistics. I have a particular concern about the decline in indigenous participation in tertiary education. Progress in secondary education seems to have stalled, but even the government's own department has released figures that show that, in tertiary education, commencements and enrolments of indigenous Australians have fallen dramatically in the last year. Commencements have fallen by 15.2 per cent and enrolments have fallen by 8.1 per cent, to below or just above the 1996 statistics. After years of steady increase in the proportion of indigenous higher education students, that figure has started to decline again in 2000. Participation of indigenous Australians in vocational education and training also fell in 2000.

In 2000, there were fewer indigenous students enrolled in higher education than there were in 1999, and the number of commencing students was 630 fewer than in 1999. It had fallen from over 4,000 to approximately 3,500. These are the statistics of failure, and this is why we cannot oppose this legislation. Inadequate as we might think it is, if we are confronted with those circumstances and someone comes forward with resources that might be of value, we have to say, `Too little, too late; but better than nothing. Let's support this and let these resources flow as quickly as possible.' But nobody can be comfortable with the circumstances where enrolments and participation—absolutely and as a proportion of tertiary education participation—are falling. Any incoming government will have to face this issue after the election, and I certainly give a fundamental commitment that an incoming Labor government will address it.

talker.name: Worth, Trish, MP
Ms WORTH
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —In summing up, I would like to thank all those who have contributed to the debate on the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Amendment Bill 2001, because it is certainly an important bill. While the educational outcomes for indigenous Australians are improving, considerable gaps still remain between the educational achievements of indigenous and non-indigenous Australians, with indigenous Australians remaining the most educationally disadvantaged group in Australia.

speech.para: The Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Act 2000 is the vehicle for the government's Indigenous Education Strategic Initiative Program—or IESIP, as it is commonly known—for the 2001-04 quadrennium and provides the authority to approve some $591 million in grants to indigenous education providers in the states and territories over the quadrennium. This funding affirms the government's very strong commitment to indigenous education in Australia, an area that we know to be very important.

The purpose of the bill that I am commending to the chamber today is twofold. Firstly, it will allow for the funding of projects involving partnerships between communities, industries and education providers and business support for vocational learning for indigenous secondary schools. Secondly, it will accommodate amendments to the Fringe Benefits Tax Act 1986, which now restricts the use of tax concessions used by charities and other nonprofit organisations, which includes most Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations, to a maximum of $30,000 of the gross taxable value of the benefit per employee. The amendment in this bill allows funding to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations to minimise the impact of the restrictions.

The first amendment in the bill is a consequence of a budget measure under the Australians Working Together package. The measure is a response to one of the recommendations of the McClure report, Participation report for a more equitable society. The recommendation aims to encourage business investment in community economic development and provide leadership skills to disadvantaged communities. There are two elements to the budget measure: partnerships between communities, industry and education providers; and support for vocational learning for indigenous secondary school students. The projects involving partnerships between communities, industry and education providers are aimed at providing support for a significant cohort of secondary school indigenous students to stay on and successfully complete year 12 and go on to higher education or vocational education and training and industry based traineeships. The vocational learning projects will be based on local community industry needs and opportunities.

The early intervention strategies to be funded through the bill are based on the experiences of the Polly Farmer Foundation Gumala project, which has been successfully operating in Western Australia. The vision of the Gumala project is to improve the educational outcomes for Aboriginal students in the Roeborne area to a level commensurate with the broader population so that they are able to compete effectively for apprenticeships and commercial cadetships or to pursue further education and employment opportunities.

The fringe benefits tax compensation measure in the bill affects only those organisations that are providing salary packages to employees at 31 March 2001 in excess of $30,000 per employee. This is annualised and grossed up and does not include items such as remote housing allowances. The provision is expected to affect an unknown number of educational institutions but is included in this bill so that nonprofit Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations can continue to provide staff with competitive salary packages and so that students who are educated by those organisations are not in turn disadvantaged by the changes which have been made to the Fringe Benefits Tax Act 1986. This is particularly important in remote areas, where it is difficult to attract suitably qualified staff. The bill provides increases in appropriations for non-Abstudy payments by $2,538,000 for 2002, $4,504,000 for 2003 and $4,417,000 for 2004.

With respect to the comments made by the member for Dobell regarding cuts to Abstudy from 1 January 2000, I would remind the member that more than $15 million was transferred from Abstudy to the Indigenous Education Strategic Initiatives Program for away-from-base activities for indigenous students undertaking studies through a combination of distance education and residential schools and other face-to-face teaching.

The member for the Northern Territory expressed some concerns about indigenous students enrolled in vocational education and training, or voc ed, as we know it. It should be noted that, although there is an apparent decrease in the number of indigenous students commencing higher education—that is, university studies—there has been a substantial increase in the number of indigenous students enrolled in voc ed of some 12 per cent between 1998 and 2000. In 1995 there were 26,000 indigenous people in vocational education and training courses; in 2000 there were over 51,000—almost double that number. I consider this a very good achievement and something the government can take some pride in. Further, the Aboriginal take-up of New Apprenticeships has trebled in the past two years. The New Apprenticeships increased from 1,080 to 5,340 by March 2001.

The member for Calwell asked some questions about monitoring programs and reporting to parliament. I remind the member for Calwell that reporting takes place in the year following the allocation of funding, so he should look forward to tuning in next year for that report.

Again, I thank those who have taken part in the debate, and I commend the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Amendment Bill 2001 to continue the work to address educational disadvantage in the indigenous community.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

subdebate.1.para: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Ms Worth) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 30 August, on motion by Mr Entsch:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The opposition supports this measure. The Excise Tariff Amendment (Crude Oil) Bill 2001 is designed to reduce the excise applicable to two kinds of oil: old and new oil, variously described, in order to seek to increase the production incentives for the respective kinds of oil that are described in the bill. The government, of course, is no doubt responding to the perceived problem which, I think, is quite rightly identified as an issue for Australia in the future. While we have been quite self-sufficient in crude oil reserves in the past, the reality now is that, as we look to the future, our reserves of crude and the potential reserves that we might exploit in the future are somewhat diminished over those that we have enjoyed in the past. As we look to that depleted situation in future years we can also look to increased costs from importing this essential commodity for our industry and for commerce. The reality is that that is a very expensive proposition and, clearly, the government, like the opposition, in seeking to avoid that kind of situation in the future, is looking for measures that might increase the discovery and production from the various kinds of existing and new facilities.

speech.para: Oil, of course, has the tags of `old' and `new' oil on the basis of when it was discovered and brought into production. Following the oil price shocks of the OPEC crisis in the early 1970s the then Whitlam government introduced an excise on crude oil in order to ensure that profits and super profits in those days arising from indigenous discoveries were shared with the Australian people and taxpayers. Oil which was in production before 18 September 1975 was referred to as `old' oil, and that oil which has been brought into production subsequent to 18 September 1975 is referred to as `new' oil—although these days it is getting somewhat older. However, the legislation in consequence of that seeks to find ways to stimulate production by lowering the excise rates on both these kinds of oil. The reductions are not dramatic. While the amount of money is obviously in the millions of dollars, compared to the cost and value of large scale oil production obviously it is not an overwhelming amount but certainly will contribute towards the incentives to find the new reserves and to increase the production from those existing reserves.

There are other issues associated with the exploration and discovery of crude oil and petroleum resources. While we are facing the issue with crude oil, we do have quite substantial reserves of gas and condensate and we are in the position of importing and exporting these products. So notwithstanding the issue of domestic production of LNG and condensate, we also have the proposition that we import some of these commodities into Australia. Given the sheer geographical size of our country and the ease of shipping it directly from one area to another externally, it is often a better economic proposition to import some of these products into the eastern seaboard even if we export some of them from the western seaboard.

The government over the last few years— it has now come to this conclusion probably somewhat late in the piece—have also undertaken a number of activities which have themselves contributed to reduce exploration. The one about which I am particularly concerned is the way in which they have allowed the Australian Geological Survey Organisation, AGSO, or Geoscience Australia, to shed staff and reduce their overall capability. The organisation have always had a very good reputation with industry and with the parliament and the public of Australia for being the premier scientific and geological survey organisation in the country. The data that they collect is of enormous use in a pre-competitive context both in mineral exploration and also in petroleum resources.

Since this government has come to office quite significant cutbacks have occurred in the budget available to AGSO and that has reduced their capability and ability to assist the industry to look for new resources that this country will find essential. In the very period when Australia is facing reduced exploration in mineral activity and significantly reduced reserves of crude oil, we find the government acting quite in accordance with the economic cycle and the downturn by reducing the capability of the one organisation of government able to add value to the data and to provide extra capacity to the industry—instead of acting countercyclically and, in fact, increasing the funding available to that kind of organisation so that they might get out into the industry, make more data available perhaps at better rates and ensuring that those who are committing substantial sums to exploration and development of our mineral and crude resources are actually able to do that with somewhat less risk. By producing data in the pre-competitive phase, AGSO reduces the risk to those companies that would otherwise be forced to put substantial dollars of their own on the table in order to look for likely prospects for mineral or petroleum reserves. By reducing the availability of that data they are undermining our potential productivity in the area of mineral and petroleum resources, and this evening we are particularly concerned with the issue of those petroleum resources.

Australia will eventually have a number of alternatives in this area. There is the potential of gas to liquids projects that seek to convert some of our abundant gas reserves into an alternative diesel effectively which, of course, is a very worthwhile project, and a number of options are available on that scale. There are also alternative means of powering some vehicles that use crude and some of those products that are ultimately derived from crude. So while one particular fuel or energy source is not the make or break of our economy, the reality is that for the foreseeable future we will be very dependent on the importation of crude oil at significant cost to our economy and the industry.

While the opposition supports these measures as essential to encourage the exploration and production of this vital commodity, we would also draw attention to some of the policy failings in recent years. While certainly not the sole contributing factor— no-one makes that suggestion—the failure of the government to adequately fund AGSO and their failure to identify the obvious problem some time back and to ensure that industry was well positioned to respond otherwise in a time of downturn, I think represents a failure of policy at government level.

Quite clearly, the government must take some of the responsibility for the position in which we now find ourselves—not so much the position we are in now, but the position we will be in in future years. As with everything in the resources industry, there are significant time lags involved. The period of time between exploration and production, in the case of minerals, can be five years or more. In the case of petroleum, it can be even longer. The amount of investment required is also quite substantial. The opposition is pleased to provide a speedy passage for this legislation, since it is obviously necessary that we undertake this. I think it is well worth while drawing the community's attention to the failures which we have perceived in recent years, which are outlined in Knowledge Nation.

talk.start.para: — Nobody who has an interest in communications, transport or industry can fail to give attention to the need for oil fuels and oil based fuels. It is only fairly recently that we have become aware of the way in which the OPEC countries can artificially jack up prices to maintain a money volume flow into their economies, and they do that by reducing oil production and increasing prices. Countries such as Iraq, which produces almost only oil, can use price increases to create tremendous damage internationally. Saudi Arabia has been ready to expand production and to modify the price of crude oil around the world. The flexibility and dynamics of politics and economics in the Middle East affects much of the cost of production in industry and much of the cost of transport in Australia.

speech.para: The government's Excise Tariff Amendment (Crude Oil) Bill 2001 will encourage, to some degree, greater exploration and greater development of oil and some gas resources in Australia. It is a proposal that, when you come to look at it, deals with the domestic price excise on crude oil. It is a most complex piece of legislation, because you have old, intermediate and new oil excise prices. Governments over a period—as tends to be their fashion—have chosen all sorts of formulas to define new, old and intermediate oils. They all carry a different excise. The level of excise depends on where crude oil is produced in Australia or whether it is branded old, new or intermediate. It is complex, and this government is seeking to simplify it to some degree and to ease the pressure on crude oil producers so that there will be encouragement for oil exploration and production both onshore and offshore. A secondary effect will be gas discoveries arising from oil exploration.

The Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, Senator Nick Minchin, announced the government's decision on 15 August, just a little over a month ago. We are dealing here with the legislation that relates to that announcement. It was a very significant announcement, in which the minister said:

quote.para: Ultimately, the consumer and Australia will benefit from efforts to meet Australia's future energy needs through enhancing Australia's self-sufficiency in oil and gas.

speech.para: Every Australian would want to endorse that. When we saw petrol prices soaring at the retail level to a dollar a litre or somewhere near that, people began to really worry about where we were going with self-sufficiency. The most frequently asked question that was addressed to me as a federal member was, `I thought we produced most of our petrol and most of our oil ourselves, so why are we jacking up prices?'

When one has some time to explain to people the complexity of world markets and the way in which world prices can be driven from the Middle East, how Australia must be free to sell on the open market or we expose our domestic market to all sorts of distortion, and how the process is now not in any way driven by government taxing policies—I will come back to that—they begin to understand how reliant we are on maintaining a good effort in both exploration and production. The minister went on to say:

quote.para: The potential expansion of Australia's gas reserves as a consequence of these legislative changes could be expected to contribute towards additional opportunities on the North West Shelf for downstream value-adding gas industries and for Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG).

speech.para: There we have a good decision—one that will add to Australia's efficiency, one that will add to our pool of resources to be used for Australian transport and industry production, and one which this government has sensibly made.

The cost in one year, as I remember it, is something like $80 million, but the industry representatives and economic writers in the popular press have welcomed this decision. I noticed an article in the Australian dated 20 August headed `Excise Scrapped to Oil Wheels of Exploration'. In that article, I noticed that a Woodside Energy spokesman welcomed the move to increase the prospect of greater production and exploration. Another Weekend Australian article of 25 August was headed `Nation Needs to Maintain Tax Incentive'. One in the Australian Financial Review was headed `Canberra to Cut Crude Oil Excise'. That is a summary of what we are doing in the House tonight.

The formulas and the scales are all within the legislation, and it is only if you are an oil producer—and very few of us have oil producers in our electorates—that you would be concerned about the detail. But I would be remiss if I let this opportunity go by without making some remarks about the far-sightness of this government in removing the automatic indexation on petrol, because it is a complementary process that we are entering into here tonight. The first move was to wipe out that indexation, something that was imposed as a revenue raiser by the Whitlam government—Paul Keating was chortling, budget after budget, about the amount of money that was gushing into the Treasury coffers from his indexation of petrol. It took John Howard and the government to wipe out and kill that indexation. In fact, the Labor Party in one instance when they were in government—and, Mr Deputy Speaker Quick, you may remember it, but I will remind you in case you have not—were increasing their excise grab on a monthly basis. So the Australian motorist was the person responsible for filling up the coffers of Treasury for the then Prime Minister and previously Treasurer, who had claimed that he was the world's best Treasurer.

The Hawke government fiddled the excise once a month during a 12-month period in 1986-87, diddling the motorist—and `diddling' is a word that comes from Alan Ramsey, a long-time friend, I understand, of former Prime Minister Keating. Alan Ramsey outlines in detail what he felt was a really obnoxious process of gaining revenue. The claim was made at that time by the Australian Labor Party that when crude oil prices fell, because we are tied in with world prices, the price of petrol would automatically come down. Nothing could have been further from the truth—absolutely nothing could have been further from the truth. It took the government at the beginning of this year to have the courage to say, `We are not into those hidden taxes; we are going to wipe out that 1.5c increase that occurred in January, and never again are we going back to the indexation of excise on petrol.' So we have a double consideration of the transportation and fuel needs of Australia.

These are the very things—and I know that the member for Leichhardt will be very well aware of long distances in Australia and of the fact that the need, when you are in remote areas, for the provision of dieseline, petrol and oil for fuel is critical for lighting plants, equipment, and moving vehicles and people around. Of course, that does not discount the significance of air transport and air travel, whether it be the flying doctor services for emergencies or just the day-to-day business and family transportation. Australia is absolutely dependent on fuel oil for our success and continuation. The more remote the area, the more dynamic the member of parliament seems to be in representing that area, and the more significant this legislation becomes for the member and the people they represent.

This legislation really does simplify the payment of excise on crude oil, but the big advantage is the incentive that it gives to go out and explore, and to produce more of Australia's natural resources. It means we become more self-reliant and that complements a wise decision taken by the government earlier this year to wipe out indexation of fuel excise.

talk.start.para: —I must admit I came here with the wrong information. I thought this was going to be a bipartisan debate on the Excise Tariff Amendment (Crude Oil) Bill 2001 because we both support it. But I find that the member for Mitchell simply cannot restrain himself. He has to get the barbs in wherever he can. I hope he stays and listens, because there is a little information I would certainly like to give him.

speech.para: We certainly support this legislation because it is designed to encourage exploration. It is designed to help Australia move towards self-sufficiency in liquid petroleum product. But it is also a statement of the lack imagination of this government, because this government is saying that the only form of liquid petroleum will come from crude oil. The whole point is that in Australia today we have the capacity to move towards the degree of self-sufficiency that the member for Mitchell was talking about. But, unfortunately, at the same time that this government reduced or removed the excise from CPI indexation, it whacked the GST on LP gas. We have seen what that has done to a typical Australian industry. If this government is fair dinkum, if this government is real and means what it says about us becoming self-sufficient in fuel reserves, it would do something about what it did to kill off the LPG industry, the liquid natural gas industry.

The other thing that this government did when it was first elected back in 1996 was remove the bounty from new ethanol. The amazing thing is that we are a country that has the technology to use ethanol as a liquid fuel. We have Dr Russell Reeves, and I use his name constantly in this House, because he happens to reside in the electorate I represent. He is a world expert on ethanol technology. The company of which he is a part, APACE Research, holds the world patent for blending ethanol with diesel to produce diesohol, that five or six years ago was used in the ACTION buses right here in Canberra. It was used because ethanol is an oxygenator, creating better burning of the fuel and reducing pollution, and it is something that we produce in this country. If the government had had the foresight back in 1996 to maintain the bounty for new product ethanol, we could have encouraged a whole new industry.

I would like to raise another issue tonight, and it is an issue of real concern when we consider the situation of the world today— the instability and the possibility of the world being pushed into a global conflict. With the current state of play in the United States of America, there is no doubt that a conflict would most likely involve the Middle East, that very rich source of crude oil. The shame of the matter is that Australia is certainly not self-sufficient in crude oil and we are no longer self-sufficient in distilled product; we are increasingly dependent on importing distilled spirit from offshore—and that is a shame. We no longer have the capacity to refine enough liquid petrol and liquid diesel for our own industry. How are we going to be if, as the Prime Minister says, we are prepared to support the United States all the way? It is quite likely that some of our sources of liquid petroleum will be denied to us. That is a distinct possibility in the short-term future.

I venture to say that, if that happens, we will look back and rue the day that we put a GST on LPG; we will rue the day that we killed off the ethanol industry by removing the bounty for new ethanol and encouraging a new industry, because Australia is unique in this. We have the capacity to use both of these fuels probably more than any other nation in the world, and we ignore it—and the government expects us to hold this up and say that this is a triumph for modern thinking. It is not. It is, I would suggest, a logical way to go. But we need to be a bit more expansive. We need to use a bit of lateral thinking.

We have been dictated to too long by the fossil fuel industry, by the enormous wealth of the petroleum companies. We need to be able to break that shackle, because eventually one day we will get to a situation where we will not get a new oil well that yields any product that we want. That is simply a fact of life. We are going to have to develop new technologies to move on. As I say, here in Australia we do have that capacity.

I would also like to point out that I listened to part of a lecture by David Hale the other day. I know that David Hale is a pessimist—I realise that—but I think he is probably also a realist. He gave a lecture in Zurich, and I read part of what he said. He makes the prediction that within six months we will be staring at crude oil being in the order of $50 to $60 a barrel. What does that have the capacity to do to Australian industry and to the defence of Australia, when we have put the brakes on other alternative fuels that we should have been developing, encouraging and nurturing? While the government is supported by the opposition in this piece of legislation, there are other paths that we can go down—and we should.

I heard my predecessor, Martyn Evans, indicate that the knowledge nation is a way to the future for Australia, and I am horrified when I hear members opposite denigrate it. But, as I say, one day we will put down a drill for an oil well and we will keep putting down holes for oil wells, and we will not come up with any oil. Then we will have to go back to the textbooks and design a new technology for a new fuel. We already have some of those new fuels, and we are ignoring the ways in which they can be used. If we were the clever country that Knowledge Nation points to, we would realise the capacity we have there and we would realise the potential that we have in alternatives. We would nurture those alternatives—and we would make sure that we get there quickly.

talk.start.para: —The issue of oil and petrol pricing is one that I have spoken about in this place for many, many years—even in the previous place. In fact, I can remember as chairman of the industry committee of the Labor caucus in 1983 having debates about the taxation of oil and other natural resources—the so-called resources rent tax issue. In those days there was a lot of debate about how we were going to proceed in terms of taxing of oil and how we were going to balance the considerations involved in that very complicated subject. But in more recent times we have had the situation where the international price of oil, the so-called world price of oil, has fluctuated dramatically. Indeed, up until a little while ago it was continuously going up, and we were faced with very serious increases at the petrol pump—increases which were resulting in a heavy burden being placed on the Australian people.

speech.para: At that time the government spoke of the rises in the cost of petrol as simply being a consequence of being tied into the world parity pricing regime. There was no attempt to explain to the Australian people why we were tied into the world parity pricing policy, the benefits of that and whether there was some way to, at least, overcome the problems created by fluctuations in the policy.

The explanatory memorandum to this bill provides significant information regarding the various levels of production and some of the costs of production. Yet when I asked the minister a question on notice relating to the current costs of production of oil in Australia as declared by the major companies involved in such production, the answer was, `The sort of information required to answer the honourable member's questions is not available.' Interestingly, we now have the situation where it suits the government to try to change the arrangements and lots of information is available about the costs of production and the taxing of those costs. One wants to ask the question: why is it available now in the context of this bill and why was it not available then?

I do not oppose the provisions of this bill because they try to make it more commercially viable for companies to exploit old oilfields rather than new ones or, at least, provide parity in relation to the taxing of old oilfields and the taxing of new ones. As I said at the time, any increase in Australian production is welcomed. It is welcomed because it is better to rely on your own natural resources rather than import oil or even petrol.

Having said that, though, the current situation in respect of petrol pricing is no different from the situation that existed a few months ago. The regime has not been changed. The issues raised, including by me in a question to the Prime Minister, have not been faced. As I think the honourable member for Patterson said, in a few months time we could be faced with another oil shock, another situation where the price of oil may go up. We have not dealt with the central question of how we would respond to that situation, especially if the price of petrol at the petrol pump were to rise significantly. In other words, the problem has been ameliorated a little bit because the world price of oil has slightly diminished from where it was, but the problem has been swept under the carpet. It has not been solved. It has not been resolved.

We need to resolve that problem. We need to resolve what we as a nation are going to do in relation to the cost of oil production and the relationship between the cost of oil production and the cost of petrol at the bowser. If oil companies can make significant profits when petrol is 87c a litre and then, because the world price goes up, the same companies charge $1.03 a litre, you have to ask the question: why is there a difference in price? You might say it is due to world parity pricing. That is not the reason. That may have been the reason, but that is not the reason the charge goes up. If the petrol is supplied by Australian oil production then those oil companies that are making a profit at 87c a litre are making very big profits at $1.03 a litre.

The point I made at the time was that there is no relationship between the costs of production and a reasonable profit for those Australian companies and the world parity pricing policy. The world parity pricing policy was brought into place at the time because it was felt that there needed to be a spur to exploration and production of crude oil in Australia. The idea was that if we fixed the price at the world price, which was above the price which would have normally been charged by the companies in the marketplace, then we would be effectively giving the companies a profit windfall, which is what we did, and we would expect in return a commitment from them in terms of investment in exploration. I have found out that there has been no relationship between the profits made by international companies involved in Australian exploration and petrol development and world parity pricing. This was just an artificial measure put in place.

It is interesting that the Prime Minister talks about competition policy and the need for us to ensure that the marketplace operates, but in the case of petrol pricing and the profits made by companies through oil exploration what do we have? We have no real competition. We have competition only at the very edges. We have no real competition because we are locked into the world parity pricing policy. As I have said, people are not screaming as much as they were two or three months ago when that policy forced petrol prices in many parts of Australia to above $1 a litre. Just because there has been a stabilisation in the world parity price and companies have been able to provide petrol at between 87c and 93c a litre, it does not mean that that situation will continue. The problem that we identify will remain. That problem has not been resolved.

We have to ask ourselves why we cannot allow more genuine competition among oil companies in Australia based not on world parity pricing but on the actual costs of production in Australia plus a reasonable profit margin. Why can't we allow that? Why do we have to have a policy which, in effect, in most situations gives them substantial and handsome profits, thank you very much? There is no relationship between those who are making profits and those who are committing resources to exploration. In fact, some oil companies have complained to me that all oil companies benefit from the world parity pricing policy, but only some are prepared to invest in new exploration and in the development of new oilfields in Australia. Why should all of them benefit from world parity pricing when only some do something in the national interest and invest in exploration?

At the time of the petrol crisis the government felt that its hands were tied. Finally, as everyone knows, it offered a 1.5c a litre reduction in the taxation regime that applied at the bowser, but of course that minuscule reduction had very little impact. We have to develop a better petrol pricing regime. We have to get away from the situation in which the government has to dramatically reduce the taxation level, because the taxation level must be significant if we are to deal with issues such as conservation arrangements, road funding and many other issues. But at the same time—I am not arguing against a certain level of taxation—we need to focus on the issue that I have raised with respect to the world parity pricing policy and what it is amounting to.

One thing that we have to do before we can make a final decision in this matter is get information about what is happening with respect to oil companies: information about how much investment they are making, information about how much profit they are making, and information about the costs of production and the relationship between the costs of production and the charge they are making at the wholesale level and at the final retail level. All those things need to be studied in an atmosphere of openness, not in a closed atmosphere, as is occurring now. I hope that I never again receive a response from the minister like the one in which he basically said, `The sort of information required to answer the honourable member's question is not available.' Of course it is available. I am not asking for commercially sensitive information; I am asking for information that will allow public policy to be formed in relation to petrol production costs.

I urge the Prime Minister to think about this matter; it is not going to go away. As I have said, several people have commented on the possibility of the world price of crude oil rising again. If that happens and if OPEC makes certain decisions, we could face a situation in which the costs of petrol again go up to exorbitant levels that have a dramatic effect on the cost of living. When that happens, it is important to look at our policy and to think about finding a way through that is consistent with competition policy and with allowing a fair profit for the producers but not allowing people to make huge profits that they then are not required by law to plough into Australia. It would be much better public policy to have greater competition between oil producers, but to offer an additional incentive for those who are prepared to invest in new exploration, to invest in the development of new oilfields, or even to invest in the further exploitation of old oilfields that require new technology. That would be a much saner, more sensible approach than having the kind of policy which rewards everyone involved in oil or petrol production in Australia, even based on oil which is imported into Australia, irrespective of what role they play in the exploration of new fields.

We all need to help to develop energy policy in this country. We must continue to confront the question of oil and natural gas resources. It is especially important for a society like ours which has so many available resources. However, as people have mentioned, unless there is a structure in place which encourages greater exploration and greater development, and which rewards those who are interested in doing something more in this area as opposed to rewarding those who do nothing, we will not have the developments that are required.

I want to say something about the relationship between the oil companies and the cost of petrol at the retail level. Some of the oil companies promised that they would not undermine and perhaps push out independent retailers, the people who wanted to shop around in respect of the wholesale price of petrol. Professor Fels from the ACCC has often commented that the oil companies should be very careful about these sorts of non-competitive pressures that are placed on particular petrol station operators. There was some improvement in behaviour, but I know that a number of independent operators have, in certain cases, been squeezed out of business by major oil companies having too big a role in the retail sector. More work needs to be done in this area and that work ought to be done by a parliamentary committee, or by some other inquiry, which would report back to parliament on ways and means of moving forward to do the best for the Australian consumer.
In the short term, we are stuck with the motorcar and the cost of petrol. We need to get the best result for the Australian motorist. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —in reply—In speaking to the Excise Tariff Amendment (Crude Oil) Bill 2001 I would like to thank the honourable members who have participated in this debate. I thank the member for Bonython for his contribution. His comments about AGSO were particularly relevant. That is a magnificent organisation and I agree with him wholeheartedly. It is a premium geoscience organisation which is very capably run by Neil Williams and his crew. From a government perspective, it is an organisation in which we can take a great deal of pride. It is highly recognised around the world.

speech.para: The member for Mitchell's magnificent contribution touched on the value and incentives created by responsible treatment of excise. For those who might have forgotten, he reminded us that this government removed the automatic CPI increases on petrol, and of the subsequent benefits felt by the Australian public as a result of that action. The member for Paterson raised a very valid point, and one with which I totally agree, in respect of his support for alternative fuel sources. He acknowledged that we have to be able to focus on those alternatives and that we cannot rely forever on our fossil fuels. I remind the member for Paterson of this government's recent investment in ethanol. I am particularly proud of the $7.35 million that went to the Mossman central mill in my electorate as part of a successful G Gap proposal, to develop an ethanol plant. I can tell the House that it is progressing very well. It will certainly have an added value for the sugar industry in my region and it should blow a new breath of life into that region.

I thank the member for Calwell for his contribution. I was pleased that he welcomed the opportunity offered through this bill to increase oil production in Australia which hopefully will reduce our reliance on imports. He also offered some interesting views on the issue of fuel pricing and raised some serious concerns about non-competitive pressures placed on independent operators by majors. I was pleased to see that he acknowledged that there has been quite considerable work done in this area to address these concerns. However, I note his interest in wanting to continue to further investigate this area and to see what further can be done.

The bill responds to concerns raised by industry groups that high excise imposts on old oilfields discourage full exploitation of these existing and very valuable resources. It streamlines current legislation. It reduces certain crude oil excise rates and encourages oil exploration and production both onshore and offshore. A secondary but highly desirable benefit could be gas discoveries arising from oil exploration.

At the moment, the excise regime for crude oil is complex, with rates increasing according to the age of the oilfield and the volume of the oil produced. It is proposed to streamline this system and to reduce rates for the oldest and the newest oilfields. For old oilfields the crude rate is up to 75 per cent. The bill will reduce the rate for some oil by as much as 20 per cent. In addition, as part of the streamlining, the bill will remove the threshold price provisions for old oil. These provisions have not been used recently, so they are an unnecessary complication in the law. Reductions in crude oil excise rates for new oil have the effect of providing an incentive for the North West Shelf expansion project by delivering $75 million worth of assistance over 10 years from 1 July this year.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
